TL:DR below. But honestly, read the whole thing if you consider playing for the first time.  Now me and Warframe have a bit of a 'it's complicated' relationship. So let's do the nice things first and then I'll delve into the parts I don't like in particular or that just make me want to rush the Digital Extremes team with an axe.   THE GOOD  The gameplay and the general mechanics that the game presents as it's main strength (you playing as a space ninja with superpowers) are present, delivered and executed with grace. The game is fun to play and provides quite a lot of entertainment. Moreso if you have friends to play with, since the game is based around coop for up to four players (90% of the game is still solo-able, so you can still play even if you're a person who would totally hang out with other people, but *insert excuse*) Anyways the core game is solid, the forums active and the overall community feels good. The main premise of the gameplay can be summarized like this: Step 1: Disregard enemies Step 2: Acquire currency and resources from the corpses of said enemies. Step 3:Use the aforementioned to craft a weapon Step 4: Further personalize your playstyle by further modifying the weapons in your arsenal and your warframe Step 5: Return to Step 1 Well, disregarding enemies using various weapons, be it a bow capable of tearing through multiple foes with one arrow, a shotgun obliterating your enemies, a staff, a scythe, a massive hammer, kunai, inflato-ray, handheld chainsaws, sniper rifles, claws, high-powered gloves and shoes further enhancing your punches and kicks, a katana, a dog, a flying cube or anything they might've added since I wrote this review is fun, and as you probably realized by now, you have a lot of options to choose from. So you can spend a lot of time either polishing your skills with one weapon or hoarding everything you come across and hugging your recent favorites while drooling in fetal position and chuckling softly later. The crafting system does its job and while some weapons are definitely hard to obtain, if you get to the point where you're able to get them, you probably don't mind sinking a few more hours into the game anyway.  The game has a solid lore partially influenced by the decision of the players and a history shrouded in mystery so well, we can only keep guessing about who we actually play as. The story provides good support to the gameplay and keeps me intrigued.  And mods. Oh boy.  THE MODS  Now, even though I laid before you the core gameplay I purposefully left out one feature, simply because the mods are both good AND bad. Every weapon and 'frame you come across is equipped with a number of empty mod slots. These can be filled with, you guessed it, modifications. Mods are numerous and their effects vary immensely, so the number of possible combinations to try is astronomical. BUT. Mods aren't acquired automatically or unlocked (several exceptions there, but that's like 1% of the total mod count). Mods have to be found from random drops. And given that a specific mod usually drops from a specific enemy, and that a) the chance for that is pretty low and b) the mob may be spawning in end-game levels only, it can and will frustrate some who try to just reach for that one mod they want so badly. Mods can be also improved in terms of effectivity, but that means destroying other mods to improve one, or using several 'Fusion Cores' which give considerably larger bonuses and drop randomly from fallen enemies too. This system is slightly-above-average at best and downright rage-inducing at worst. Also the aforementioned customization is also limited by the player's own (hopefully) human conscience. In short there are mods that aren't worth squat and have no reason to exist whatsoever, since the bonuses they provide can't lift a candle against others. So, instead of making the most of what you've got, you will spend hours/days chasing/fusing that one mod that will finally make your weapon usable in higher levels. There's even a mod that increases overall damage up to insane numbers, a must-have for endgame. So the mod system, while essential, is partially broken. There have been ideas on the forums on how to either rework or discard the system in favor of a new one, but I don't think that we will see any changes in the foreseeable future.  THE STUFF THAT MAKES ME GO OHMYGODWHYISTHISSTILLATHINGAFTERA♥♥♥♥♥♥♥YEAR  1) The inventory For a game with so much custom-loadoutization, Warframe makes one very profitable (for them) and very infuriating (for you) choice. Adding an inventory system. Basically, you have (as of now) about 30 warframes and about 180 weapons. BUT. You can only have two warframes and six weapons in your inventory at once. There are two methods of expanding your inventory-either obtaining event weapons that come with their own separate slots, or purchase aditional slots with platinum (real cash). And while platinum can be obtained by trading with players and you get some at the beginning, most of it comes from real purchases for real cash by real players.  2) The grouping and hosting This one is pretty self-explanatory. Even though the number of mission crashes has significantly reduced with the removal of strict NATs, it's still an issue that can result in wasting a lot of your time and building up enough fury to start biting your table. Example: You spend 40+ minutes surviving in the void with a new reward coming each 5 minutes. All goes well, the drops are nice. Suddenly, everything around you freezes. You are now trapped inside you own private world, empty and lifeless, while your friends are overwhelmed and decide to finish the mission. When they leave, your mission crashes and all the rewards, experience, mods and so on are GONE. NO REFUNDS. And while you can submit a report, nobody will give you back those minutes you spent to earn absolutely nothing.   THE GRAND FINALE  Now while Warframe definitely has its issues, it is first and foremost a free game. And with 260.8+ hours under my belt I would be lying if I said that the game isn't entertaining enough to make me return to it ever so often. And that's why I recommend it, even though the rant above might turn away some of you. I recommend, because you can squeeze a great amount of fun out of this without spending a single penny. There's a reason why the game has such strong playerbase. It is definitely worth at least a try. And if you don't like it, you can always come back later to observe the changes.  TL:DR It's fine. Give it a go. And maybe three more gos after the first one. Seriously, play this.

Ah Warframe. Personally, I can call it as THE best F2P MMORPG in Steam by the mere fact of how so much effort the developers, Digital Extremes, has put into this game. Now before I get all touchy and such, lemme get to the quick pros and cons.  PROS: +F2P that isn't a P2W at all, almost everything can be obtained through effort +Amazing graphics and mostly consistent animations +Gameplay is extremely immersive +Customizability is extreme. Almost every personal detail can be modified to your personal tastes, with the only restriction being the models themselves. +Lore is fascinating, deep, and above all hits us to the personal level +Did I mention it's F2P already? Yes? Well, won't hurt to say it again.  CONS: - The amount of grinding in this game is what puts off many possible players from trying it out. Personally, I love it because of how the grinding in here reminds me of the Monster Hunter franchise. However, also like Monster Hunter, the process of collecting resources is very tedious and at often times unsatisfying. - Graphics overload. Going back to my comment about the Graphics being a PRO, with all the high end graphics comes with an often grievous cost. For lower end computers, like mine, the graphics are consistently a problem that can lead to crashes and, at worst cast scenarios, blue screens. -Repetitiveness. Like Monster Hunter, at certain times, the game can often have a feel of repetitiveness. In many missions and/or situations, fighting the same enemies in the same environments using the same methods can feel a bit boring to an extent. This issue is resolved very quickly. however, with new additions of weapons and the updates that are very frequent.

Pros: Graphics Gameplay A lot of unique playable characters More than 5 tilesets and 4 factions of enemies (Grineer, Corpus, Infested and Orokin)  Cons: A LOT of grinding  9/10 ~ RedPanda {i'll write a proper review as soon as im done grinding}

As far as free games go, this is a fantastic game. This game has a fantastic environment, great gameplay and beautiful look. I like how you're not really 'forced' into buying any cash items at all, almost everything is available in-game through farming. There is fantastic customisations on virtually everything you obtain. The dojo (guild hall) is great, and very fun to decorate (although the interface needs to be improved for that).  I do have some 'pet-peaves' with this game though...  Firstly, I hate how gear-oriented this game is! The mob armor scaling at higher levels is rediculous! I found that even when doing basic map completion (star chart nodes/quests) that my character was extremely squishy against mobs that took little damage from me while 1-shotting me! This mean taking time away to grind out some better weapons and mods just to continue.  Secondly, the reward to effort ratio is completely unfair! I'm doing missions where I'm barely able to survive, struggle for a while, often dying a few times just to come away with 2000 credits and I need like 100k for something. Come on!  Thirdly, dead squads. The game has been out a while, so nobody is doing star chart any more. Unless there's an alart or something, you can forget anyone grouping with you. And no thanks, I don't want to try solo an Interception mission.  Fourth, pressing 'X' and ending up sky high somewhere because there was a trip-wire NOWHERE near you! Everyone who's played Warframe, will know exactly what I'm talking about here lol.  Fifth, having to stand with you shoulders perfectly squared to a locker to open it. OMG this one really bugs me!! I run through maps as fast as I can, and I see lockers, I walk up to them spamming 'X' to open then quickly. Nothing happens, you have to stand 100% perfectly in front of the darn thing JUST to open it, come on!  Lastly, you should rename this game to 'Farmframe' or 'Grindframe'. Sure, every game has RnG etc, but this one takes grinding to a whole other level. I hate grinding in games, it's not fun at all. Who wants to spend hours upon hours just to get a single item, then have to repeat that task another 10 times for the other items you need?! We're not all no-life 100% game time people without a social life or job. I think loots should be more attainable. Not through cash shop, but through improved squads/grouping.  To conclude, despite these so-called 'pet peaves' of mine, this game is fantastic fun! Please don't let me personal opinions put you off this great game! I would still highly recommend it to you.

Okay, so this will be a long review, you ready? Got your popcorn? No? WELL TOO BAD IM STARTING ANYWAY.   So you start out with the Lotus, a lady who tells you to run and use your first ability, in my case, slash and dash, to kill your enemies. Around a minute later, You're given a choice. I believe its MK1 Bo staff or MK1 Skana. I chose skana personally. After killing more enemies, your given another choice. MK1 Kunai, or MK1 i forgot what it is, I chose kunai. Then your given your final choice for the mission, Primary weapon. I believe its MK1 Braton or MK1 Paris. paris being a bow and braton being a machine gun. I chose paris. So, in this game, you can rush through the entire level, do it however fast you want to, or you can stay, get loot, get mods, and really customize to your playstyle. Personally, i like stealth. So i eventually got the warframe Loki, whose abilities are, Decoy, Invisibility, Decoy explosion, and Radial disarm. There are many warframes, a new one being recently introduced, Atlas, who can read minds i believe. Now, to the point, this game is an absolute grindfest. Everone calls it P2W because of high platinuim *The premium currency* prices. Thats to put up a grindwall. They dont want you taking the easy way out.There are people with 3000+ Hours in this game that are barely halfway through getting a prime warframe. So, you may be thinking, 'How duz me get muteeruels fur diss' Thats how you all sound obviously, but you can purchase blueprints in the market for credits, the money earned ingame. Platinuim is used to buy the component itself. Say you wanted a dual skana blueprint or something, you would need X amount of resources, that you get from each planet. Each planet gives its own resources, like earth, has rubedo, and mars, has something else. Anyway, onto the main factions in the game. The five main factions so far are the Grineer, the Corpus, the infected, the Orokin, and the Tenno, you are the tenno, You are the operator, ordis- sorry i got lost there. But you have this dude in your ship named ordis. Every so often he'll say funny things, like 'Oh dear! The operator has come back with an archwing part! You must forge it immediately, Soon you'll be flying through the skies like a *Voice gets much deeper* WINGED DEATH MACHINE'. Anyway back to the factions, The orokin are the more advanced faction.They have these things called death cubes there, that shoot lasers that kill both them and you extremely fast, making it very useful. The grineer are the starters, Fairly easy. Nothing special about them. The corpus hold a lot of loot, and have tougher enemies. Like MOAs, for instance. These are robotic chicken like guys with machine guns. Onto the Infected, A failed lab experiment of the grineer, the infected are now insanely powerful, being leapers, chargers, and ancients. Ancients can grab you and pull you along with them, which is scary stuff. Onto the gamemodes, Ill only be listing 3 to save time, but theres the exterminate, where you kill everything on the ship, the survival, your air supply is cut off and you have to run around and get capsules to stay alive, whilst being shot, and defense, where you defend a certain item/artifact. Actually, theres 2 more I wanted to list, the crossfire, where you board a ship full of fighting grineer and corpus, and kill them all. I dont remember what the last one is called, but you take the side of a faction, like corpus, and they become teammates as you clear out infected or grineer. Thats all for now, updates WILL be coming, this game is still developing, fast, and insanely fun, this game is a Ninja grindfest with a lot to do.

This is a just wonderful game, I've seen no other like it. All the maps are procedurally generated, the rooms are the same, but arranged completely different every time, and the map could be long one play through, and short the next, on top of all that, every planet in the system has its own environment type, so you'll come across many interesting landscapes, and every playthourgh of a mission, there's a chance of there being a different penalty, for example, if there is ice in the level, it will reduce your maximum shields, and sometimes there'll be fire, making the terrain hazardous.. Every piece of equipment, including your warframe, has its own level, and your account does too. There are several different warframes/classes for you to find and build, and one of them is bound to suit your playstyle, not to mention a large arsenal of weapons to choose from, but you must earn the credits to unlock these. Eventually, if you get enough credits, you can buy a Sentinel, a small floating robot that'll hover over your shoulder, and support you any way you have it configured. Also, every piece of equipment has specific mods that will work for it, such as damage types, fire, ice, shock, armor piercing, rate of fire, reload time, and many more,, you can also level every mod up to a certain limit to increase its potential. There is an extensive crafting system, you find certain materisl in each system, and you use these to complete blueprints you've found or bought with credits, in order to create new gear, or even warframes. If you get really good, you can run along walls, and keep jumping to other surfaces, to speed your self up far more than a regular run would. It takes some decent aim to to a good job, and good reflexes, so come on and give this game a try, it is very fun indeed.

Takes forever to get new equipment, but its an overall fun game. The developers are churning out a decent amount of new content on a regular basis, which is nice considering more f2p games dont get as much attention.   Once you get the blueprints needed for new gear, finding materials to craft it can be a bit of a bother. Once you find the materials, you have to wait hours and sometimes days to craft the item you want. Real time. That really kills the momentum of the game when youre forced to wait so long to continue playing with the items you want. Of course, if you can afford the incredibly expensive platinum currency, waiting wont be an issue. They have to make money somehow, right?  The only other negative I can think of is the melee combat. For a game based around it being known as 'Mass Effect Online with Swords', it doesnt have much going for the melee. Attacks can sometimes be difficult to land in rapid succession, and the damage done doesnt warrant using anything besides jumping and charged attacks.  Everything besides that is great. Graphics, sound, controls, everything is appealing and easy to pick up. Definitely one of the best free-to-play games I've ever enjoyed.

The Facts-  Game rating based on the ESRB Single-player and Multi-Player [Online] Platforms: Microsoft Windows and Playstation 4 Developer: Digital Extremes Genre: Third Person Shooter/ Hack n' Slash  ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Plot-  You are a survivor of a alien species known as Tenno, thought to have been extinct long before the games start. You wake up from a pod to find that there is a massive galactic war between two factions; Corpus and Grineer. You fight your war through to survive forging your own path to either fight to unite the surviving Tenno and be the war monger species that kept the universe under control with ancient technology known as Warframes or to fight only for the riches. --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Character Design-  The characters you play are soundless agile ninja that you get almost full customization of. You re guided by a burden navigator known as 'Lotus' She is used to guide you and warn you of oncoming danger in game, however, like all Navi talk through, they are just annoying. Bosses can be exceedingly hard and there is a good amount of enemy variation between the Corpus, Grinneers, and Infested. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Sound & Artwork-  The music is enemy triggered and it is seemly soundless when you're not being hunted down or in fire fights. There is barely any musical style to the game. Sounds are basic with Armor clashing against blade and bullets burrowing through flesh into bone. You can hear a good lot of the damage you inflict. Visually the game is gorgeous, even on the lowest settings the environment and characters always look shockingly great. A thing to note down is the blur effects that can happen when in huge skirmishes. ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Gameplay-  With all the cons of the style of the game this is where it takes my heart. The gameplay is amazing, with a ton of map variation that is not the same a good portion of time, the hack and slash feel mixed with strategic gun play and puzzles. It makes me feel like I am playing Ninja Gaiden with better controls and guns. Fast passed loot fest action and incredible special abilities make for an amazing rush. there are a few bugs right now due to it being in BETA. The customization in Warframe is wide but complex when it comes to upgrading. ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Conclusion-  All in all I'd have to give the game an 8.75/10 Due to all the faults it has. Even with it being in BETA. The replay value however will be 10/10 because if you like it you'll stick with it through the whole thing for awhile. I know I do. --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The new standard in which all Free-to-Play games should strive for. Digital Extremes has raised the bar once again since they first created Unreal Tournament. Warframe is simply pure bliss to play.

In short: This game is fun and you should try it. It satisfies a lot of action itches, and it's always improving. It's not hyperbole to say that either; the devs are constantly updating core systems to work and feel a lot better.  Not as short: You can read a summary of the game from this page or other reviews, but the concerns most folks will have are about it being F2P, and if the game is fun enough to sustain interest. WF's F2P model is summed up as a well-modeled wait-gated, mild resource farming game. Don't be scared off just yet. You can play as much as you want for free. The game doesn't limit you with tokens to play, or waiting to heal yourself. What you wait for are things like crafting times. Resource requirements for most things are pretty mild (3-5 runs of a map should get you most stuff). You can even trade other players for platinum, the game's premium currency.  Game play is a lot of fun, and if you played before and got tired of it, it might be time to try again. The melee system was revamped, missions are much more engaging now rather than mostly fetch quests, story and lore are told much better than it used to be, and the game even has a few end-game elements such as warring factions (not PvP, but rather setting up defenses for invasions). The game focuses well on PvE, even though there are some options for dueling and 2v2 sparring.  If you never played, the game has more than enough to keep you busy (and more importantly, interested). If you left a while ago, you can return now. The game has changed so much that most every system that you thought was lacking is now quite robust. The game isn't done improving yet though, and it's technically labeled a 'beta' still, but the reality is that WF will keep changing and improving, and it looks like it's all going down a good path.

The reason I tried this game is because it's constantly in the top 15 most played steam game list. I was skeptical about its popularity at first, but it was soon dissipated when I started playing.   The basics classes are warframes, each frame has three components you can collect from boss drops at the end of the boss level. It's rather fast to collect these components, no need to buy them from the real money market. In which the frames are quite expensive to buy, there is no real need for that.  Most weapons can be bought with in-game credits from the market, and built with resources gained in game. Again, no need to buy with real money. There are some end game weapons / frames that can be collected from end game content, you can't buy them in the market.  The frames and weapons are augmented with mods, which are dropped in game. They give stat changes, such as increased damage, fire rate, reload speed, health, etc.. Mods can be combined with other mods (such as duplicates to the same mod) to increase their level, which increases their potency and the cost of using the mod. The higher the level of the frame / weapon, the more mods you can augment it with.  The only things worth spending money on are frame and weapon inventory slots, which are quite cheap. Then after that, there is an item that can supercharge a frame / weapon, gives you more space for mods. Which can be obtained in game, but is quite rare. Then there are cosmetics items, which are purely optional. I got about 1800 plantinum for $25, after 20+ weapons and 4 frames, and some cosmetics, I only used up 400 plats.  The missions are randomly generated, at the end of each mission you collect in-game credits, mods, and resources. You can alternate between your primary (rifle, shotgun, sniper), secondary (pistol, throwing knives), or melee (swords, dual swords, heavy). The movement is fluid, you can wall walk, slide, slide jump, slide spin attack, leap attack, etc. It makes you feel fast and like an assassin.   After 70+ hours in game, I'd say this game is ninja with guns/swords in space, a third-person diablo-like item collection game. Although repetitive, when played in co-op, can be quite satisfying mowing down large amount of enemies.

Note: I have only played the game single-player due to my possessing a slow internet.   Imagine being a future ninja in space, and you'll have a pretty rough idea of what Warframe is right there. Warframe is a lovely free to play first person ninja game, in which you travel through a variety (over 200) different missions as you seek to bring balance to a super-future version of our own sol-system. For a free-to-play title in beta, this game feels more complete and well-done than many retail games available at this time.   You can, if careful (the game is not a walk through the park, and success feels like you've truly accomplished something), sneak through an entire level without alerting a single of your varied enemies as you complete objectives assigned to you. Or you could run in with dual revolvers and re-enact scenes of the wild-west on spaceships orbiting Mars. The choice is up to you, and the game certainly accomodates for whatever playstyle you're looking for so long as you're willing to put the effort in.  From the various missions you complete, you can acquire a variety of materials that can be later used to craft new weapons that offer a different feel on the game. After having played the game only with shooty-guns that made lots of noise and sneaking difficult, I acquired a bow that allowed me to move through an entire level without an enemy seeing me, at least until someone saw me sniping his friend and sounding the alarm.  Much to your future detriment, the enemies in this game are not as stupid as in some others. They will sound the alarm at the slightest sign of your presence, alerting anyone nearby (or not, much to my annoyance) to your location. This is actually where I get quite annoyed with the game, as when you've just sneaked through an entire area, assassinating every target along the way without anyone seeing you, I might add, it's very annoying when an entire battalion comes from no-where from what was minutes ago empty (and possibly blood-stained) corridors.  However, it is a fairly easy thing to turn off these alarms, wipe out the remaining enemy, and then continue on your way. And in the spawning of more opponents, there is the ever-present accompaniment of experience to carry you along. However, this does not mean that if you play for ten hours you will immediately wipe the floor of someone just starting. All leveling up does is give you access to an increased limit to the number of 'mods' you can have on any one item.  You get mods from killing enemies, and mods change how your weapons work (only for the better, may I add. No need to balance what you're getting and what you're losing) A major part of this game is figuring out the best combinations for the enemies you will be facing, certain damage types being more effective against enemies with armor than enemies with shields. If you're ever finding it tricky to work out the very best way to format these mods, the game has an auto-fill option for what it thinks is best for your weapons, but mods are mostly for you to make everything to your preferance, so take some time to decide these things.  Besides customizable weapons, there are also a variety of Warframes that vastly change how you play, such as character speed, size, health, and special abilities. You start out playing as the Excalibur model for the tutorial, but at the end you can choose from one of three options. I recommend you think carefully of what you choose, as though you can later on acquire the two you didn't choose, it will take alot of time and effort to do so. As of writing this, I have played over seventy hours of Warframe and still have only the starting Excalibur Warframe. It's good for beginners, but you're not going to be a beginner for long, so I recommend you seriously think about the other two options.  Unfortunately, though understandable now that free-to-play games always have these features, there are micro-transactions in this game. They allow you to purchase Weapons, Warframes, various pieces of Equipment, and Sentinels, who are little guys who fly around and help you out. I have not yet obtained one of these, so I know next to nothing about them.  However, what I like about this game a good deal is the crafting system that lets you make all the weapons available for 'Platinum' and then some that aren't, so you can, with some ease, acquire all the weapons in the game fairly quickly, though you'll be hard-pressed to find a place to put them all as there is an inventory limit that can be expanded through the use of, you guessed it, Platinum i.e real money. You start with fifty platinum, which is enough to get a couple more spaces, but it still irks me that I'm pretty much out of room for more weapons when I've only just gotten the dual revolvers.  Besides all that, there are also clans that you can join, or make yourself fairly easily. What really makes these clans interesting, though, are the Dojos. Each clan gets to have their own space station that they can customize a good deal, from obstacle courses to dueling rings to enhanced crafting rooms for making even more stuff. Making the Dojo recquire you to build a key out of components available from the first level, though if you want to create the more interesting rooms within, like the Oracle or an Obstacle course, you will recquire a very rare item called Forma, that I have yet to acquire.  This game does have a multiplayer co-op, in which you and three others go into the various missions available and try to accomplish whatever the Lotus (Lady who tells you to do stuff) wants you to do. I have not tried it (bad internet), but I can imagine having four super-ninjas running around would be a great deal of fun.  Which brings me to an interesting point about this game. It's not just a run-and-gun or sneaking about holding the Ctrl key to stay out of sight, this game features a great deal of manuevurability that lets you still be shooting or sneaking while using. Wall climbing, wall runs, running slides, jumping up and then sliding to soar through the air (a very cool looking move that can knock enemies over if well-timed) as well as the use of these in combination with melee attacks to finish off your enemies in style.  This system of movement works very well in combat, allowing you to chain a wall run into a leaping stab or diving off a ledge to ground pound a group of enemies Iron Man style (It is very cool, believe me, and a viable tactic for combat). This system also helps out in stealth, quickly diving to another point of cover while an enemy's back is turned or moving through a grate system to get a tactical advantage.  With a large arsenal of rifles, bows, shotguns, pistols, revolvers, kunai, swords, hammers, axes, boomerangs, and a variety of special attacks unique to each Warframe, this game can and will certainly keep you entertained for a long while. And that's just the gameplay.  The game comes along with an interesting story that is told to you by Lotus when she describes your missions for you, from the constant battles fought between Grineer (a race who have cloned themselves so much that they require technological aid to be able to battle) and Corpus (I think they're robots who re-animate dead people to fight, but I'm not sure on that) to discovering that the Earth is being slowly poisoned by the Grineer in an attempt to have compete control over the planet.  And then there's just trying to figure out some info on yourself, the Tenno, a people who slept dormant for a long time before being re-awoken to inhabit the Warframes to bring stability to a system torn apart with war, all without their memory I might add.  I myself still have a great deal of this game to explore and enjoy, and I recommend that if you're at all interested in the above, you give this free game a go. I'm glad I did.

Decently addictive game where you play as a SPACE NINJA, It is free to play but if you want to upgrade your stuff you need to either pay or grind for several hours at a time. That said, the gameplay is pretty good and if you are the type to put hours into online multiplayer shooters, then you likely will not mind the repetetive nature of the game.

Warframe, it turns out, isn't about space ninjas trying to restore balance to the universe. It's actually about an entire race of spacefaring hobos of live in their shopping-cart-sized ships just taking the same odd jobs over and over just to get shiny new stuff to use until they can hock it off to some other poor space hobo.  Hobo Prime/10  But seriously, this game is a lot of fun. It's dynamic and exciting throughout most of the experience. The parkour makes getting around really fun, and the weapons are interesting and satisfying. My only gripes about this game are the build times, how grindy it is, and how there aren't any clear overall objectives. Just about all of those problems can be remedied by playing with a clan/friends. With a group you can set goals on what items you would want and what you're going for. Like any online game, don't go it alone, it gets really boring really fast.

Warframe is a very fun and additctive game that at the time of this review is in beta. This is a MUST try game in my opinion, where the graphics are nice the physics and fighting are extremly fun and who wouldn't love 'space ninjas'. As with all free to plays Warframe has platinum which is the currency that you buy with real money, which you use to buy slots for warframes, weapons, and accessories. Now without platinum you get stuck with only a couple warframes and weapons, with the only way being around this is hoping to get a 50% or 75% (for the best deal of course) and buying platinum or getting into the trading which is confusing and a little annoying at first but after a while you can get used to it. Warframe has quite a few differnt mission types and even has a few quests, some of which unlock warframes. Sadly Warframe in i'ts current state is just about the most grindy game I have ever seen, where you might have to kill a boss many, many, MANY times to get the warframe parts or resource you want from that specific boss. Or you might need to do a certain void mission over and over to get the prime part you're looking for. But in my opinion grinding for a new warframe or weapon and using it is worth all the effort as almost every warframe and weapon have distinct differences and you always feel like you can find something new and interesting in what you're doing in the game (other than when farming of course, I recommend grinding with friends and music and other fun things to distract from the boring drone of grinding). But no matter what you feel like about this game from this review if you havent put at least 5-10 hours into the game you haven't given it a fair chance!

The only downside to this game is that there is no open world or even sandbox type environment to expand immersion within the world. In virtually every other aspect, the game is a dream-like playground for fans of games like mass effect, unreal tournament, or in some ways even Prince of Persia and Ninja Gaiden.   There is wall running handled in a well executed manner, there is melee combat complete with actual combos and timing as well as blocking, there is evil space creatures and factions to kill and hate, and there is a huge array of both weapons and warframes to choose from and collect in order to diversify your experience. Even recently a new system of flight combat was added straight out of a space shooter sim hybrid.   While it is true the game is VERY light on story line or explanation, and can become quite grindy after a deep binge of obsessive exposure, the core systems of the game are bieng constantly improved and there is NO pay 2 win mechanic because anything you can acquire through the shop except for a very few cosmetics are all obtainable in game.   PvP players be warned however, this game is not about PvP, at all, and the PvP aspect of the game is not very well realized or implemented at this point. While PvP is playable, it is certainly not for everyone and is not what the game is focused around at all.

This game has taken the number 2 spot of game I have played the most in my life, which is odd being that it's free to play. Experimented with this game on my friends Xbox and within a few minutes of playing I knew I had to get it on my PC and that was over a year and a half ago and I am still loving it. The game is slightly difficult to get into when you are just starting out but once figure out the ins and outs it is very enjoyable. An amazing amount of customization for your character to play however you want to play and 99% of the game can be done without spending a dime. The lore of the game is still being uncovered by frequent updates and additions, but the basis is you are a futuristic space ninja moving from place to place, battle to battle gunning down enemies with tons of guns and/or slicing or bashing your way through enemies with just as many melee weapons.  The only (possible) downside is how you acquire items in this game. Its a 100% RNG grind by chance. You want that item you better be ready to run that mission over and over. But regardless of that when you do run those missions whether it be solo or with a squad of friends 9/10 times its a great time.

What can I say, it's an awesome F2P game to play, You can work for everything if you so wish to or of course use microtrasactions to buy stuff if you want. Some parts shows that you should play with friends though you don't have to. Also hey you get to play as space ninjas which is always awesome :D So yeah this is a definant recommendation from me for this game as I feel other should play this game or atleast give it a shot to see if you like or not.

Ask whoever you want,and they will tell you this game is grinding. However,Warframe isn't grinding like:'Kill ♥♥♥♥,get gold,buy ♥♥♥♥,kill more ♥♥♥♥'. It's more like:'Hey see this fun and exciting gameplay?You wont believe it,but it's actually grinding!' You will notice that it isn't grinding like MMORPG's where you have to walk endless kilometers and kill millions of enemies,it's the type of grinding that is hidden in all the excitement,action,combat and incredible graphics and gameplay!You won't even notice  it.Why?Because  you will be having too much fun while playing the game!It's not grinding like:'I need to find this,I need to find that!'.Its grinding/playing like:'Alright I won this mission,oh look I got the item i needed!What a surprise!'.Its not gameplay like:'Wow,this is boring,I better buy some stuff with real money.'It's gameplay like:'I'm really enjoying this,luckily this isn't pay2win,gotta go to another mission now!'.   It's not like:'This is bad'. It's like:'I recommend this game'.  I recommend this game,I love the game,and I think you,my dear friend,should try it.

One of the best free to play games I've ever played.  Pay to win game? Hell no. Most of everything in the game can be earned through missions, either it be boss fights, surviving in defense or survival missions for a long time, or going into the void and doing missions.  RANK SYSTEM : You rank up throughout the game, either by doing missions, leveling up your weapons, etc. When you have a higher rank, it allows you to use epic weapons of mass destruction. I'm not kidding. Some of the weapons in the game just destroy everything in it's path with little effort.  WARFRAMES : There are tons of Warframes to gather throughout the game. At the start you get to pick between 3 warframes. EXCALIBER, VOLT, and LOKI. If you like stealth, go with Loki. If you like slicing enemies into little bits of meat, go with Excaliber. If you like frying your enemies with electricity and super human speed, go with Volt.  Other warframes can be gathered through boss fights, void missions, or alerts.  WEAPONS : Tons and tons of weapons to choose from, giving you a different experience everytime. You can switch up weapons easily and change your style anytime you want in your Arsenal.   PRIMARY WEAPONS : You have your rifles, shotguns, grenade launchers, flame throwers, rocket launchers, laser guns that shoot laser cubes and explode on impact with a chain of more explosions, guns that shoot bolts that pin enemies to walls, rifles that shoot lasers that cut through groups of enemies, sniper rifles. etc.  SECONDARY WEAPONS : You have your pistols, hand held rocket launchers, infected pistols that shoot poison and radiate enemies, one handed automatic crossbows, duel magnums, duel machine gun pistols, pistols that can also shoot bolts and pin enemies to walls, duel one handed shotguns, etc.  MELEE WEAPONS : You have quite a selection. Two handed swords, warhammers, giant axes, and maces.  One handed swords, either they can be normal swords, or infected swords, eletric plasma swords, fire swords, or heavy hitting maces, axes, hammers, scythes, ninja stars, a blade weapon that can be thrown that cuts down enemies in it's path and comes back to you like a boomerang, then can be used for close range attacks, etc.  SENTINELS : These little guys are droids that follow you around, there are a few of them, but are worth getting for a little extra help. I apologize that I cannot remember the names lol, but the one I use is like a vaccum. It sucks up all the ammo and loot, even energy orbs and health orbs. It also has a shotgun equipped to it, so if enemies come close they get blasted in the face.  Some sentinels are used for just doing tons of damage, but others are used to make go invisible, stomp the ground making enemies fall on their butt, or suck up everything with a vaccum. I recommend getting the vaccum one if you're a new player, since you'll get so much more loot with little effort.  Sentinels can have mods put into them and can be leveled just like your weapons and warframe. Mods like emergency shields incase you're shields run out, a deflecting shield when you are reviving a teammate it will pop a shield over you to give you a little more time to revive before getting attacked. Also it can have weapon mods added into it. Some only use rifle, or shotgun mods. So if you have some extra mods laying around, you can stick them inside your sentinel.  BOSS FIGHTS : Most of the boss fights are epic, each boss does it's own thing and has it's own way of being defeated. Once you defeat a boss, you'll get some materials and a mod. At the end of the mission is when you get a blueprint. Gather blueprints to create whatever the blueprint was, you'll need to defeat the boss a couple of times because it's random when it comes to getting blueprints. Example : Getting the Rhino warframe, defeat the boss and you get a RHINO SYSTEMS blueprint. You'll need to get the RHINO CHASIS and the RHINO HELMET as well, in order to build the Rhino.   So you'll need to fight the boss more than once if you want all the blueprints for that certain warframe. Sometimes you'll keep getting the same blueprint, but you can sell the extra blueprints for some credits if you're not going to use it.  RANDOM ASSASSINATIONS : Most of the time when you kill a boss you'll get a thing in the mail saying 'You'll pay for what you have done, TENNO'   This means that a assassin will come and try to kill you randomly in a mission. You're screen will start to flicker and that's signals that the assassin is coming for you. If it's flickering but you do no receive a messege saying they are coming for you, that means the assassin is coming for someone else in your group.  These assassins are able to be killed, but won't go down easy if you're a low level. Once they are killed you get a blueprint from them. If it's the STALKER, you get a chance to get either one of his weapons. It can be the DREAD, which is the bow and arrow, HATE which is his melee scythe weapon, and his secondary which I forgot. Most of the time you'll get the Dread bow, I have like 14 of them lol.  There are other assassins which I won't spoil for you lol. But most of the time you'll be hunted by the Stalker, once you start killing high leveled bosses, that's when higher leveled assassins will come for you, and they all do different things and have different styles of fighting.  WHEN an a assassin comes, they only go for their target and no one else unless they get in the way. So play it smart and get some distance so your teammates can pound them into the ground, making it easier to kill them.  DOJO/CLANS : A dojo is where you can design and build your own base. Adding rooms and decorations to each spot and being able to build workshops that create weapons that cannot be purchased in the market with credits. So you'll get access to some really unique weapons. You get to build 3 workshops and they're all different. One is for Grineer weapons, the other is Corpus weapons, and the last is Infected weapons.   This will allow you to research and build weapons that the enemies are using and can use them for yourself. I recommend new players to join other clans/dojos. Because it costs a lot of materials to build your own dojo. Usually other clans have fully built these workshops and have researched everything. If you decide to build your own, that's cool too, but it'll cost a lot of materials and it takes a lot of effort doing it by yourself.  COMMUNITY : The community is cool most of the time. You'll always have high ranked players helping low ranked players with missions or boss fights. I like to go help ranked 2 players, because I can give them mods and other goodies. When you play for a long time, you'll gather so much materials you won't know what to do with it, so it's best to give them to low ranked players, or go to the trading chat to sell. (You'll need to be rank #2 in order to trade in a dojo, and need credits too, because the dojo might have a trading fee)  TRADING SYSTEM : You can trade with other players in a Dojo, by them inviting you to it, or you inviting them. You can trade all sorts of stuff, Void keys, mods, blueprints, etc. It's impossible to be scammed in the game, and everybody usually doesn't try to anyways. I recommend going to the Warframe Wiki and checking out the prices for rare mods, because sometimes you'll have players lie about the platinum price for the item you're trying to sell or buy. Trades go smooth most of the time, I don't want to make you feel uncomfortable about trading, I'm just saying that you should do some research about it before doing so.  UPDATES/EVENTS : These guys update this game almost twice every month, and everytime it's something big, they usually add missions where you can get some sweet weapons or other goodies. Events are awesome too, because you'll get a chance to get all the blueprints for one warframe, or get a sweet looking helmet for your warframe or a weapons.

97/100  + Pretty good controls once you get the hang of them. + Very unique abilities for each frame. + Many strategies are usually viable for every encounter. + Frame balance has improved a bit since my last review. + Good F2P system - everything can be obtained, somehow, for free(minus a few cosmetic things). + Unique, diverse enemies, especially the bosses. + Generous difficulty curve. + Very fast gameplay that adequately punishes for inattentiveness. + Receiving constant updates, frequent events and timely developer responses. + Gmod ragdoll physics. + Story and lore content actually exist now, and it's constantly evolving with every update. + Voiceacting is pretty alright. + The music is great. + Astronomical replayability. + Nifty weapon-modding system that actually does allow for a significant degree of customization.  ~ The Archwing 'space combat sans spacecraft' crap is incredibly disappointing. ~ PvP is b r o k e n. It does exist, though, in case you want to rally some friends and ban the ridiculous weapons. ~ Fairly smart AI... for a multiplayer game. ~ Extremely expensive paid content. ~ Long 'crafting' times for items, but you can 'rush' them for premium currency. ~ Grinding is a mildly significant part of the game. ~ Hosted client-locally, rarely leading to nasty lag. This also means it will hose your connection if you are the host and you have a terrible ISP. ~ Severe Chronic Power Creep is a recurring theme. ~ No official soundtrack available for purchase...  - STILL very buggy. Most bugs don't last too terribly long, but they introduce new ones pretty regularly. - The code that handles the intial connecting to other players is horrible. - Poor weapon balance. - QA basically skips over the text.

For a game that is still nominally in beta, I have had ridiculous amounts of fun in Warframe.  Squad-based 4-player mission instances across many amazing tilesets, with an incredible range of weapons and frames (exoskeletons) to use. Multiple mission types, looting, crafting, mastery ranks, Clan spacestations, Clan conflicts, events, and more.  The dev team is highly connected to the playerbase in a way I haven't seen in other games. Updates are normally weekly, hotfixes are rapid when there's an issue, and let's not forget the devstreams.  Who doesn't want to be a space ninja? Whether you are bending the forces of magnetism, setting the world on fire or teleporting to every enemy in the room and backstabbing them all at once, I hope you enjoy your new addiction.

It's not worth playing 10k Hours.  Lets start with the enemy scaling. (Reminder: Games are designed for Casuals, the mayority of the population)  The enemy scaling in warframe is like this: Depending on the game mode, the enemy level increases. The higher the enemy level gets, the more health, shields and armor he gets AND the more damage he deals. Your character (Warframe) on the other hand doesnt at all scale with the enemy level. you can only level up your warframe till lvl 30, put on some mods. Which means your cap are capped mods. This means, enemies one shot you before they turn into bulletsponges. As a result the options you have to create 'end game viable' Warframe builds are highly limited and offer you a boring and binary play style.  Binary playstyle - the options you have are: a) Invisibility: you get invisible, stay invisible, and slaughter everything. dont get hit - you ll die with one shot. and the accuracy of the enemiese damn. (e.g. Loki's ability 'invisibility' or Focus - Naramon Tree)  b)invincibility: the 2nd viable option. you dont take damage means, you cant get one shotted at all. (Valkyr - hysteria. trinity got nerfed on a wednesday) Well trinity's ability 'Blessing' gave you( before it got nerfed) a up to 99% dmg reduction. 99% dmg reduction was awesome, because you and your team was invincible for a certain amount of time. everything below 99% dmg reduction, e.g. 98% dmg reduction, was utter crap. and dont forget that the enemies' damage scales with their level. which is why it is going to be crap soon.  Non viable playstyles are: 'i m going to catch all the bullets and take damage while my friends kill everything' it doesnt work, you dont do it. in warframe this strategy works like this: you catch 2 bullets and bleed out until someone revives you or you die. you cant even be the 'tank' while you are invincible because the enemies attack everyone.  How do you kill enemies?  there are a few options: a) Ability spamming Warframe is a game, designed around ability spam. abilities save you and some frames are only viable as long as you can keep their abilities active. for example valkyr, limbo (gets redesigned), excalibur, chroma, frost, etc. i probably forgot some. some of those abilities are by far stronger than any weapon ingame. You might think now: 'Why should i use a weapon at all, i can kill everything with abilities!?' and yes you are right you can, and a lot of players do that, just kidding, everyone does that! BUT now we have some enemies which have the 'Despell' ability. again: your warframe is only viable while using its abilities on one hand and on the other hand you have enemies able to despell the abilities you are forced to rely on due to the broken enemy scaling. Something is wrong here.  b) melee weapons (and beeing invisible and/or invincible) you take a melee weapon of your choice and kill all the things while no enemy attacks you because they cant. you know, they cant see you even if they know you are here.  c) buff abilities and a few 'OP' weapons (and beeing invisible and/or invincible) you can buff your warframes, spread spores with saryn, cast sonar/silence as banshee, etc and simply one shot everything as long as possible.  In warframe enemies dont drop health orbs as regular drop at all. the only way to get healthorbs as drops are a) you destroy crates and open lockers, maybe you get some b) Nekros - Desecrate c) Oberon - ultimate d) some other ridiculously stupid ways to get health orbs.  your warframes have ~200 (low level) hp up to ~1400 based on your warframe. only one warframe can have up to 5k+ hit points (even with 5k hp you are going to die with 1 shot after you reached a certain enemylevel) the healthorbs you can find give you 25 or 50 hp back which is nothing and health orbs dont stay they despawn.  In the archwing gamemode healthorbs are a regular drop but it isnt in the regular game mode. why?  What can you do? a) you can play 'balanced' 'PvP' cant tell you much about it, i dont like it which is why i dont play it. my opinion on this topic would be biased  b) Dark Sectors: Some sort of endgame which is currently not available.  c)Lunaros: New fun game - havent played it yet.  d)Archwing: Fly in space and kill things, afaik it gets an onverhaul - again.  e)Regular PvE ('farmframe'): The Mainpart of the game. you farm resources to build things, things you need to level in order to get mastery points, mastery points to increase your mastery level until you have leveled everything and ask yourself the question: 'What next?' in the end you realize that there is no content and if you dont teach new players how to play it gets boring very fast and you hop to the next game until warframe offers more 'content' again. You want the new stuff? farm it! or go to g)  but if you farm mit the game works basically like this. you have common stuff and prime stuff, prime stuff is better than common stuff. for prime stuff you play void missions for common stuff you play the game and void missions. to play void missions you have to have void keys. to get void keys you play common missions or void missions. which means: you play void missions to get credits, prime stuff and void keys.(i ll talk about drop tables after this paragraph) conclusion: you end up playing void void and more void. you dont care about the common missions anymore after a while.  f) 'Chatframe': you use the ingame chat to communicate with people you met ingame.  g) 'tradeframe:' you farm Credits to be able to trade and (re)sell stuff to get platinum(the good currency) in order to buy all the stuff because you hate 'farmframe'   Drop tables: as previously mentioned you can get void keys from void missions. Let me explain it like this: You open your garage with your key and your key gets destroyed, pick up another key somewhere in your garage, get to your car, drive to work, drive home, open the garage again with the key you got in your garage which gets destroyed, you park your car in the garage, pick up a new key for your garage and so on. what i mean is: the game has beautiful tilesets, the level designers do a great job but the only tile set you see is simply the void tileset - nothing else.  endless missions offer different rewards you might get annoyed by: e.g. in a survival mission you get a new random reward every 5 minutes. But those rewards do not feel like a reward after a certain amount of time. for example you get Reward A at the 5 minute mark, you can get reward A again at the 10,25,30,45,50... and so on minute mark AGAIN. what i want to say is: the rewards dont get 'better' or at least the reward system does not feel like it is 'rewarding' you for playing the game.  'We are 5 minutes into this survival it s ok to get a crap reward.... 1 orokin cell... well ok, i figured as much...' *after 65 minutes survival* 'We survived for 65 minutes now! we have to get a good reward!!!... nooo not again 1 Orokin Cell'

More than 600 hours and counting...I feel like I'm ready for a review.  I've been playing this game since 2013, despite my seemingly low amount of hours for a Free-to-Play cooperative third-person hack-and-slash/shooter game that's been out for now 3 years on Steam. Watching this game grow and become what it is now has been a treat and I will continue to track and follow this game for the foreseeable future, but there are some issues I'll warn against with this game.  For new players, this game seems like a godsend. The graphics are beautiful and worthy of any AAA studio, despite many believing this game would fail during its humble beginnings. The gameplay is solid and damn near the best I've ever enjoyed in a video game thanks to its solid and almost freeform flow between gunplay and melee combat coupled with its ever satisfying and enjoyable 'parkour' system. The number of weapons, cosmetics, and playable characters rival even the heaviest hitters of the RPG genre, such as Borderlands. Best of all, damn near everything in the game can be obtained for absolutely free. The greatest part of this game is certainly the fact that this game is still constantly being updated, cared for, and nurtured by its developers and now its own community thanks to the Tennogen system. However, for veterans, this may be the game's greatest flaw.  For veteran players like me and plenty others, its difficult to muster up the passion to play this game after farming for every single thing we want in this game, and then some. For a lot of older players with all the weapons, Warframes, resources, mods, cosmetics, clans, solar rails, and completed quests we could ever want, we don't pick the game back up for sometimes months at a time as we wait for the next big update to add in the new story quest or new Warframe/weapons or new event which interest us enough to hop back on. Then, once we, for the umpteenth time, grind the new piece of equipments' resources then grind for its levels to later slap a 'potato' on to and then play maybe one more survival with it, we just put the game back down and wait again. I find it a bit sad that even I beg the devs for new content I'll acquire and max out within a month or so just to put the game back down for another few months in anticipation of the next new chunks of content.  In short, new players are sure to love this should you be able to push through the grindfest that is Warframe, as you'll soon be grinding without even realizing what you're grinding for. As for veterans of Warframe, try convincing friends to join so you can enjoy helping the Lotus teach them the ways of the Tenno. If all else fails, the game's creative community has some of the best fan art and cosplay I've seen in a while.  P.S. You can buy everything instead of farming for it, but not every single person has the liquidity to drop hundreds of dollars on a free-to-play game. For those who farm by choice, you guys and gals are the true MVPs.

First off let me start by saying, this is a GRIND game, you have to put time and *some* effort in to actually get what you want. If that is not your type of game, warframe will not hook your interest. This game is a very satsifying third person shooter, the characters you play as- Tenno, control sort of like the classes in Mass Effect 3's multiplayer in the way that each has their own varying health, sheild, stamina and power base. Each frame comes equiped with certain powers that can either damage enemies or contain them and negate their ability to do damage. The game is constanly being updated on a weekly basis with new weapons, cosmetics and sometimes new enhancements to the game to make it look pretty. This game offers a sort of, 'Pay now and get this item sooner' mentality. No, this game is not a pay2win, everything in the game besides certain cosmetics, IE Scarfs, statless armor peices and some color palettes can be acquired with just playtime. Helmets can be gained through alerts which popup frequently. If you want to get into this game or just learn more about it, like elemental types or faction specific enemies and what items they drop, then i HIGHLY reccomend heading over to the warframe wiki. Over all, this is a wonderful game and one that i would reccomend to anyone who enjoys shooting, cutting and blowing up some mobs. 9/10

Warframe (and its developers Digital Extremes) shows a love for their fan base that I rarely see from any Free to Play (or even some Subscription based) MMOs. Just as with any MMO, there is always new and interesting content in development; unlike most MMOs I've played though, there is always some focus on fixing even the small, non-gamebreaking bugs that other companies might ignore.  The developers always seem to pay attention to feedback in order to improve, alter, or fix content that doesn't seem to have woo the players as much as they hope.  With the wide variety of Warframes, weapons, mods, and followers no two players are likely to have identical playstyles. Add to that the ability to customize the colors on your equipment and you feel a large degree of control over your gaming experience.  I myself have sunk hundreds of hours into playing this game and still find myself coming back for more whenever I can.

Very little I can say about this game will really do it justice. The seemingly insurmountable content still leaves me bewildered even after all of the progress I've made. I've invested quite a lot of time into this game, however if you compare this number to veteren players I would still be considered more of an amateur than my peers. This is ultimately meaningless however as there are all manner of players ranging from hardcore to casual and anything in between.   I've seemingly managed to power through a lot of content that most have taken double the time to complete however I have had help most of the way. This is where the game shines through the most in my opinion. Playing with friends is a very rewarding experience as most of the time you'll find yourselves working towards the same objectives whether it's gaining that new and shiny gear or simply experiencing the latest update and all it has to bring. The sense of camaraderie with both friends and even random players as you work towards your goals is something I feel every time I venture in, despite how well versed with this game I've already become. That is of course not to say that the game doesn't hold up as a solo experience, but I'd highly recommend bringing a long a friend or two... or three. The community in this game is worth commending both for their general friendliness and tolerance as well as their contributions to the game. Many of the game's features are derived directly from the imagination of the playerbase such as the famous 'Clem' figure.  The game however, is not without its flaws as minor as they may be. Currently the game is still technically in its beta phase despite its large size and you will no doubt come across a number of glitches and issues. Almost every time however, these have provided chuckles and good memories and some extreme examples will go down in Warframe history forever. Another problem I find is that although the game is free to play, if you in any way want to progress you will most likely have to fork over some cash in order to gain the game's virtual currency used to buy equipment space and other such things associated with 'premium currencies'. This is circumvented through the use of the trading system however not only is this a much more tedious way of gaining currency, it still doesn't make up for the fact that at some point someone would have had to have bought currency to trade with in the first place.  Despite its flaws, and I must reiterate that they are indeed minor, this game is absolutely incredible through both the scope of content available and the sheer enjoyment it provides. Never have I encountered a Free-To-Play title with such quality, comparable to a AAA title. This game has given more to me than most ever will and I'll never forget the experiences that I've gotten and will continue to gain. The developers are constantly working to add more and more to this game and I'm positive it will continue its success for a long time.

Back in its early days, I felt like Warframe was a dry experience. The first hour was pretty good but it lost its novelty as you played on. It felt like a grind. I believe the developers have improved upon that.   The story is a lot more engaging with cutscenes and progression. Also, the AI has been improved so you can now be stealthy rather than be caught a kilometer away while crouching. Lastly, the movement controls are a lot more fluid; running around looks a lot more natural (plus running and crouching doesn't give you that speed boost anymore).  In terms of meta-gameplay (ie. salvaging money, metals, items etc.) it's still pretty much the same. To progress in the story, you need to scavenge materials to meet blueprints which build items you can use. This makes it grindy which I dislike. If you can get past the stunning graphics of this game, you will see that it is a grind fest. Don't get me wrong, though; it's good fun!  7/10 - Good

Wow, well, where to start? Warframe is just brilliant! The best free to play game on steam(not counting TF2, because that was paid at one point)! The concept itself is just so tempting, you're a space ninja who beats up robots, ugly guys and sometimes space zombies! The graphics and art style fit the game perfectly. It has a great combat system, large selection of weapons and a vast amount of mods you can apply to make your weapon suit whatever roll you need. And each warframe has it's own abilities, and they are awesome! They range from distractions, teleporting, freezing, poisoning, creating black holes, clearing a room in a single stomp or even punching your enemies very soul out of their body! Theres just too much to talk about at once, it'd make your head spin. Great and helpful community and an awesome Dev team who just work on this game because they love to! The only money they get really is from people who pay for in-game currency, platinum. This is where most F2P games fail. Free to play but Pay to Win! This is not the case, everything you see can be obtained without pumping any money at all into your warframe account. Want a new gun? Buy a blueprint and get the resources! most of the time it isnt even that hard to grind for them. Tho warframes can take wuite a long time to obtain without money, it's so much more fun and rewarding doing it manually. What can't be bought from blueprints are available via random events. Seriously, if you havn't played this game. Just go, get this, now! It's badass! It's fun! IT'S FREE! You have nothing to loose except countless hours :P

This game honestly wasn't what I epected when I started playing. I figured, 'Oh an action MMO, so we're looking at a massive world full of people all doing random quests only with guns'. Wrong. The world is divided into small maps that you play with teams and completing each map unlocks the next. The combat is fast, requiring you to go back and forth between shooting things to slicing them up with melee attacks. The sheer depth of customization options you have is astounding, and the way that skills are handled is a nice addition. The graphics themselves are nice, and players can drop in to a map in the middle of play so you may start a map with only you and another player but end it with 4-5 people. There is an element of grind present, as to manufacture gear once you have the blueprints you need materials for which you'll either have to pay Platinum (the real-monet currency) or play maps over a few times to get what you need from enemy drops (easier to do on Survival levels). Also, leveling up yourself is a seperate things from leveling weapons and frames, and ranking up as a player requires completing 'challenges' which you need to wait 24 hours to try again if you fail.  I have a few problems with the game; First, you're kind of thrown to the wolves when it comes to initialy setting up your character, but the Wiki helps. Secondly, I feel that, while the graphics are wonderful and the visuals themselves nicely done, the bio-mechanical look of the game could have been done better. That's not to say that it looks like crap, just that the disproportionate bodies of the enemies can look out of place compared to the avatars of the you and the other players. Sometimes the game won't remember the mods I've added to weapons/frames after I exit that menu, but that might be something I'm doing wrong and not the game itself  You're best option, if you try the game and enjoy it, is to buy the $40 starter pack. You'll seriously need the in-game and real money currencies as well as the other bonuses to help get yourself started, otherwise you're stuck with the most basic of basic gear for quite a long time.

This review is split into sections, using numerals to show each section.  My rating:  All in all I would rate it an 8/10. Would recommend if you can deal with a decent amount of grinding and some bugs. Also this game is still in BETA!  I The game modes are: Exterminate (eliminate all enemies), Mobile Defense (taking a DataMass to a Control Panel, then defending it), Defense (defending something for 5 waves at a time), Survival (survive a mass onslaught of enemies for as long as possible, rewards every 10 minutes), Excavate (defend and keep a scanner and its excavators powered to extract resources, Interception (you Capture and Defend several points from being taken over by enemies), Sabotage (Destroy a Reactor), Assassinate (all boss missions, and to kill high valued targets), and Hijack (defend a mobile target and possibly destroy it). The game is 100% Co-Op, unless you go to the PVP (Player Versus Player) areas. Graphics are good. Gameplay is very grindy, sometimes buggy, and very well balanced. Bugs well crap…  II The game is grind worthy, grinding through many missions to progress is slightly boring. But considering that each mission is never the same, in the sense that they will always look different from the last time you played it. All weapons can be OP if you mod then properly, and you obtain mods from trading other players, rewards from missions, or by defeating enemies. There are Warframes, which is basically your suit with magical powers that are very destructive against enemies. There are 300ish missions and more than 10 different planets/moons with 10 or more missions each, with their matching environmental art styles. Each Warframe has their own special four abilities unique to that Warframe. Warframes’ abilities range from being able to turn invisible, to being able to stomp the ground and suspend all the enemies in the air, to shooting spikes into every enemy within your sights. The weapons in game can range from a Jet Power Hammer, to a Pistol that shoots rockets, to a gun that shoots circular blades or bolts. The lore is very simple, and easy to remember. There are three main factions, the Grineer that are a bunch of brain washed clones, the Corpus that probably are like humans, and the infested that are infested creatures of doom. There is an enemy called the Stalker that rarely shows up if a boss curses you, and then there are the G3 and Zanuka that do the same thing. You have these syndicates that are 6 different groups, you sign up with one and then you trade this thing called standing for a mod that boosts your Warframe’s abilities, or a weapon, or something else. The basic 300 missions, are the normal missions, then there are Void missions and derelict missions. Void missions come in 4 Tiers, each increasing Tier number indicates increasing difficulty. There is a void boss called Corrupted Vor, he comes around just as rarely as the Stalker does, but only in the void. Derelict are basically the Tier 3 and 4 but only with infested enemies. Also customization of your Warframe/weapons is pretty good, you can change every color to whatever you want, and same for additional cosmetics. Credits are the basic currency in the game, Orokin Ducats are prime pieces (rewards from void missions) traded for special currency to be traded for Primed mods/cosmetics, and the premium currency platinum. Platinum can be earned by the login rewards, by trading rare mods/prime components, or by purchasing them.   Archwing I have not done too much of this yet, as such I am unable to give 100% valid information. AFAIK (As Far As I Know), you have a jetpack and fly through space and continue your basic objectives, and you can go fast just like Sonic the Hedgehog. This is mainly unfinished structure added into the game, there have been several alerts in game using this game type; but it remains with little content.  III Alerts One of the best ways of acquiring rare mods/items is through daily/special alerts. There are daily alerts that often reward with only credits or a few resources, but sometimes they have a rare mod or weapon as a reward, sometimes rare resources. Normally a weapon or some high cost item would be reward from a Tactical Alert, rarely some type of cosmetic items. Tactical Alerts are long and tedious alerts that last a week or so, in which the player needs to complete a very hard challenge in order to obtain said item(s). The Tactical Alerts are mainly for experienced players, who are looking for challenge.  IV Raids Raids are very hard (in my opinion much more difficult than Tactical Alerts), they offer a rare arcane item, and require a massive amount of teamwork. There currently is only one raid in the game, it has several team based puzzles/challenges, which works well with 8 player squads. In the end you face off a very easy to kill boss, as long as you don’t die.  My rating:  All in all I would rate it an 8/10. Would recommend if you can deal with much grinding/some bugs/ absolute nonsense.

Pros - Awesome graphics  - Unique factions - The warframes play very diffrently from eachother - Lore is amazing if you research it - Awesome weapon designs  Cons - Very grindheavy - Lack of quest and in-game storyline - Very shallow in-game lore - Cosmetics are VERY expensive - Weapons are either completely useless or the most powerfull thing in the known universe - The Lotus can be a real **** sometimes - Say goodby to your current beliefs because you have to accept RNGuses as your new lord and savior

Surprisingly good game with co-op. Sort of like the Mass Effect 3 multiplayer, but good, and with free-running space ninjas. There is almost no PvP in this game, which is wonderful for all of us sick of wonderful PvE games being ruined by devs focusing solely on PvP, but if you're too much of a spastic little gremlin to play cooperatively with other people you're not going to like it very much.  As someone who's dumped a lot of time into this game already, I should point out two things going in: it takes about 10-20 hours before you'll get the hang of all of the craziness (so read up on the wiki), and it *is* primarily designed to be a cooperative game (so find a group to play with, because it'll go much faster and be more reliable than playing with players from matchmaking).

All of this is very nice, but in the games current state it lacks variety in enemy an missions, an the lore, which seems very nice, is given to you very lightly, leaving the best part of the game obfuscated. overall this is a nice game to play whenever you have free time however the game itself is extremely tedious and occasionlly boring whenever you try to play alone. If you do want to pick this game up I advise that you play with a friend so that it will be more entertaining. otherwise here are the games pros and cons.  pros: -nice diversity in characters & weapons to choose from and use   - graphics are nice to look at (especially at max settings)   - blood and gore is always a plus  - can use in-game currency to buy warframes(characters) and weapons  - you never feel like the game is pay to win  cons: - in order to obtain new warframes and weapons in-game without buying them you have to buy the blueprints, obtain  all of the materials to craft said item via the games crafting system and crafting times are fairly long ranging anywhere  from 12-70 hours in real time also you have to do all of this with in-game currency.   - level designs are incredibly repetative as you will see the same level designs several times over the course of your  playthrough.  - two leveling systems profile leveling (Mastery)/character&weapon leveling. yes in order for your weapons and characters to be at max power you have to level them up first also leveling your profile takes a huge amount of time.  - certain weapons are mastery locked so in order to craft or even buy them you first have to level up your profile to the required level.  - game can feel like a huge grind especially when playing alone.
