Warframe is a game that some close friends recommended to me to try out. It's free so I thought 'why not?' I was greeted with a rather hectic and somewhat all over the place tutorial. There was a recent update as of writing this that apparently changed the tutorial for new players and even though I have not seen it, I have good faith the game devs put all the feedback and advice they got in order to change it for the better. The game is a 3rd person shooter, which for me is a real eye catcher. In today's gaming world, most games that want to involve shooting almost all go for the obvious first person perspective. Warframe changes that and I will say that at first it feels a bit awkward to play, over time you get used to it and after a few setting changes, you are ready to go. Now the controls and control mappings are a bit awkward, I have mapped out all the buttons that I need to keys that are somewhat easy and more comfortable for me to reach. It still feels a bit awkward though but I don't have one of those super uber gaming mice that have 10 buttons on it so I can't really blame the game for that. The graphics are alright, I don't really like to judge a game by graphics alone, but although not the best... It's decent. The whole going to different planets and different missions, as well as the ability to play with other players/friends or by yourself is pretty neat. The missions however, are not too exciting. There is several mission types: kill all enemies, collect the maguffin, capture and hold the points, survive waves of enemies till you die or leave, kill boss dude... It's all great... but all the planets have the same types of missions just with different enemies and evironments. It get's a little stale after a while, which can effect the replay value. Speaking of, the replay value is pretty great. You can customize your character, make new characters, new weapons. Its all there, but its a little weak due to having some items (most cosmetic though) cost real money. Making new weapons and blueprints for different characters requires farming and grinding which can turn alot of people off. This 3rd person shooter/rpg mixture has alot of potential, but it is boged down with somewhat over complicated mechanics and tedious farming. Final thoughts... It's not a perfect game, not by a long shot. However, I would not say its a bad game. It's free right now so give it a shot, if you don't like it... then that's fine. If you like it... Then awesome! This game is certainly something that will take most gamers out of their comfort zones, and I appreciate Warframe for doing that.

Space ninjas. Space baddies. Space farming. Best farming simulator 2016. 11/10 Would farm again.  In all seriousness though. Warframe is a third person co-op shooter. You play as the Tenno, who seek the protect the balance. As I got into this game, it was confusing. Unless you check the wiki 24/7, which I did because I'm a nerd that way, you won't understand anything. However, once you get the hold of the mechanics, the game is really fun.  However, the grinding and the cruel RNG does make this game feel repetitive time after time. When you do get burned out, just do something else. Come back in a few months and even weeks and I garuntee you that something new has been added/changed.  Pros:  -Beautiful Graphics -Fluid Motion -F2P completely. Everything is unlockable except for event items (which could have been done for free) and cosmetics -A Dev (Digital Extremes) that actively updates and cares about this game -Just fun  Cons:  -Repetitive at times -Confusing to the new player -And yes, DE is human, so they do make mistakes. These mistakes are usually temporary and will be fixed almost immediately.   Overall, this game is fun and just pure awesome. Like any game, it does have it's cons but the pros heavily cover them up. I recommend you pick it up and give it a go. Remember, check the wiki. :3

I first found this game while just looking for a free game to play on my PS4, and I was completely unable to understand any of it or operate the controls properly. So I left it for a month, only to return on my crappy desktop. I played for three months and got addicted to it, but then took an 8 month break because that computer gave out. Now I have my new laptop, and I can't stop playing. All I do anymore is eat, sleep, work, and play Warframe. I only have three frames so far, and one Kubrow. That's about it. I spend all my time in the game doing pointless things to help out newbies. I know what it's like to not understand the game when you first start, so I want to be able to guide some of them into the fantastic world of the Tenno. If it was possible, I would give this game a 100/10, because it is the pinnacle of gaming, and is also free. The graphics are amazing, the maps are large, missions are never the same length, and there are so many possibilities that can come about. I love this game more than any game I have ever played, and am thankful to DE for continuing to add features to it. I recommend this game to literally everyone who likes video games everywhere.

For a free to play game, this is actually hella good, and it sure explains why it has millions of players.  Pros:  -Fast paced, very smooth gameplay -Runs on potatoes -Huge customization options  -Lots of mods to obtain -Hundreds of weapons to use -Many Frames to be collected -Frequent updates, hotfixes, events, and new content -Sweet graphics -Unique sounds, not all guns and weapons sound the same -Literally the best community I've ever seen -Almost everything can be collected without using real life cash -Can trade real cash currency (Platinum) for ingame gear and components  Cons: -Tutorial is quite inefficient -Some weapons a lot superior to others -Warfarm; lots of farming and grind -Can be laggy; peer to peer connection -Beginning can be slow -Hard to rank up -Beginning enemies can get repetitive -Difficulty can spike; times can get really easy, or really tough -Some Frames are needed for specific missions  Overall it's a fantastic game, and it's a must play in my opinion.

Warframe is a large, multiplayer game in which the player, known as the Tenno, control their warframes to complete missions and tasks, with an overarching goal of restoring order to the system, Taking place over all the planets in the solar system, plus some extra terrestrial bodies such as Ceres and Europa.  The basics of gameplay are fairly easy to understand, where in a very basic level could be played out similar to other shooters. However the Warframe has much greater capabilities, with alot of mobility at their disposal and frame-exclusive abilities which can turn the tide of battle, offering a more skilled level of play in working for synergy between weapons, abilities and mobility options available. This can provide even greater strength with others, as each mission can be completed in a squad of up to four players, which extends to eight for the Trials of the systems, the end-game content so to speak.  The initial arsenal which the Tenno has access to is limited, but different weapons are made ready for construction as you experience the game, with the increase of the Tenno's Mastery Rank (MR). MR is essentially a measurement for how much of the game a certain Tenno has experienced, in which a Tenno of rank 3 has not experienced nearly as much of the game of a Tenno of rank 12, for example. Increasing your MR also unlocks the avaliability of some sections of the game's content, such as weapons, quests and certain areas.  Missions are easy to get into and intially can have significant variance, such as defense, interception and capture missions, and after a short while of gameplay the Tenno can also complete a quest to obtain an Archwing, which can provide a fresh task to undertake.  Community is also rather nice, with many members willing to aid others and there is the ability to join a clan within the game to interact with a smaller community within.  However, the Single biggest flaw for the game is repetition and grinding. Many parts of the game can require grinding for specific materials and blueprints, which often results in returning to missions multiple times, and weapons and warframes require useage in order to gain levels, which adds to this grind. For a player who doesnt mind a grind, this isnt much of a big issue, but many players, myself included, do not enjoy the huge amount of grinding required.  Warframe IS a fun game, and also holds lore which at times can play a significant impact into the game, But the grind which it holds is a significant deterrent for many players in the long run. despite this, I find myself returning time and time again to play, with the updates adding more content to indulge in. It is not a game for everyone in the long run, but by heck it at the very least can provide at least 10 hours of fun for most people.  Plus the game is free. Because it helps bring in players :3

Highly recommend. Admittedly, this game is far more fun if you have 3 other friends to play with, but not necessary. I've sank quite a few hours into this game, as every update brings new warframes, and just as you think you're getting out of the game, a new title update comes and I fall back into the game. I'd personally love to see a more fleshed out story (there really isn't any story right now.) If you want to compare this to another game, think of it as Mass Effect 3's multiplayer. That's basically what it is, with far more specifics such as mods, weapons, orokin artifacts, void missions, and much, much more.

The game is quite good, however you will be grinding through every mission to collect credits, materials even the blueprints which give a challenge. However this game have a lot of grinding to do like leveling your weapons and frame to rank up and collecting materials by doing the same mission by farming, and other stuff like it. And you have to wait a certain hour to finish a weapon or frame.  The pro is that there is a lot of missions and weapons for you to play with and the best part is the frames where each frame have a different ability to suit your way of playing wether you want to be stealthy or run and gun or even melee every enemy in the game. There is missions where you can get exclusive weapons such as event or alert missions where you can get helmet blueprints or extra credits. You can also have a clan in the game and build a dojo where you can do pvp or make powerful weapons that can only be crafted at the dojo  Now the con is that you are given a really small slot and some platinum which platinum can only be obtained with REAL money where platinum can be used to instantly finish a building progress or buy weapons without having to get the materials (not the prime weapons though) and you must think well before spending your platinum or you will get a problem later on. And one of my problem is the potato's (you will know after playing it) is where it doubles the points for your weapon BUT without a doubt its hard to get the 'potato' as sometime they appear in alert mission while you are asleep or at work. And not to mention the enemies gets harder overtime and the fact that there are different type of enemies which force you to use a different weapon on each faction to get the best results.  In conclusion the game itself represents a great 3rd person mmo where you play as a space ninja but need a lot of grinding which is perfect for people who likes grinding or rpg games. However if you are impatient and a singleplayer player, i would not recommend this for you because in some mission its nearly impossible/hard to solo as this game requires great teamwork and patience since you wont get anything instantly in this game.

Warframe is the kind of game which you start to love the moment you forge your first weapon. Like a sort of gamble, you try to gather materials to craft every weapon out there for your own personal space ninja colection. Huge downside represents the fact that even if you craft or buy every weapon out there, you have no real reason to switch from a handfull of weapons that currently wipe the floor with everything else out there.   Additionally, the game's lack of endgame reminds me of Diablo 3, where you had no real reason to keep playing, other than farming new items and boasting them on a chat with the rest of your friends.  Warframe has a huge potential, however the lack of quick and efficient adaptation is beggining to seem like a big risk in a domain such as the Gaming world, where somebody else may catch up and do a better job at giving the public what they demand.  Overall, the game gives a nice feeling to the casual player where nothing can stand in your way, not even gravity.

Warframe is a tactical third person shooter set in a vast and continually expanding universe that is very interesting if you look into it's lore. The game is set on your character, an old tenno warrior who is in an massive suit of armour called a warframe. A warframe is a suit of armour that was placed onto a tenno when they are initaited, and has 4 special abilities and a wide array of advantages such as better shields or armour. You, a lone tenno, was put into cyro-sleep after a great war beetween the sentients and the (as i call them) the orokin people. You wake up centuries later to a unverse filled with corruption, greed and violence and it is up to you and your fellow tenno to restore peace once more to the solar system.  Gameplay wise, the game is built around you doing acrobatics and maneuvers to outsmart your enemies, such as running across a wall to reach an enemy with your shotgun. As you progress through the game you'll find things called 'mods'. These mods are used to augment your warframe and weapons to certain advantages. One example of this is to give a rocket launcher a faster fire rate, or a shotgun more accuracy. Whilst the mods do little to improve your items when you first get them, you can upgrade them with fusion cores or with other duplicates of mods. You can say get a damage mod from the basic %20 increase to a phenominal %200 increase on the max rank. This system works beutifully and works well with the whole concept of you being your own unique character.  The classes in his game are set in what type of warframe you have. There are over 20 warframes currently in the game (the most recent being mesa) and with each one comes a different experience. Your warframe is unique with the abilities and attributes it has. One example is the warframe 'rhino' a beast of a warframe that has high armour, shields and health and a powerful array of abilites that revolve around either taking or dealing damage. Each of your warframes comes with 4 revive tokens which replenish every day to the maximun of 4. This is very useful as solo players will find killing enemies difficult on higher levels.  Apart from your warframe, you will have access to a wide array of primary, secondry and melee weapons. Each catagory has a subclass, which include handcannons, staffs, longswords, rifles and many more. Some of these sub-clasess require different types of mods, such as a well modded rifle set will not work on a shotgun as they are two different weapons types. Same as your warframe you can mod your weapons with a wide array of mods that include increasing damage, to mods that inflict elemental damage or 'status effects'.  There is alot of things that i can talk about but there is just too much to fit in a review. This game is FREE and does not force you to pay and it is fairly easy to farm for resouces and build that all important weapon you've been wanting. This feels satisfying and well achieved and one of the many reasons why a have played warframe for over a year (yes i realise it says i have less than an hour of gametime but i have over 1000 hours on the browser version of the game).  i give this game a 4.5/5 a very well earned score, keep up the great work D.E :D

This game is only fun if you are rich. Although it is 'free to play', the action gameplay will become repetitive when you only have the same guns and warframe. To get a new warframe you'll need to spend several days grinding for both material and credits to get the blueprint for what you want to make. Then you'll have to go online to the wikia and find out where to get the ingredients to make the warframe you want. After than grind for the materials to make each piece of the warframe. Once all that is done you can finally craft it, but then you'll need to wait around 72 hours (3 days) for it to be finished crafting and then you can use it. Ofcourse fans of the game say 'go do something else for 72 hours.' 'go get some fresh air'. Well maybe I dont want to get fresh air. I want to play a game for hours and hours. When I put effort into grinding I espect my item to be done not wait 3 days after i've done everything to gather the materials for it. The action gameplay, wall jumping, running, sliding, is great. However the instances, setting, maps are so enclosed and tiny that the wallrunning stuff doesnt really shine. The stealth action in the game isn't fun either. You have to get a certain item to be able to see enemies. If you dont have it, you will have to see enemies by eyes. Sometimes the game will spawn you in front of an enemy when you start your mission thinking 'ill do it stealth'. And as much as you will try to play like a ninja, if you end up in a room and 1 enemy spots you, even though you take that enemy out pretty much all enemies in the surrounding rooms will rush in and destroy you. The tutorials and guides teach you very little about the controls. It teaches nothing about upgrading or forging. There is no way to tell you what mission you should do next. You pretty much have to look at every planet to find your next mission. The game might seem like its free to play, but it will eventually wither away at your mind until you cough up that extra cash for some items. Any fan of the game will tell you that the game shines through its multiple various weapons and warframes with unique abilities, but unless you got an endless bank account or extreme patience this game will not be fun for you. They make everything so incredibly hard to get with no sense of progression that it will force you to open up your wallets or simply uninstall the game. The action gameplay really is just you running and sliding along the ground just because the slide goes faster than the sprint. You'll most likely rarely wallrun, or even take cover. Most missions wont require any thought or strategy, just sprint through them to the goal. Unless it is a defense mission you dont have to kill any of them, but remember the enemy will not forget about you and most likely chase you and horde up until you reach the extraction points. This game doesnt listen to it's community. It only tries to emulate other games rather than being it's own. They care about your wallets rather than the player. I doubt they even spent much time developing it as it seems to just be a simple copy and paste missions disguised by fancy lighting, blooms, and motion blurs. Fans of this game would argue that even though the story and missions are tedious and repetitive and that the fun is from the 'action', remember all of them most likely paid for the items and warframes. If you see them have alot of nice weapons and they tell you they crafted them all, then they are rich in time or they are lying. Youll never experience the 10% of actiony fun that people play this game for unless you have a fat wallet.

I hate Destiny, and most first person shooters as well unless they have unfathomable depth (eg a great story, RPG backbone, etc), and I wrote Warframe off for years until I read an article about how Warframe was a game changer in the free 2 play industry, which prompted me to take another look.  I'm not sure what it is about Destiny, but it just seemed gimmicky and unappealing overall, though I do like the art design quite a bit, but as soon as I loaded up Warframe for the first time (on my PS4), it sank it's Valkyr claws into my soul.  The lore is deep and mysterious, the gameplay is fast and frenetic, and mastering the in-game systems including the wide variety of 'classes' (ie Warframes, of which there are currently 42, what other game has 42 classes to choose from?!) is just endlessly entertaining.   The design elements (from the game mechanics, to the menus, to the sci-fantasy aesthetics) are just super appealing to me, and I like how the game offers little explanation for anything, requiring the player to dig in an investigate if they want to know what's going on. It reminds me more than a little bit of the mystique generated by Dark Souls, my favourite series of all time.  Unlike most f2p games, nearly all of the content is farmable without buying 'Platinum', the in game currency, plus there is a robust WTB market where you can trade rare drops for Platinum, so you could in theory never drop a dime on this game. Personally, I like the grind so far, maybe I'll eat my words end-game, but man, this game really is top notch in every way :D

Apart from TF2, Warframe is easily the most polished, entertaining free-to-play game on Steam. This game is extremely addicting and succeeds where many other games have failed. It outdoes Brink in incorporating usable, parkour-like mobility into a shooter. It outdoes Planetside 2 in making it feasible for the player to learn game mechanics from experimentation. It outdoes most other F2P games in that it allows the player to become powerful without needing to use purchased currency. Above all, the game's concepts are unique enough not to be hackneyed, and practical enough to make for a fun, sustainable game.
Space ninjas are cool

Warframe is a game that takes a little bit to get into. From confusing damage types to an also confusing crafting system, it can all seem a little daunting, or discourage a person from playing the game. The thing that upsets me most is that color palettes are locked behind a paywall and the only color palette that comes with the game for free doesn't even include all of the colors in its scheme. Luckily, you are given enough Platinum to buy at least one color palette to make your Warframe look halfway decent.   Platinum is the in-game currency that is used to rush or buy hard to obtain items. But Platinum can only be obtained with real money. A lot of things in game can be grinded out and farmed for. Such as other Warframes, weapons, mods, and companions. It can take a very long time though and rushing or out-right buying things with Platinum is often encouraged. Yes, it is a Free-To-Play game, but like all of the others it will want your money to get into the good features.  There is a lot of content in Warframe. You'll always have something to do, from leveling up weapons and warframes, completing missions and quest, or trading in the chat, you'll easily be able to keep busy.   One other problem that I have with this game is that a lot of the missions and locations are the exact same. They'll often cut off certain parts of the map and have you do a mission that takes place there, but in another mission it's highly likely that you'll end up running through that same area again. But at least there are a lot of different objectives to do on each planet.  Warframe also runs very good. I've had no issues with this game and it is graphically pleasing to the eye. Though the enemies are kind of weird. (Seems like a space take on Alice In Wonderland creatures) It feels solid to play and the controls will have you feeling like a badass in no time.  Ultimately I would recommend Warframe to anyone who has the patience to figure it out. It has a great and very active community so you'll always have people to play with. And the community is quite upbeat and willing to help out. At least give it a try. I mean.....It is free...

Edit 2016 - 400+hours. This game continues to evolve as with any MMO looking to keep its players. With so many new additions both in core gameplay, tilesets and player content. Since its free i'd recommend simply installing it and giving it a go.  Here's a few things that have been added over the last couple of years. - various environmental tilesets with related mission mutators. - improved pvp modes seperate to pve, including a sport akin to gaelic football. - starmap and mission selection has been revamped again and again. - weapon content,number of playable suits 'classess', enemy diversification and ai has increased considerably. - outerspace and underwater missions - quests seperated from standard missions - events - new tutorial and mission introduction gamplay. - totally free to play - although throwing cash at the shop for ingame currency may improve quality of life and reduce the grind against rng related rewards.   Edit:2015 u.17; a lot of things have changed since i made the initial review 2 years ago. Once i've invested a few more hours i'll update as appropriate.  Original 2013 review ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 90+ Hours and still playing!  For a free to play game, this ain't a bad one. 3rd person melee/shooter with upto 3 other players work together to achieve various different missions against one of 4 different ai factions with common but reandomly generated maps.  Good fun, light hearted and fully achievable without spending any £££'s.   Ups: variance of skills abilites and weapons, everything lvls with use, starting weak and getting more powerful.  No need to pay $, the free experience is complete. Constant updates and tweaks by devs Good community PVE orientated gamplay. Smooth gameplay  Downs: are the repeative nature of the game, need for grinding to aquire resources and delay in matchmaking for unpopular missions. PVP limited to clan only training.

TLDR; Warframe is awesome. Try it, it's free. Don't like it? Fair enough, but you lose nothing by trying.  So, I have played Warframe for quite some time, on and off for about 4 or so years now.  Since it was announced I supported it, and now as I write this review I have realized that I never regretted it.  I have not played Warframe as much as some, but it has had an impact on what I expect out of many other games.  I can't recommend a free to play game more than I recommend Warframe. It's just fun.  Dynasty Warriors meets Star Wars: Jedi Outcast and had a threesome with Devil May Cry while going to class with an attractive art direction to learn and secretly have an affair with all of these (developing) story points.  Really, if you like action games, try it, it's free. If you like Devil May Cry, do yourself a favor and make this party crazy! Try Warframe. If you enjoyed Jedi Outcasts interesting combination of lightsaber and gun play and third person gameplay, Warframe feels very much like a game I'd been missing. Do you like being a man blender of blood and gore as you spiral through hordes of enemies that peel apart under the force of your advance like wet cardboard to a well forged blade, until you meet the inevitable leader of the cardboard men's group and have a real fight for a while before inevitably coming out as the better, and run off with all the spoils of the battle and victory in your hands?  Yeah, bet you can't tell if I just described Dynasty Warriors or Warframe, can you? Guess what, I'll tell you a secret. (It's both)  Strap on some wonderful RPG style mechanics and a similar card collecting system to upgrade your arsenal and you have a game that I never knew I needed, but I had it from the beginning and it's only now that I realize just how much it means to me.  Warframe is a game you need to try, it's free, it runs VERY well on almost any system in my experience, and it's above all really dang fun.  Get it.

This game is weird.  You play it for an hour... or 10. Or rather even 100. You kill. You shot. You cut. You reap. You heal. You farm. 100... 200... 300... You learn it more and more, and during those hours of time invested in - you like it more and more.  This game is a 'No no' for people, who might fall in for ICNRPS (interspace cyborg ninja role playing slasher/shooter), because you might just dissappear forever.  Great gamelplay, being dynamic, demanding at higher difficulties, but staying fresh overall. Awesome atmospheare overall, levels being perfectly crafted and having gorgoues environment. Great financial model of free game, with content, that can be unlocked with time and reasonable efforts, or just bought for money (aka donations only speed your progress, nothing imbalanced).  Have to pay my respect for the devs, you guys are awesome.  I left warframe like a year ago or two already, as my life pretty much made me quit, but this game is the one, I always have good memories associated with, and i always know, that i can come back and enjoy it, like it is my first hour playing... or second... or third hundred.

Now that I've got 1000< hours in this game I can definitely say that it's awesome.  Even though I have to farm a lot and sacrifice a lamb or two to either RNGsus or LOOTcifer I keep coming back to this game becuse it's just so full of things to do. It also looks incredible and has a pretty decent OST behind it.  <Variety> You can also see a lot of creativity in the weapons(OMG a giant hammer with a jet thruster on it's back!!!), the enemies and the levels. You can customize your loadout however you want to complete a specific tasks.  <Dev Team> The devs are also worth mentioning becuse they interact really well with the community which helps the game grow a lot.   <Lore> Also if you are like me you will find the lore really exciting becuse the game doesn't tell you the whole thing but rather it gives you little bits and pieces that you can place together as you want which is way better that a book you have to read through. More abou that the game gives you most of these informations in an in-game CODEX so you don't have to go to the wiki or their website for them (I'm looking at you Destiny).  <Trading> Last but not least there is this trading system in which you can get anything in the game without paying a single dollar. In my opinion this is what makes Warframe the best FTP game we currently have

Warframe is a surprisingly enjoyable game with a lot of content. It is exactly what Destiny based its gameplay on (hub map, where you select level-oriented missions on planets from a solar system layout, then team up with other players for a run through), but with a much smaller budget and no price to entry for the player (and in my experience, far more variety to game play environments, customization, classes, and so on -- plus ninja swords).  This game may not be for everyone, but it definitely deserves a try. Especially if you have a friend or two to partner up with (though it does pretty well at matchmaking in-game).

*This was written during the Specters of the Rails update. Things ARE different in the game after this review. I've fallen in love with this game but this latest update (The Glast Gambit) is making me doubt my love for this brilliant game.  The first thing that I wanna address is the 'pay to win' misconception. No, this game is not pay to win. You can get everything BUT MOST cosmetics for free. You just have to spend a crapton of time to get it. If you are thinking 'COSMETICS MUST B PAYD 4! IS P2W! U SAID IT!' then know that cosmetics do nothing. It just makes you look prettier, maybe, if it falls in-line with your tastes. Getting new stuff can be hard for a new player so look for help online in order to have help at your disposal. Weapons and other useful things take time to get for free and if you pay real money for them then you have only gotten them faster.  Warframe is a free to play game made by Digital Extremes. You play as a Warframe, a war machine ninja thing that can parkour and shoot things and use melee weapons.  The gameplay is the best thing about the game. Using a melee weapon is really fun and gunplay is pretty good. The 'parkour' mechanics are pretty awesome and they can even be really useful if you wanna create a shortcut of some sort. The game also has a bullet time feature... Kinda. You aim your gun in the air, you go slow-motion and you shoot stuff. This can also be used for creating shortcuts if you combine the games parkour maneuvers with the slow-mo bullet time feature in order to reach certain places from a distance.  The story is... Uhh... Um... Do you know the game Destiny? It's like that, kinda. You begin in a place, something finds you and you escape from the bad guys of the game. And then you get a spaceship because why not? The INITIAL story is nothing special. In fact, it's kinda boring. The enemy factions are kinda cool, I guess. The Grineer are the 'barbaric and primitive' faction and the Corpus are the 'rich yet also greedy, technologically advanced' faction. They both use their own futuristic technologies and they are both the bad guys because... Well, they just are. Many other questlines in the game are far more interesting than the first questline (such as Natah and Second Dream) as they expand the lore and the world of Warframe by a margin.  The levels have some variety to them. For example, Mars is a desert planet thing and Earth is a 'nature-has-taken-over-post-apocalyptic-greenery-yay' (and Earth is the worst planet in my opinion due to how generic-looking it is). While the planets have THAT kind of variety, it doesn't mean that they are unique. They are incredibly generic. It's just factories, science stations and the kind of things that you expect from each respective planet in our solar system (the game takes place in our solar system btw). The most unique planet is Uranus in my opinion, as it is a water planet with giant fortresses on top of the ocean surface and you can go underwater or fight on land. Think of this planet as Kamino from Star Wars but with Grineer architecture. Other wonderful looking places in the game include everything related to the Orokin race such as the Orokin Moon, the Void and the Orokin Derelict. Another thing that the levels have going for them is procedurally-generated levels. It sounds AWESOME, right? Well, the rooms just have a swapped order in order to not make the levels repetitive. It works on the better planets of the game but when some planets are too generic, it doesn't work at all.   The graphics are fine enough as they are. They look good. The models are nice, the texture-quality is nice. The game is also well optimised so you can probably run it on a potato, though not with 60 fps at Ultra settings.  The multiplayer aspect of the game is really good in my opinion. You can speak with other players through multiple channels. I'm going to go over the default channels that are always with you: A channel for the region chat where you speak with other players about a lot of different things, a trade chat for marketing an item that you wanna sell or trade and recruit chat for asking other players to join you in a mission or you can join other players if they ask for help. Playing with other people also helps a lot, especially against bosses and 'levels that go on forever'. Since you are more people, the game obviously becomes easier. Hell, you may perhaps find a new friend! Oh, and you can create and/or join clans (!) in the game. I won't be going in-depth into what player clans do but it's basically this: You start a clan, you build your own place and other clan members may contribute to things in your clan home in order to fund construction. You can also do different things in your clan home such as build rooms in order to fight other players for fun, create a platforming room for fun, create useful rooms that allows you to build new weapons and/or just overall build nice looking rooms/decorations. The community is mostly nice. No one has been rude to me as of yet but I have seen people being rude to each other on the region chat multiple times. Lag is also a thing but that depends on you or other players. There are dedicated PvP modes in the game but barely anyone plays PvP.  There are many different mission types, by the way. I won't go over them all but you can bet on it that there are many such as Survival (It's horde mode), Defend (you defend something against waves of enemies), and Exterminate (you kill everything that isn't friendly) just to name a few. Having multiple people on Defend and Interception (capture the flag, pretty much) is recommended, especially on harder levels as it will get overwhelming at times to do these types of missions solo.  The sound effects, sound design and music composition is fine. Music is meh though. Some songs really stand out while others are just generic sounds.  Let's go over the negatives now. The first questline is a thing I've already mentioned. Specters of the Rails did ruin some things for me. While others may think that the 'archwing mode' in the game was still ♥♥♥♥♥ in pre-SotR (SotR stands for Specters of the Rail for those who don't know), I think that it was awesome... until SotR happened. I don't mind the new '360 degrees flying-around' thing as that is cool, but the camera is way too close to the player this time and my eyes hurt when the player moves so fast with the camera so close to him. Bugs are here and there but they are in every game and DE fixes them whenever they can. The game is incredibly grindy. However, SotR did reduce the amount of grinding required for prime stuff but the same can't be said for everything else as you will be grinding a lot. The worst flaw in Warframe is just the overall artstyle and level design. While the Warframes themselves AND their weapons look really awesome, everything can be described with one word: generic. The levels are really bland, the enemies look so boring and while they are fun to kill, they don't do much to you and are just like every other enemy template in shooters ever (except for most of the Infested enemies such as Ancients, Mutated Moas and Juggernauts, the bosses, some of the Corpus enemies such as Moas and Bursas and the Grineer Manics). The levels can look so bland that not even the procedurally-generated systems in the game can help it.  Overall, this game is fun as a multiplayer game with friends. You can solo it but it will take time and skill to do so. I'd give the game a 6 or 7/10. It's good but the game has flaws and the artstyle is too generic for me to love it. Do give this game a try. It may/will be boring in the beginning, as this is one of those games that require you to play many hours in order for the game to really click.

Warframe a game where you 'Tenno' masters of the Warframe have to save the solar system from the hands of the grinner, the corpus and every other baddie around (and there are alot), but killing them with style !!!  Pros: - Amazing graphics, animations and particle effects; - Great soundtrack (specially the 2 newer story quests, they are just a pure masterpiece); - Random maps every mission; - Parkour all the way through the level, or you can just walk like a peasant if you want... (yes you can do a barrel roll) :P - Lots of weapons to choose in your perfect style to kill enemies; - The Devs team are always getting new updates with new content out; - #Fashion Frame (customize everything to your own way, literally make it YOUR game!);  - The best community you will find in a game (sure there are always the random toxic players, but they are almost inexistent in this game); -You can choose the syndicate you want to work with; - There is no pay to win here because you are able to get everything in the game free, the currency the game uses as real money 'platinum' can be traded from other players for stuff you farm in the game so you just need to find someone to trade you; - Cinematic missions! (yes this is a free to play game with cinematics let it sink for a minute); - If you are new and have any doubts you can always ask for help in the chat, im sure you will find someone to help you out ;) Cons: - Heavy grinding (I personnally like it but i know some don´t) - PVP its not very good since there are some unbalanced powers from the warframes and some weapons can´t be used; - Sometimes you will eventually run into a bug or two, thats just normal for a constant updating game, but be sure hotfixes burn them all away;

- Story -  'They were called Tenno. Warriors of blade and gun: masters of the Warframe armor. Those that survived the old war were left drifting among the ruins. Now they are needed once more.  The Grineer, with their vast armies, are spreading throughout the solar system. A call echoes across the stars summoning the Tenno to an ancient place. They summon you.   Allow the Lotus to guide you. She has rescued you from your cryostasis chamber and given you a chance to survive. The Grineer will find you; you must be prepared. The Lotus will teach you the ways of the Warframes and the secrets to unlocking their powers.  Come Tenno, you must join the war.'  I think in my opinion is one of the best F2P games I ever played.It has: weapons, space ninjas, Archwing, character customization, santinels, your very own pet (called Kubrow) and more. The best advice I can give you is: take your time and don't buy everything you see on market.Almost everything you see there can be created/optained through hard wark and patience.  I definitely recommend this game to anyone that is looking for this kind of games...That's it, now excuse me, I need to get back and save the humanity.

Great game and it is free so give it a shot!   You play as one of the Tenno and you use a Warframe (there are quite a few, but you get to choose one out of a few for free from the start). You take on various kinds of enemy factions (Grineer, Corpus, Infected) in different kinds of missions given to you by Lotus, more or less the leader of the Tenno, across many planets. You can unlock more planets as you accomplish certain goals. On top of that there is a place called the Void that is quite difficult and requires a key to enter (4 tiers of difficulty). In the void you have the potential to unlock special items only obtainable there that both look better and function better than their normal counterparts. These are 'Prime' items.  The combat is quite good and fast paced, and it's all in third-person. Though fairly straight forward, it isn't necessarily easy. You'll want to move around a lot which can take some getting use to (as a Tenno you can be very acrobatic). You have a health bar and a shield bar, as well as energy which is used up when you use your Warframe's skills.   As you play you gather materials which allow you to build new weapons of which there are many types (primary, secondary, melee, and subtypes of those), as well as companions (sentinels which are floating little weaponized creatures, and kubrow which are a lot like dogs), and new warframes (basically your battlesuit) for you to use, which each have their own unique appearance and skills. There is also something called an archwing that allows you to do an entirely new kind of mission where instead of running around in a ship or on a planet, you can fly though space killing your enemies. Spaaaaaaaaaace.  In addition to building things, you can get a lot of drops called Mods. There is a massive amount of different mods out there. Mods can be used to improve your Warframe, all of your weapons, and your companions. As you level your gear up you can equip more mods. You can also sell mods, fuse many mods into one to increase it's effect (best of the three options), or fuse many mods together to gain one random better mod.   In addition to all of that you can buy quite a few cosmetic things as well. For your Warframe, your weapons, your companions, and even your ship Liset. Your ship Liset is quite important. It's your hub for access to the market, codex, syndicates, foundry, arsenal, and more.  The game allows you to join or create a clan which gives you access to a clan dojo, where you can gain access to many useful things over time (there's even a sentinel, the Djinn, that can only be gained by owning a clan dojo and building a bio-lab). You build various rooms with materials, and anyone in the clan can contribute.  There also are factions you can join that are either broken off from the Grineer, Corpus and Tenno, or are something entirely unrelated to them. These factions are the Steel Meridian, Arbiters of Hexis, Cephalon Suda, The Perrin Sequence, Red Veil, and New Loka. They all have different standings with each other (Allied, Opposed, and Enemy) and you can join as many as you want. By helping them, you can gain special rewards only obtainable through them. However be aware that be helping some, your reputation can go down with others. And by joining syndicates, there is a chance that very difficult enemies can spawn in and attack you. There is also another powerful enemy that has a chance to spawn in and attack you called the Stalker. This enemy is attracted by killing bosses. The more bosses you kill, the more of a chance it has to spawn in future missions.  Great game. Download for free and get your friends in on it. There's much more I could discuss but I've already written a massive amount, so find out for yourself!

A friend recommended this game to me and helped me a lot earlier on, so keep in mind my experience was definitely enhanced by being admitted into a clan with high ranking members to help me out.  Warframe is a great, free game (definitely NOT pay to win/play) with good graphics, a variety of warframes (armor?), a variety of weapons, and a lot of ways to cater the game to your play style (or many different play styles to try, whatever floats your boat).  The game suffers, like most, from grind, repetition, and some lack of guidance. However, the developers continue to work on the game and are attempting to rectify some of these problems. Grind, while awful, is pretty much a cornerstone of a great many games (ARK is worse than WF to be honest). To be fair though, while playing through the game and unlocking new areas I did not find myself severely lacking in resources to build what I wanted. The biggest set back was mostly credits (in game currency), which can be earned by selling some of your acquired goods, completing normal missions, completing extra missions (alerts, invasions, etc), and by trading goods with other users. However, with a helpful clan, you can credit farm pretty easy and overcome this obstacle. Mid to late game, grind will be a bit more of a problem as you strive to attain better items, but for the most part you can get by with what you've got. Repetition is not an issue early or mid game. In fact, repetition is more than likely caused by personal choice. Missions have randomized tilesets, a good variety of enemies (that will vary depending on your location in the starchart), and with multiple ways to play you can get a lot of variety out of the game. However, when you begin to grind for particular items, you'll choose repetition to something new to achieve a goal. By late game, you'll have seen everything, tried everything and run out of things to do. The devs provide events and are constantly making new weapons and frames to try and keep things interesting. They are also discussing changes to the starchart to offer some more randomization to keep the game from becoming dull. Lack of guidance is also being worked on. There is a lot to this game and a lot to learn. If I didn't have a helpful clan, I would have been drowning, but that wasn't the case for me. I can only recommend you ask for some help to learn the game at this point. The devs have stated they will be implementing more missions and guides to showcase parts of the game that are essentially stumbled upon currently.  I've mentioned quite a bit that the developers are working on making things better. This can also be a con. Updates to the game are often riddled with bugs which will eventually be fixed. Some of these bugs can be crippling in game, some of them are minor. What you run into is the luck of the draw.  Overall, I really like the game. It's free, you'll get in a good few hours at least, and it's not pay to win (you can pay to get things earlier if you want and for COSMETIC skins). Also, if you want to buy the premium currency, daily rewards can offer heavy discounts. No need to pay full price, 25% is common, but you can probably hold out for a 75% off and buy quite a bit of premium currency for all your WF desires.  I HIGHLY RECOMMEND that you find yourself a good clan to join. They can help explain where to get what, how to efficiently use items, what you can get rid of and what you should keep, etc.

I can't stop... playing this game... Help me.  For a more substatnive review, a lot has already been covered in other reviews that I can echo; the gameplay is fun, it's got some grinding aspects but you never feel a lack of what to do, the co-op aspects are spectacular, and abilities start to synergize with each other as you start to work together...  The reason I got so wholy sucked into it, though, is that it feels like an amalgamation of a lot of my favorite aspects of gaming; a compelling leveling system, great customization options for gameplay style, reasonable grinding for new equipment and warframes so that each acquisition feels like an exciting accomplishment... Cooperative Cyborg Space Ninja Third Person Action RPG. Do I have your attention yet?  Having witnessed the evolution of this game from its infancy I can say that it has grown into a unique peice of gaming that will certainly garner its place in the hearts and minds of people. Coming from just a handful of 'Warframes', this games version of character with pre-made stats, to an abundence such that there is almost always one to suit any playstyle within the third person market.  In terms of graphics it has come a long way. The lighting and animations have come to a crisp smoothness that a lot of other free-to-play titles simply haven't gotten to. The bio-metal, or whatever the suits are made up of look organic but have the deflecting power of metal which makes for an interesting change when you're sliding across a metal surface and hear the suit grinding against the ground.  Combat is almost always fast and fluid with hoards of enemies attempting to do everything in their power from keeping you from your objective with varying enemy types. Going head long into a wave of enemies can be fun, but the unprepared should be ready for a quick death. Finding your niche is easier since there are plenty of people in the community who are willing to pull you along to get the Warframe of your choice by getting you the parts to build it.  Crafting is simple to learn and essencial to maximizing your arsenal as well. Getting the right gun could just be a matter of getting the materials to build it. If it turns out to not be that great, sell it off and craft again until you find that one you're willing to put money down to get a Orokin Catalyst and enhance it further for a fraction of the cost it would have been to purchase the weapon outright. Who knows, you might even find an event and get the Catalyst completely free.  The final and most important element of the game is the mods. These can completely alter the way some of the warframes play out, even some of the weapons get an extra kick. Current personal favorite is the Kunai throwing knives with a 170% chance of an additional shot at the same time. That's right, I get the possibility to throw a third with each toss of a blade and deal massive damage. Finding this kind of combo for your weapon is just a download away.  Enjoy.

After 666 hours in this game and 200 0f those happening in just 2 weeks, yes at one point I spent literallly over half of 2 weeks playing this game I feel like I can say that this game is good, but niche, its not a game you can pick and play very easily, theres a very bad tutorial system and a lot of the mechanics are taught very well (i.e. weapon modding and crafting) this is a game where you cant really aim for anything such as a weapon or Warframe (the different playable classes) its all about just using what you have and chugging forward. The entire game is a grind, I cant deny that, but the core gameplay of being a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ acrobatic robot space ninja with guns is fast paced and fun enough to keep anyone who gets into this game hooked, shooting and killing is fun and feels great, the movement system is fluid and works extremely well with the combat, and just the variety of guns, melee weapons and Warframes means theres something for everyone. Now as I said earlier the game is a grind, but more of what I'd call a farm, cause its always gratifying. One last thing im very happy with is that you can play this game without spending a single cent, while buying the in game premium currency will certainly help you progress quicker and give you more customisation options which are most of the time just aesthetic, you can still get every single weapon and warframe in the game as a complete free to play, despite how it will certainly take you a bit longer, all in all, addicting gameplay with unique and fun weapons and mechanics, with the only drawback being that it isnt very friendly to new users and the grind can be a major detriment to some players, but in my opinion, great game, certainly worth a try.

Overall Warframe is a great game. Good graphics, runs well on most PCs, very smooth controls and movement is fluid, the mission types are engaging and keep you wanting to progress further into the game.  People who complain that it's too 'grindy' are missing the point and purpose of what the game is. Warframe is not an open world RPG where you can simply roleplay without putting in any work, the entire point of the game is about fighting and doing missions. It also isn't supposed to be a game where you can get your gear and characters up to max tier within a week. You're meant to spend a lot of time on it to rank up and get the gear that you'd like. While you can straight up buy your stuff with platinum (the currency that you purchase with real life cash), you are not obligated to and you don't have to as almost everything outside of cosmetic items can be built with in game only materials, albeit taking more time to craft.   The devs made a good in game trading interface for players where you can get platinum for items that you acquire with only in-game materials, such as prime gear parts and mods. If you are dedicated and seriously want something that is only obtainable with platinum, you can get it through effort and trading worthy items to other players that would want what you have. It takes time, but if you don't want to spend any cash, you can still work for what you want.  I do recommend playing the game with at least one or more friends though if possible, as it's a lot easier to learn and figure things out with a friend to help you, especially if it's someone who has already played the game before and can help get you a headstart into learning the core game mechanics. Playing solo is still viable though, since there's a huge amount of player-to-player interaction, and you can figure out almost anything you need by just searching through the warframe forums or steam community page.   Onto the actual gameplay and bread 'n butter of the game, everything really flows together really nicely in this game. I'm a huge fan of the movement system, since you can be really agile and parkour around maps, and it's all extremely fluid feeling. All of the warframes are pretty balanced and you can do a decent amount of work with any warframe you choose to use, given that you equip and upgrade proper mods to your gear. Mods are basically just 'boosters' to your weapons and your warframe (Your warframe is basically like your class, btw. Your warframe is what gives you all your abilities and sort of defines what your role is in the game.) and they apply various different perks and bonuses, and you can further ugprade to get even more out of them. The weapons are decently balanced as well, of course the harder you have to work for a weapon and the higher rank it is, the better it'll be, just like any other game, but with proper mods you can turn even low quality weapons into pretty good ones.   Some people say the game gets repetitive, which I could see why people would think that, but it really depends on what kind of person you are and what kind of games you find personally fun. I for one haven't gotten bored of Warframe yet in the 2 or so weeks I've been playing it. Warframe definitely isn't an open world game, but it still has a good community with loads of content to explore and learn about. There are hundreds of different weapons to choose from, so you can always switch up your playstyle and try new things to keep the game fresh. If you go into the game with an open mind and not expecting it to be a f2p version of WoW, you'll have a lot of fun.   If you like to be a perfectionist in games and always want to seek out the best possible outcomes and the strongest gear in a game, Warframe will be awesome for you because you can spend days upon days hunting down the rarest and most powerful weapons and mods to gear up with. With the alert mission system, there's a bit of luck involved with getting the best gear as well, since you may or may not be online while something super good pops up on the alerts, so you may end up having to wait for it to pop up again if you aren't on in time to get it.   All in all, Warframe is a good game, especially since it's totally free to play. It's hard for me to find a real complaint when I'm not in anyway obligated to play the game if I don't want to. The only negative thing I'd have to say is that corpus missions suck. Corpus enemies have a bunch of shields, plus they have flying drones that give even more shields as well as certain enemies who nullify your abilities. They also deal pretty good damage, especially as you go later in the game. If the enemy spots you and triggers the alarm and you don't clear it fast enough, a tank-like enemy called a Bursa will come rushing in and wreck your day, while being pretty hard to kill in most circumstances.   This paragraph is probably going to sound stupid but I just need to comment on it. The single worst part for me is these enemies in corpus missions that I like to call 'turkey legs' (or MOA, which is their actual name.) They are literally just a pair of green mechanical legs with a gun on top. They seriously look like some sort of oversized robotic bird legs running around the place. Their design is so absurdly silly that I can't help but get angry whenever they kill me or when a swarm of them come to attack me with their never ending laser gun attacks. There's also the infested MOA, but at least their design kind of makes sense to some degree since they're actually a living thing and it looks like they got hit with some sort of plague. With the corpus MOAs, I can't help but imagine this stupid picture in my mind of some mad scientist in a lab creating the corpus turkey legs with them flooding off of a conveyor belt thinking the design is super wicked and unstoppable, when in reality it's no joke, just a pair of green legs that shoot at you while looking hilarious running around the map.  Also, the boss fights can get a bit ridiculous at times, since some of them are literally invincible unless you hit them in super specific spots, make them use an ability so that they become vulnerable, or use a specific type of damage against them. The game usually gives very little indication of what to do, aside from Lotus perhaps making a small comment here and there about the boss's general weakness, for the most part you have to either figure it out on your own, or search up how to beat the boss. While not unbeatable, I'd recommend finding someone to bring along with you if you need to do boss fights until you get stronger gear at least. It's usually easy to find someone in the recruitment public chat, so I'd try that if you don't know anyone personally who plays warframe. A lot of people are usually willing to give a helping hand, especially if you're somewhat new.   Anyways, this game is overall very enjoyable, and for being free to play it would never hurt to at least try it for an hour and then just uninstall it if you don't like it.  Highly recommended.

Warframe if unique, to say the least. You're in the middle of a warzone from the very beginning, and on top of your powers and armor, you're a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ ninja. The third person shouldercam is a bit weird for me, as I'm used to FPS games, but still a nice change from not being able to see the lower right corner of my screen. The movement system is pretty cool, what with all the parkour, but if you're used to crouching on the fly, you can't do that. If you try, you'll initiate a slide, keeping forward momentum for a few seconds, allowing you to dodge bullets aimed at your Tenno's upper half. However, if you're on a computer with no high-end gaming thingamabobs, the game runs quite slow.  Overall, I give Warframe 7/10, because Windows 7 would probably handle it better than my Windows 10 s***box.  *EDIT* So, I got a PS4 for christmas, and Warframe is free on PS4. Naturally, I downloaded it, and I've got about 10 hours on it there. I hereby update my rating to 10/10. The graphics are beautiful, there are screen flares (but not to the extent of JJ Abrams), bloom, and a ♥♥♥♥ton of other graphics terms I'm not familiar with. PLAY IT. NOW.

As with most games with fast combat, you will need a beefy computer to play this game. However when you get the game working, its a great way to pass time, and can even become an adiction. Graphics:On High the game is gorgeous. the graphics are very nice to look at, there is gore, but it can be easily turned off. Gameplay:The gameplay can be either fast pased, low passed, stealthy, shoot-em-up, slasher...you get the point this game is uniqe and can match whatever playstyle you disire Playtime:This game is infinetly long it seems, and there is always somthing to do, wheather it be getting a new weapon, mod, warframe, or trying to beat a boss (not an easy task btw). Multiplayer:easy to access and is encouraged.(though you have to beat the tutorial mission and the mission after that to unlock it) and there is a multiplayer mode called conclave with four game modes: Free for all, team deathmatch, capture the flag, and lunaro(aka football crossed with basketball) Maps:this game takes place across all the planets and some of the moons in our solarsystem and each planet has about 15 missions on them all with their own level design. not to mension that there are derelict orokin spaceships in the void for advanced players to explore and fight in, for a chance to get prime weapons and warframes, along with items essential for building certian things( for example: forma is needed to make rooms and hallways for a clan dojo).Plus a map called: the derilict for those who want to try and defeat the hardest boss in the game and leader of the worst force in the system: Lafantice Enemy's:there are 4 nations in the game, all with about seven or more veriations of there soldiers. Overall this game gets a 10/10 in my book and not only is the game fun, but the lore is very facinating. Edit: I forgot to mention that people on this game are very friendly

You now that pleasant feeling when dopamine levels spike up in your prefrontal cortex and striatum? You know, that sense of reward and achievement? Well, Warframe is all about that - sense of illusory achievement in a virtual environment (which game isn't?). Mostly, because you set up goals to get stuff and then you get it. To put it shortly Warframe = farming with guns. But it doesn't mean that it's bad. It's actually very fun.  There's plenty of content. I have 200 hours on record and I still haven't mastered all the gameplay elements and unlocking everything would take me another year or more (since the developers keep updating the game all the time).  Don't be put off that it's F2P, because you can get everything for free (except for skins and extra slots) - it just takes a lot of farming. Warframe is NOT P2W.  So why is Warframe so fun?  - Ninja parkour: wall runs, slides, slide kills, bullet time, zipline kills, double jumps, ground slams...Warframe is a very fast-paced game and offers numerous ways how to kill with style. - Unique abilities for different characters – choose your own 'pokemon' and master it! Wreak havoc and assist your team! -Friendly community - always someone around to help you out on a mission or trade with you. - Clans - build your own dojo - vast customisation and research options – or join others to facilitate your progress through cooperation - Tons of weapons, mods, sentinels/kubrows (pet or machine assistants) and warframes (suits) – most of the time you spend farming and upgrading stuff - Your own ship - place where you build stuff - Relays - places where you meet other players, trade for prime stuff, interact with syndicates (earning standing points unlock useful stuff) - Archwing missions - Star Wars like shooting in the outer space!! (How cool is that?!) - Quests - special missions with story and special rewards - Various type of missions - plan your next step according to your desires or goals; there's enough to choose from, so that you don't feel bored - Cool and challenging bosses - special reward drops and a bit of 'story' that freshens up the farming experience - Feeling of being a total badass hacking, slashing and shooting enemies across the Solar System  There are some cons though, too:  - Paid content is too expensive without discount (I recommend to wait for random 75% discount on daily login rewards and to spend platinum on slots, orokin reactors/catalysts and formas (although you can build the latter three from rare BPs) - Extra slots cost money (understandable) and there's a certain pressure to purchase it, otherwise you can't build a nice arsenal - Farming is long (although it's understandable, why would otherwise people would be motivated to buy something) - Most other players rush out through the missions - which is kind of bad, if you want more time for looting - Don't like the Forma thing for polarity change - you reset your rank to zero and start all over again just to have extra space for mods - Gamepad is not fully supported (some things don't work) - Solo is not possible for all missions - some are just too hard  Anyway, Warframe is a fun and addictive game. The best F2P game ever!  My overall rating: 9/10

Man, considering I've pumped almost 500 hours into Warframe; a game I originally did not enjoy, I'd say its worth your time.  That is, however, dependant on your viewpoints regarding both third person shooters and also science fiction themes. It also may require a bit of patience, so if that's not your thing, or you can't enjoy something for the sake of enjoyment, please, try something else.  Warframe is at core, somewhat of a grindfest at current, but for some people (myself included), this can be made fun with a little imagination, and a simple appreciation of the way the game handles and looks. You play as a Warframe, whom is tasked with various objectives and goals in missions that you select from a series of nodes you unlock as you progress across a map of our galaxy. These range from Capture - wherein you chase down, and kill and then absorb a capture target, before extracting whilst being shot at by mutlitudes of enemies - to things like Survival and Defense, which involve trying to keep your life support system above 0% by slaying foes and collecting the life capsules they drop and defending a Warframe pod that contains a cryo-frozen Warframe soldier inside respectively. There are more missions, which I will not go into detail about, but they can all prove fun.  The game is primarily free to play, although has a micro-transaction system in place that allows boosters, weapons and Warframes themselves to bought outright. This balances out toward people who dislike grinding to achieve things. The only things I would consider pay-to-win (and they aren't truly, as they can still be attained - though rarely - freely through alerts), are Orokin Catalysts and Orokin Reactors. These items are one-time use, and boost a weapon or Warframe's modification capacity respectively, allowing you to change and add more to the ojbect in order to increase its power or to make even cooler builds.  The game up to this point was not entirely user-friendly, and much of its mechanics and nuances had to be learnt via friends or guides, or just by simply asking in game, but recently a new addition - the Codex - was added to the main menu UI that allows tutorials to be accessed freely. So that's cool.  Now onto the cool part, the Warframes. They appear as exo-suits or armour that encompasses a person, and they grant mysterious and awesome powers that pertain to each different frame. Volt, for instance, has abilities that let him control and manipulate electricity in the level, killing enemies and shielding allies with it. He is just one of plenty unique frames and all are acquirable for free. Your only restraint will be slots in your inventory to hold these frames (and weapons too), though this can be increased via buying platinum - the paid currency (or trading for paltinum, if you find a rare item).  Story is a bit limited at the moment, and so is the end-game. But this has been slated for fixation by the end of this year, or even earlier.  To conclude, Warframe is cool.

As of 7-13-16 (Specters of the Rail update), the void system has been revamped to reduce RNG and as such, grind. Some parts of this review may no longer be relevant.   Warframe as a whole is really a big hit or miss; it will appeal to certain players, but feel lackluster and repetitive for others. There's no denying that Warframe could very easily be called 'Grindframe' and nobody would bat an eye, because it's really what you'll be doing the entire time you play as you progress. MMORPG players will be used to this kind of environment, and will likely enjoy this game a lot due to it's fantastic graphics, character design, customization options, and it's overall true F2P nature.  Once you clear most of the missions on your starmap as a beginner, you'll set your sights on larger prizes, such as Prime weapons and Warframes (basically cooler looking, better attributed items) which can only be acquired in an exclusive zone on the starmap called the Void, which is only accesible through one-time use Void Keys. These keys can be found during regular missions if you largely surpass the 'standard' or 'regular' threshold for either time limit or extra objectives. After you first start to do Void missions, you'll slowly start to realize that in order to actually get some of the cool gear that other players are running around with, you'll need to grind these missions a lot in order to get anything worthwhile. For each Prime item, you'll need a set of usually four components, which includes the weapon blueprint, which all need to be found seperately through random chance following the completion of a void mission. This random chance is usually very very slight in favor of certain components needed to complete an item, which only further encourages the need to farm the same mission over and over until you finally do acquire the item you're looking for. After that, you need to craft each component for a 12 hour time span, after which you then need to craft the ACTUAL item which takes another three days (I should note that these crafting times only apply to Prime Warframes). My point is, as most of endgame entirely revolves around this formula, a lot of players might get turned off early and stop playing this game altogether because of how tedious things might seem at first, and how tedious things start to become as they level up.  The game isn't very beginner friendly either. The tutorial is succinct and over in a flash, consisting only of one mission after which you'll be on your own. It really only shows you the basics of combat and movement, but not anything else. The problem is, there's a TON more content that you'll be left in the dark with, considering how there is virtually zero explanation for anything past ingame combat. There are tutorials available in the Codex in your ship, but new players likely won't discover this if they don't poke around a little by themselves. And again, these tutorials don't explain any of the real meat of this game, of which experienced players had to learn by themselves and grow the love the game based on the things you don't know after first starting. For new players, looking up a video on Warframe basics is highly recommended before uninstalling due to complexity or simple intimidation of the whole ordeal.  Sorry about the jumbled up review, just had a lot on my mind to clear before giving my personal opinion of the game and if I recommend it or not. Like I said, Warframe is really a huge hit or miss. Some people will love it, others hate it, others won't give it a chance and really see what's at the heart of this game before simply quitting. It's a truly F2P game, meaning absolutely ANYTHING can be acquired without using real money, all depening on how much time you're willing to grind (everything leads back to that...). All the brilliant cosmetic options, Warframe selection, weapon selection, ship customization and selection, all of it can be granted through simply playing the game and earning them through trading with other players (again, which is an aspect that is also ENTIRELY foreign to new players, and is downright intimidating for your first 50 or so hours).  In conclusion, I would definitely recommend you check this game out. Considering it's free, there's no harm is installing it just to see if you like it or not, as this game is NOT for everybody. Those without patience or willingness to learn more about the game, or simply don't enjoy the repetitive although fun gameplay will very likely not enjoy this game at all. I for one love this game because of it's brilliant graphics, it's arguably expansive lore and universe, it's awesome sci-fi ninja setting, and it's fast and exciting gameplay.

Warframe is basically like DJ Khaled.  'I changed, A LOT.'  Warframe has, like our good friend Khaled said, changed a lot over the past years and it keeps doing it, you cant compare the one we have today to the one we had in 2013, it was kind of sloppy, repetitive and overall kind of lackluster. The concepts where there but they needed some improvements. Now it's really smooth, with a lot of content and tons of updates every month or so. Dont be fooled because it's free to play, you can get everything (except most of the cosmetics) for free, that is, by grinding. Though it can get a bit repetitive i always find myself coming back (probably because of the content they keep adding)  Talkin' about updates: 'Another one, and another one'  They're like that, one after the other almost non stop, new warframes, weapons, cosmetics, quests and missions added on all of them, constant bug fixes and hotfixes. I'm going to give my opinion only so don't take this personally. Also 90% of my experience with Warframe was on my Xbox One. I played on PC as well but not often.   I have put over 300 hours into Waframe and unlocked almost every frame and I 'SELL ALL DA THINGS' to pay for slots and taters. After all this time, and monetary investment I regret ever playing this game. Update after update the developers seem to nerf the frames into oblivion and to create ever more ways to make you want to, and need to, pay to advance further in the game. The game is already 'capped' based solely on the difficulty of various missions when playing solo so when you include the lack of useful mods, potatoes, and a clan this game is purely pay-to-win. At least half of the community is made of new to relatively new players who lack the things I previously mentioned and are forced to grind in the worst way possible, alone and without any guidance. I had a clan when I first started and they did what they could for me, even still I was unable to meet the skill requirements for end game missions as a mastery rank 16. I didn't have any primed mods. I didn't have any sentinals, kubrows, or even regular rare mods for damage (elemental/critical). I could not earn or find these mods in game alone, and the clan was busy helping very new players. After all this time and effort what do I have to show for it? Nothing. Just a lot of wasted time and a headache from grinding for 5 hours for simple neurodes, to make a weak and un-potatoed gun and frames. Keep it up DE with all of this nerfing and driving off paying customers like me, you'll be the ones getting shafted next.

Do I recommend this game? YES, Absolutely !!!  Its free !! And: This is the best free online-game I have ever played. By far !!  Why? Up to 4 players against different kind of enemies in different landscapes and situations. It has elements of card-games when modding the weapons (like RPG-elements). The steering of the character is a challange at first, but based on the speed, when you got it, its fun like a racing-game. Players who are more active are rewarded with higher levels in characters and weapons, but those levels are limited at 30, so new players arent disadvanteged too much and are able to catch up soon. Everyone can get the character (Warframe) and the weapons which fit best to their very personal fighting-style. There is a possibility to spend money, but not needed at all.  Asssasination, Defense, Extinction, Rescue, and so on are just some of the level-objectives in the 200something levels.  Fast actions, fast movements, great team-tactics and a well-thought weapon-damage-system makes this game a great fun-trip every time.  Get into the universe and we might play together soon.....

Two main things I like about this game:  First, of all those things in the trailers, I saw precisely one thing you can't actually do in game; it was when Loki stabbed two enemies at once, and if the Devs follow through with their promises, that might be possible by the next major update.  Second, since the trading system's implementation, there is literally nothing in the game that you can't get as a f2p player (which I am). Paying helps, but hard work will get you farther than any amount of cash.  In terms of originality, it seems like the developers had never played another video game in their lives. It's often hard to find games that aren't influenced by Star Wars, Halo, or other successful franchises these days, but this is one of those few.  Overall, great game, and I wish more games were like this.
