Turn off bloom immediately. Just turn it off. You will go blind as soon as you're anywhere with snow. I also recommend turning off blur and glare. The visual design in general hurts this game a lot; colours are all very samey which means things aren't visually distinct from each other, and it's even worse when you have the aforementioned effects turned on. I played in an area that was so bright I had to take a headache pill when I finished.  You never know when jumping somewhere will put you out of bounds and reset your position. Sometimes you need to take five mile drops, sometimes stepping in ankle deep water isn't okay. This game loves parkour so not knowing where you can land is unacceptable.  The cash shop is constantly in your face. So much so tha it makes finding noncash-shop things difficult. Inventory slots are limited to basically nothing,and you will pretty much need to buy more to advance.  The game is very restrictive from the outset, and doesn't open up easily. Tutorials are largely terrible and poorly laid out, and tend to overcomplicate simple things.  There's some fun stuff hiding in it, but it's all very much a pain to access, and there's so many poor design choices, I doubt I would ever really recommend this game.  Oh, and the archwing is basically unplayable. Spaceflight with half the necessary controls missing. Have fun getting hung up on scenery and never being able to see what you're fighting

This game is really good, and not good good, but so good, it will explode your brain *Don't take it too literally tho* Its about you, a Tenno, which will stand up, and kill everyone.. TL;DR: Great game for fans of parkour/slaughterhouses/stealth games  Warframe is a good game. It's not 10/10, but it's not 7/10. I'd say about 9/10 in my opinion. Its gameplay is absolutely stellar, being the most fluid yet connected movement I've ever seen in a game. Yes, it does have a market. However, everything that you buy in the market, you can also craft or find. As for graphics, at the max settings, the graphics are beautiful. Maybe not up to par with a few of the most recent games, but still, amazing. The gunplay feels solid, because if you try to go it alone without the know-how, your little puny @$$ is dead. However, if you've learned the advanced stuff, and you have skill, you can do plenty of missions alone. I've completed 4 entire planets all by myself, so you can also do so if you put the work in. It may get a bit repetitive at times, but the environments are beautiful. The game always offers new missions to players, like an infestation outbreak on Jupiter, or some 'faction war' between the Grineer and Corpus on Earth that you must end by eliminating every enemy there. Keep in mind, if it gets repetitive, it's not as repetitive as that CoD sh!t, because the maps in this game are procedurally generated (randomized). Also, the community isn't even close to as toxic as other games (lookin at you, CoD). In conclusion, I think Warframe is a really kick@$$ game, and hope to see you in-game soon!

Warframe is an amazing game for emphasizing your playstyle, each weapon is suited to a specific playstyle, or adaptive to MAKE it fit your playstyle, this also can be said about the Warframes themselves. Mods further enhance playstyle to the very elements you want to fire out of your gun! While it is a grind, after that first loadout is bought and you have a new melee, primary, and secondary weapon, it becomes a game of using awesome mods and unique effects for each gun to mow down hundreds of enemies in different ways, using abilities let's you master the flow of combat. Another thing great about this game is the animations, while they are triggered by player use on some, which can be a bit sudden, all animations look so smooth, and each weapon even has unique combos, stealth kills, finishers, and so on. I would highly recommend this game to anyone, and it's FTP, but not necessarily PTW, the developers themselves said that everything in the game (besides color packs and Excalibur Prime, the donator frame) is obtainable for free. Grinding to get a new weapon can be fun with friends, and the combat is so satisfying most of the time.

I recently came back to Warframe from a rather long hiatus, and WOW, the game is so much MORE now. If you played it a while ago, I really advise taking it out for another spin and getting hooked again!  This game is a little (grindy) gem, hidden here on Steam. But the grind is action packed, fun, and filled with tense moments of doubt. These challenges are overcome with skill and teamwork. This game is one of my favorite team/solo games. The missions have elements of CTF, Survival, Escort, Espionage and Exterminate/Assassinate, depending on the mission parameters. The different worlds offer variety, and the Archframe missions are a wanna-be mecha pilots joy.  Pro's- -Amazing graphics, killing in space never looked so glorious! -Fast paced gameplay, and fairly quick missions. Good for small or large time kill. -Highly customizable gear by modding makes each player pretty unique. -The boss fights are always a blast! -Great community, join a guild right off for help and support! Teamwork is fun! -Easy to pick up, takes some time and skill to master all the game has to offer. -PvP is brutal, but I suspect once you get good at it a lot of fun. -Space Ninja Mecha-madness!  Cons- -Try to avoid running the same mission/world over and over, it can feel stale even while your reaping rewards. Take advantage of the large variety of mission types and settings! -Avoid buying gear from the Marketplace, the player Trade channel often has the same (or better) items for much, much less!

I actually enjoy this game's gameplay, despite it being a total grindfest, however, the tutorial is an absolute nightmare. Nothing is imparted, the 'story,' if you can even call it that, is ridiculously slow-paced and the enemies and the instant failure-state missions build a frustrating environment for the player to the point where almost nothing is learned.  I can't recommend this game, ultimately, because of the rank-up system. Most games give you small bits of content maybe 4 times a year. DE is updating there game with new weapons, enemies, Warframes, Places almost monthly. Warframe Review [\h1]  Warframe is a Free-to-play Co-0p MMORPG, 3rd Person Shooter. You start out by choosing one of three Warframes and your end-game goal is to obtain all the frames; however, player based goals may vary for example you might want to reach the highest Mastery Rank or become pro at PvP. Warframe consists of Quests, over 300 missions, daily missions, 8-player Trials, PvP, Archwing, Operations, Seasonal events, Randomized Alert missions, and much more. Warframes customization is on point! The community is very involved with active forums, Steam Workshop, Player livestreams, DEV livestreams. I must also include that the graphics and performace on Warfame is amazing! You can max out all the settings on even old GPU's and the graphics are amazing and also include Nvidia PhysX. As I've first started playing Warframe in November 2013 and I'm a active player I highly recommend this Game to you Tenno!

I just can't do it anymore.   I formerly had a maximum-length review where I recommended this game with some caveats. I still do, but it's too difficult for me to justify its worth at the end of a regular grind session at this time. Don't get me wrong, I spent 50 bucks in support, and I don't particularly regret it, but at the end of the day you have to ask if you're further than where you were. For Warframe, the answer is 'No' on a lot of those days.   Warframe is a space-ninja futuristic third-person mmo. I could spend (and already have) a lot of time talking about its various systems, good things and bad, but only a few actually matter.   You have to be in a very special mindset in order for this game to not drive you crazy. If you want a game you can 'just play', solo or with friends while smashing dumb enemies, this one will last you for awhile, like it did me. If you want to have a life, or have your time respected, or even just grind out while listening to music and not be harassed by poor design decisions or game-breaking bugs, this game is not for you. In fact, if you want to accomplish or acquire something specific within a period of hours, the game does its absolute best to make you hate its fu*king guts, and it WILL succeed.   The inventory space is the price for free-to-play in this instance. You can buy plat like I did, or trade items for plat in-game. You DON'T need to spend real money. There had to be a paywall somewhere, and this is it. There is no auction house, and you can't interact with chat during a mission, so if you want to sell items you have to be prepared to sit in Trade chat for an unknown length of time with nothing to do. This system is terrible and, of course, done this way on purpose.   Leveling is comprised of getting different frames and weapons up to 30, then building or grinding out more of them and doing it again. Doing so will unlock more weapons you can equip, and the occasional quest. It's not a terrible idea, unfortunately it makes you spend a LOT of your play time using equipment that you don't particularly want to use. Not only that, because the modding capacity depends on level, as well as a frame's stats, the game relegates you most of the time to content you've already done because you wouldn't survive the content you're actually ON.   Being an MMO, it's a pretty serious grind. A lot of it is forgivable, but the relic system (where almost all the really good items are) totally destroys the sense of progression in the game. Let's say you want one of these items. Every relic opened drops one of five. Some items drop on multiple relics, but not always. Having already done the research beforehand, you find a mission where you can farm the relic you need, and what you want turns out to be a rare drop from that relic.   You might get a relic. Depending on the mission type, a relic is, or is not a guaranteed drop. This, I might add, has been ninja-nerfed several times. Let's say you need a Lith relic, there are currently six of those in circulation. Assuming you picked one of the few mission types left with a guaranteed drop, you have theoretically a one in six chance of getting the relic you need. The mission may take anywhere from 5-30 minutes depending on its difficulty, type, and your gear.   So you got the relic you need after running 1-6+ missions. Now you need to refine it with void traces. These drop from Fissure missions where you normally break open the relics. Their drop rate seems to range from 10-29. You're going to wind up running four to eight of these missions generally, at 15+ minutes a piece, to get 100 void traces. This will increase your desired item's drop rate to a whopping 10%. You run one more mission to break open the relic, annnnd....   You didn't get the item you wanted. ♥♥♥♥ you, now start the process over again.   Now, I'll be honest, maybe you're lucky and get it within five tries. Or if you break it open with other people on the mission, you can choose from their reward table as well. Or you can go over thirty tries like I have for one particular blueprint and still not get it. Personally, my problem with this system isn't that it takes awhile, it's that you can spend hours and have nothing but garbage to show for it. The system brutally punishes you for doing this by yourself, and the ability to solo was one of the things I originally liked about the game.  RNG isn't the only thing that kills the experience. Alerts usually give awful rewards, but some of them per day give resources or mods that are nearly (or entirely) impossible to get otherwise. Your time is not your own if you're any kind of serious about progressing in the game, and many have taken to keeping webpages or phone apps open that keep them informed when certain items are available.   Stealth exists, but for a game about ninjas, the AI is utterly moronic and makes stealth runs thoroughly boring. This is aside from the fact that it's not possible to take a stealth approach on certain mission types.  And then there are times when, somehow, the game or its devs love to troll the ♥♥♥♥ out of you, or so it seems. Maybe you get sent to scan a vital mission enemy and he spawned in a wall somewhere. Maybe you start an excavation mission and your mission objective never shows up, forcing you to abort. I once did a special alert set on Venus, where the recommended level was 3~18. During that mission, not one but SEVERAL bosses from Neptune showed up, upwards of the level 40 range. Perhaps there's a mission timer that you were unaware of and it just runs out, regardless of whether or not you see a countdown. Maybe the infamous Scorch enemy burns you through the go*damn walls without even knowing you're there, reducing your health to zero before you even notice what's happening. Sometimes it's a bug, but many times it's a decision that was made on purpose to either make things take longer, or create an unnatural difficulty spike.  The game has a special chubby for invincible enemies, for lazy design purposes. Maybe you afk for a minute and come back locked into a room with four nigh-invincible robots. Maybe you're leveling new weapons and frames, and during a messy fight the nigh-invincible Stalker shows up to assassinate you for a boss you killed weeks ago, while becoming immune to whatever four types of damage you inflict upon him at different intervals. Or perhaps several nullifiers and ancient healers spawn close together, necessitating melee combat while an entire crowd of invincible enemies hoses you with gunfire. Or maybe a boss is outright invincible unless you shoot a questionable hitbox. I've been gaming for 31 years, and I know bad hitboxes when I see them.   There's a lot of good in the game that I didn't talk about, and a few of my complaints are subjective according to gear, or mods. It's just too damn bad there are so many hours where you just spin your wheels with nothing to show for it, no matter how efficiently you plan your play-time, and it seems like you're fighting the dev's decisions at every turn. I don't need to 'beat' the game, it's just not engaging enough after a certain point to justify the time it demands from you.

Set in the far reaches of outer space during a new Dark Age, WARFRAME introduces the Tenno, a race on the brink of extinction after being enslaved by the Grineer for centuries. Players enter WARFRAME on the cusp of the Grineer's victory over the Tenno until they begin to arm themselves with WARFRAMES - an ancient exo-skeletal technology only they can operate. Hidden within the Orokin Derelicts of a lost civilization, new WARFRAMES lie dormant and undiscovered. These artifacts are the Tenno's only hope for survival.

Never before have you had the opportunity to breakdance in the vacuum of space. Or maybe you had. Then have it again. Never before have you had the opportunity to be disgusted at no less than 2/3rds of your enemy factions' appearance. Or maybe you had. Have it again for old times' sake. Never before have you controlled a biorobot hopping around a map frantically, just because it's Cool. Or, again, maybe you had. Have it again. Never before have you had the opportunity to meet an actually majority-polite MMO community. This one I know you really hadn't. Maybe before you've had the opportunity to have a space mom with such an incredible ♥♥♥. But that's the sort you want to have again. But I sure know that never before I had the opportunity to farm for basically anything and everything you need in a game. I'm talking Everything. Grindfarming simulator right here. And you sure have played games where you've had a lot of fun (and sometimes serious and emotional, sometimes terribly whacky) moments before. But it's always nice to have more, so if you're into highly mobile third person shooters where fashion is the real endgame, maybe you should give Warframe a try.

I can not recommend this game to anyone.  Clunky mechanics, endless grind, and pay-for-convenience plague every aspect of it.  What could have been a tactical, fast-paced co-op game about space ninjas devolves quickly into repetitive combat and boring, efficient farming against waves of grunts that practically run into your bullets. Once you have completed every mission type 10-15 times, you know what you are in for the rest of game.  The developers, Digital Extremes, have no cohesive vision for the game's future. Content patches include needlessly redundant features, and uninspired weapons that work in uninspiring ways. They are also rife with new bugs, and poorly balanced. An example would be their much awaited Archwing updated, which introduces a new game-mode that is practically standalone from the rest of the game. There is a massive time gate for even the highest-level players, unless you pay real money, and then once built you must find and then level-up 'mods' associated with it and nothing else. The Kubrow update worked the same way.   What initially attracted me to the game was it's art direction and pace, but ultimately it's just not enough to keep me slogging through the same missions with almost zero context behind the effects of each one.   Don't fall for the freemium trap, avoid this game.

If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.  Ingredients: 1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter 2. 1/2 cup white sugar 3. 1/2 cup brown sugar 4. 1/4 cup water 5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon 6. 1 pinch salt 7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced 8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie   Directions: 1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C). 2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside. 3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices. 4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal. 5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust. 6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing. :) enjoy your Delicious pie :3

The entire game can be summarized into just being a timesink. The entire point of the game is to go to x location and kill y number of enemies, or survive for a specific amount of time. It seems fun at first because the game has great movement mechanics, but then you eventually get to the point where you question why you are playing the game. There is no real point to it. Often finding myself waiting to craft items in order to just level my frame or weapon makes it just really boring. That is what the game comes down to. Grinding in order to get the items you want or leveling up a warframe or weapon, or waiting to craft the item you want.  Then theres also microtransactions. That is the reason for waiting to craft your items. Because the game is F2P there are always going to be microtransactions but it's just an insult to the game. Around every corner they offer ways to buy things with their currency. Want a cape? Platinum. Want any accessories? Platinum. Want to not wait 3 days to craft a warframe? Platinum. Everything in this game is trying to nudge you to buy their currency. Although it can be written off that you can get platinum by trading with other players, but in order to get decent items to trade with other players you have to do the only objective of the game, grinding.  The entire game is just grinding. Some things make sense such as to level up a weapon or a warframe. But when you are grinding to no end to no goal what is the point? You can only level up the same warframe so many times, or weapons so many times before it gets boring. Although there is a large variety of ways to play with different weapons and warframes, a lot of it requires paying through their currency. There are a few slots you can have for free brefore you have to start paying for more slots. And that is the extent of the content. Leveling over and over again. Mowing down hundreds of enemies in a level hoping you get the item you want from it. Although there are diffeent mission types some of them are just dumb. Like having to survive 30 minutes for a chance of the drop you want, and then waiting another 30 minutes for another chance. And continuing that same process again and again. That may just be an over simpification of one of the mission types, but that is what the game comes down to. Just killing enemies over and over again. The game is just a timesink.   Overall the game seems nice at first but it very easily can get boring and extremely repetitive. It just isnt as much of a game as it seems to be. Sure there seems to be a lot of content, but when it is just the same thing in a different area it makes you think, why am I playing this?

This one's just not for me. While I'll definitely say I love the art direction, some of the concepts, and that the combat is fast paced and a ton of fun. However...  It only took me a few hours before I realized 'Oh balls, this game is a massive grindfest, isn't it?'   I don't recommend this game if you're the kind of peson who isn't up for grinding the same missions over and over again to try and earn something rather than buy it outright. Unless you REALLY like the gameplay or are willing to spend real money to entirely bypass the grind, this will probably get stale quickly.  To get anything in this game you need to either spend a disproportionately large amount of time grinding the same missions over and over for the resources you need to craft something, or break out that wallet and get anything immediately. Once I got enough credits, I went to the marketplace, and after I'd managed to get through all the pages of stuff that wants me to spend the premium currency on, I found where I could get stuff I earned with in game cash. I decided at this point I wanted a new secondary weapon. While I could afford any of the weapons available at my level, I couldn't craft any of them because they all required either resources I couldn't get anywhere, or required me to have other weapons already that weren't even for sale.   So screw it, I thought. I'll try one of the other warframes. I wanna try out Volt. Oh, they don't even sell it? Well, how about Ember? So I bought the blueprint for Ember, and then I needed all the parts of Ember which after looking up how to get them online, saw none of them were available to me either. But if I crack out my wallet I could have any gun available for my rank, and any warframe immediately. I would be fine with this if buying something wasn't so disproportionate to the amount of time needed to spend on it if you don't pay for it.  I might play this game some more if I have a little time and just want to kill a lot of things as a super cool space ninja. But I'm not going to be putting in the effort to actually work towards anything. In my own personal opinion, it's too grindy and repetitive for it to be worth the payoff.

With 45 hours (so far) i can say fairly that this game is one of the best (in my opinion) for 3 reasons.  (1) STORY: I know quite a few MMO's nowadays try to input a story in their games that directly revolve around a single player instead of a faction of players, and most fail at it. Warframe on the other hand has a story that fits well around the player, and if you like the 'faction' story type then you should know Warframe also has those with pretty much every update.  (2) VISUALS: I know next gen games are coming up with more and more realistic looking games, but the problem with that is not a lot of people have a gaming rig that can support the amount of RAM and CPU/GPU that it eats. Personally i have 6GB RAM and a 2.7GH CPU and i can run this on Ultra with not even a spike in FPS.   (3) GAMEPLAY: Not long ago when you told me to play an MMO for the gameplay i would think back al those WoW players and the Horridly boring gameplay it has. Now I have seen the light which shines the letters 'NOT AL MMO'S ARE BORING AS HELL.' and I'm not going to describe the Fighting and other gameplay because it would take to long, so if you're really interested in looking at it before you download go watch a clip of the gameplay and you'll see what i mean.  but i'm a hard critc too, so here is the things i do not like.  (1) MICRO-TRANSACTIONS: It seems to get anything potent with out have to wait weeks to a months to build equipment and the such you have to buy the equipment with MT or rush the building process with MT.  (2) THE WAIT: Although everybody whose become a vet of this game claims that if you play long enough you'll never have to make a Micro transaction, but thats crap because with every update brings a new ship or a new frame you'll have to wait months before the devs decide to put the blueprints to build them on the market.  Really those are my good points and bad point on the game.  So my rating is - 8.5/10

This game's not bad, and I DON'T hate it. That said let's move to cons and pros  CONS:  It's free so they make up for this by demanding either the player grinds like a MF to unlock new gear (armor, weps, etc), or of course pay up real money for such assets. What killed this game for me was this point, because I personally got bored with grinding with the same gear in a game which has such a plethora of interesting gear (so alluring from the marketplace!). Now if you don't/can't pay then grinding with a team or clan can definitely speed up the process and is almost required if you want to get gear in a timely manner - relatively speaking, it's still not super fast or anything. However if you're like me and just want to play this game casually with a friend or two then this means essentially never getting any new gear.   PROS: I liked this game for the time I played it, I really did. the mechanics of it are smooth and fluid, you feel like a total badass space-ninja, I mean that in itself is a great start. The combat is fun, which for how much grinding the game demands of you it NEEDS TO BE. And the gear in the game like I said is very unique and there's a lot of it. And of course it's multiplayer which is almost always a plus.   CONCLUSION: In the end I can't recommend it because I feel like I can't fully (hell not even close to fully) enjoy the game and have to miss out on experiencing much of what the game has to offer because my play style isn't compatible with this game. That lays out the biggest pros and cons I experienced, your experience will probably be a little different, but if you can't see your play style (or wallet) fitting into the mold this game has, then it might not be for you.

Warframe is one of those games that you can binge and maybe get bored after a couple weeks, but is always just as enjoyable to come back to. The devs for this game are dedicated and are quite consistent in updates and more free content. I know a few people are put off by the phrase 'Free-to-play' nowadays and for a lot of games that repulsion is justified. However Warframe has a pretty decent business model, you can buy weapons straight out with the premium currency - platinum, but you can also buy the blueprints for the same weapons for a reasonable amount of credits. The mechanics for this game are also fluid and consistent, I have not had too many problems in the way of bugs or glitches, and as someone who generally does not enjoy third person shooters, this one manages to keep me coming back for more. Partly resoponsible for that is the whole aesthetic of the game, the maps are a bit same-y but the whole space ninja thing is pretty awesome just as a concept and the look and feel of the abilities and weapons really fit it well.  Overall I would recommend this game, simple as pie.

Overall a good game, especially when it's free to play.  Pros: - Great atmosphere - Nice graphics - Intense gameplay leading to sense of accomplishment - Quite a bit of variety in weapons and playstyles (frames)  Cons: - Game stability needs a lot of work, it has a good number of bugs -- nickname: 'glitchframe' - Solo play is extremely unforgiving, not good for casual players who don't always want to team up with random folks - Many players want to rush through missions as fast as possible, reducing enjoyment of the actual game, and the game mechanics in some ways support this play style  Overall an 7/10, recommended, but needs some work.

Contrary to popular opinion, I believe that the older versions of this game were less enjoyable and more boring than the current versions of the game. The new version adds many different kinds of missions like Alerts which are basically special missions that have special rewards/loot that you pick up at the end of the mission (such as; Extra Credits - in-game currency, cosmetic items that are normally paid for via premium currency - platinum, and resources to build weapons and different Warframes).  Warframe is essentially a Free to play space ninja simulator, where you get to shoot space marines and robots to death or slice them up with a sword or shurikens (I know, it's already becoming the coolest game you have ever heard of). It's got a whole bunch of different playstyles in the form of different 'Warframes', which are basically just armor suits that have different abilities (that also apparently can change your gender... MAGIC), all of the different Warframes have unique abilites and strengths that set them apart from one another. Some have increased armor and health to make them more viable and powerful in melee combat, and others have increased proficiency with ranged weapons like bows and guns. You can customize each and every one of them with cosmetic items that are bought using the games premium currency - platinum. Cosmetic items obviously do not give any bonus and there is no 'pay to win' factor regarding them, in fact, there is no pay to win factor in the game whatsoever seeing as it is a mainly co-op game, and also due to the fact that pretty much every premium item in the game (including items that increase the power of weapons and Warframes) is obtainable by in-game means, such as special events (like traders that show up every once in a while selling special cosmetic items for ingame credits or a different currency known as 'Ducats' that are normally bought using platinum.)  So pretty much, there is no 'pay to win' factor in this game unless you consider getting a different coloured dog 'pay to win'...  It's kind of grindy at times but if you're like me and don't really care about that then this game can be fun at all times.   Now the only gripe I have about this game is sort of scraping the bottom of the barrel... The platinum pricing is kind of ridiculous, you can buy 75 platinum for 5 Dollars... To buy one single Warframe, it costs anywhere from 75 platinum all the way to 325! That's alot of real money. But like I said, you can get all of the Warframes for ingame cash instead of paying real money, so it's not really a problem for Free to Play players, only for people who want to speed up their progress with Platinum currency.

So now that I have an idea of how to play this game I can say I reccomend it but with caveats:  First its opaque, when you go into the equip screen the game looks pay 2 win or like a demo because pretty much everything costs premium currency. HOWEVER what the game doesn't tell you is that you can buy blueprints of everything on there and craft it yourself. HOWEVER HOWEVER that requires grinding ingame money and materials in order to make those weapons.  The intial offering of planets looks small but you need to unlock more by killing bosses and getting specific planet nav coordinates.  Now this is the most important thing I'm going to mention here, because its practically omni important: if you don't enjoy the moment to moment gameplay inside of missions you will not enjoy Warframe. If you aren't willing to spend real money to get things faster the game is grindy requiring you to grind for both money and materials to craft everything. However everything that effects gameplay(aka eveerything but cosmetics) is craftable without paying a cent. HOWEVER 2.0 it requires a lot of grinding to craft everything. So if you don't enjoy the basics of gameplay this game isn't for you.  The one thing I do like about the grinding is that there are a lot of smaller goals in upgrading your weapons and warframe to keep you going. Lots of percentage upgrades you can slot into and upgrade on your gear as you level it up.   So basically:  play through the tutorial and see if the gameplay appeals to you  be prepared to look up a guide on stuff if you don't have massive amounts of money to spend The game IS free to play, truly free to play the main way they get money out of you is through cosmetics and avoiding grinding Look into blueprints on the market, not just the equip screen, the equip screen makes the game look like a paid for demo(its not) Level ranges for missions do not refer to your mastery level, they refer only to the level of enemies you will be facing there nothing more Leveling your items on their own does not increase their stats at all, they increase the number of upgrades you can equip on them completing a mission unlocks adjacent missions, somewhere on newly unlocked planets are the nav coordinates for the next planet in the progression

TL;DR I would like to have an in-game way of earning slots for new weapons and warframes without trading or using real money. The new player expiriance is in need of some improvement. I still find the base game fun.   You can't actually use credits to buy weapon/warframe slots. You can't even craft the slots. The only way, as far as I know, to get those extra slots is to buy them with real money or go through the trading system to get the special in-game currency to buy the slots. There might be another way to get them, but the game doesn't explain these things well.  This games' text tutorials need to be replaced with something more hands-on. Seriously, text tutorials are not fun to sit through. It put me off when I started playing.  The rest of the game is slow, but fun. It's the kind of game you can jump in and jump out of once in a while without feeling like you are missing out on anything, or, if you are board, sit and play for hours. There is fun to be had. The amount of content and coustomization in this game is amazing. Modifying the apperance of anything you own in this game is possible. I've heard the very end of the game is sometimes refered to as 'Fashionframe'.  If I had money to spend on this game, I would just get some slots and maybe some extra color palets.   Extra note to devs: Please fix your bugs. I was fighting a boss and it became literally impossible near the end. Not hard, unbeatable.

Good:  -Love the artstyle of the game, reminds me of mass effect and halo series. -Gameplay is fun and satisfying slice enemies in two or unleash unique powers on your enemies! -Tons of ways to modify your character with mod cards that add new effects to your weapons and your warframe. -You can earn everything in the game for free if you dont mind waiting ALOT except for cosmetic items. -Game is hosted by whoever creates the party so you can use this to your advantage and if you do happen to get a bad or slow host the enemies lag and slow, not you so it doesnt penalize you. -Tons of weapons to choose from ranging anywhere from Assault Rifles, shotguns, sniper rifles, pistols, throwing knifes, and tons of unique plasma and laser weapons(puts call of duty weapon choices to a shame.) -Tons of Melee weapon choices to choose from all unique in their own way ranging from greatswords, duel wielding swords, huge hammers, throwing glaives that bounce around enemies, axes, you name it its in it.  Bad:  -Overpriced real money to game value ratio of items(15 dollars for a color pack!!!!! yea its dumb) -Start with limited colors to decorate your warframe and weapons with no other way to get colors other than real money. -The crafting times on blueprints of weapons warframes and sentinel pets are REDICULOUS, weapons take 12-24 hours REAL TIME to complete and warframes take 3 days 12 hours(yeah its pretty insane, I can see why a lot of people give up playing soon.) -Very slow paced at the beginning due to the horrendous crafting system with very limited weapons/warframes. -Feels as if this game belongs on Facebook due to all the crafting wait time restrictions witch are pointless. -Repetive reworks of art in the levels and enemies and a few glitches here and there.  MY RATING: 7/10  IF they got rid of the horrendous wait time on the crafting system and lowered their prices a bit more people would have the patience to stick around the game, if you look past that it truly is a crown jewel of a game.

My impressions from one hour of gameplay:  The launcher labels the game as a beta, despite the game releasing on steam over two years ago.  The movement does not feel good to control. Most of your movement options take away control and force you on a fixed path, with just a hair of air control. Melee attacks go in the direction of the camera, rather than the direction your character is facing. You can climb up basically any surface by mashing the jump button repeatedly. There's very little degree of analog control. The control tutorial doesn't even require that you do most of the things it asks of you. I'm surprised this kind of stiff control gets a pass from action gamers.  I never felt like I was in any danger whatsoever, even when standing still, surrounded by enemies, under fire from multiple directions. Standing still and shooting at stuff was sufficient for every enemy encounter I saw.  On a gamepad where there seem to be a few missing button mappings (weapon switching, deflecting attacks with my sword, possibly others). Button prompts are displayed as keyboard keys, no matter if you're playing on a gamepad.  Overall, I'm not impressed. Given that other reviewers are complaining about grinding and overpriced transactions and that the game isn't even satisfying to control, I'm going to pass on this.

Free to play co-op shooter, still in beta, and sometimes little bugs really bother me, but overall it's a really nice game, with a lot of potential. Curious what the future holds for this one.  - Edit on 20150313: the dev crew seems to listen a lot to their players, which is amazing, but I did quit this game a while ago now. I've played it for probably more than a year, played a lot, and it's a nice game, with loads of potential. However, the pvp system is still horrible, and I'm sick of the pve grinding. Every time you think you are close to finally being done with grinding, more grinding appears. It's not like the usual grindfest rpgmmo's, it's way better than that, but still not something I want to do. Ever since the void trader it's impossible to get the things you need (unless you don't have to worry about spending time on a job, kids, or other things), so I see no reason to keep playing this game on a regular basis. It is a very nice shooter where the melee combat system is equally good, or in my opinion even better than the shooting system. Pretty good game, but not for me, at least not anymore. Have fun with it, but don't expect to reach max rank, or get every single weapon or mod in the game if you start playing this. I do miss the combat system in a lot of other games tho..

I...Dont know how to tell you this. But, Warframe is a game about Robot Mushroom Ninja's going through space to fight some rejects from Gears of War and some people with Boxes for a face ad there pet dogs, While doing some of the sickest parkous ninja matrix flips you'll ever see in your life.  But, on technical sides, Warframe is a Run-and-Gun Ninja Simulator, and perhaps one of the best ever made, as it genuinely feels like a fast paced ultra-thrill ride everytime you play. Though, when you play it enough, you start to figure out that its less Ninja whoo-hoo fun time, And quickly turns into a Over-all's and Cow's Farm-tastic MMO.  6/10. Its really fun when you get addicted, and have those moments of jumping, running, killing while listening to any up-beat techno music you can find (Or Up-beat pop song. I like listening to Bonnie Tyler's 'I need a hero' myself.) But, when you get past that, its a hollow grind fest.  Though, Props to the fact that, in a sense, you can obtain basically any item without needing to pay real cash for it. But what do i know, im gonna play it some more by the time im done writing this.

I definately recommend this game to everyone, it's absoluetly amazing! I just can't get enough of this game, I've only been playing it for about 6 days now and I have lots of time put into this game.  For just a free to play game, this one is a lot of fun, and it has amazing graphics plus it runs really smooth. Some people say that you have to buy platinum if you want decent stuff. But actually, the only time you have to use platinum, is when you want cosmetics (i.e. Helmet, syandana, better colours, etc...), more warframe/weapon slots, or to purchase something right away. Now, I would recommend using the 50 platinum they give you to start off with, to buy more slots, because the cosmetic stuff isn't really that important, where as slots are.  Basically everything else, you can get blueprints for, then go around to the different planets and missions to gather the materials to build them. Some blueprints (warframes for example) require that you fight bosses more than once or go into the void so you can get things such as, the helmet, chassis, and systems. Yes, this can take some time, but it's worth it in the end.  Overall, I think this is a great game! The only negatives I could think of, is how some maps are used more than once, even though you're on a totally different planet, and the fact that you have to buy more colours with platinum. But, other than that, this game is great, and if you haven't already, try it out! It's free :D

The F2P that keeps on giving.  To my understanding, DE played a critical role in the development of other well known blockbusters (Unreal & Unreal Tournament, to name a few), and has a great insight as to what makes a game fun to play. The developers are always working on new content, and revamping anything that becomes dated on a prompt schedule. Bugs do emmerge from time to time, but they are usually patched within hours to days of discovery.  As of the past few patches, a well written and immersive story mode has been implemented that explores the origin of the Warframes. I'm not gonna lie, it's top quality and worth playing if not for that quest line. The gameplay is awesome. Mix-and-matching a primary weapon, secondary, melee, and of course, your Warframe allows for a refined level of preferred combat playstyle tweaking, and a customized player experience. 9/10.  Also, SPACE NINJAS!

I've been going on and off on this game for a long time and recently picked it up again. I was honestly surprised with the ton of changes that happened while I was gone. The maps got larger, the enemies more diverse, but alot of the warframes were also nerfed! Oh well you take what you get and I haven't played another game yet that has had me sitting infront of my PC playing it and thinking about it and even dreaming about it. The best part, in my opinion is the fact that you can honestly grind your way to the top. Even the plat you can get from selling off the grinding loot can be more than enough. The prime warframes are another fun part, not only do they look badass, but the race to get them before they're vaulted and never seen again for who knows how long is also a plus. All in all even with all the recent hate and nerfs and kinda repetitive quests I still love this game and can't get over it, atleast not anytime soon. P.S: The second Dream questline was MINDBLOWING...I would say it was game changing, although the focus part desperately needs a re-work with how long it take to even get a single level(average of a few hundred everytime i get the beacon) with 50-70k points.  Anyway That's All Folks!!!

Okay so here goes.  The new update has upset many people and I can see why it would. DE are changing the game like any game would to try and keep people playing. People will complain for a few weeks and either learn to live with it or quit.  The game itself is great. Everything just makes you feel like a badass (even healing your allies) combat is fast, fluid and fun.  The grind is a big reason why many poeple play the game and I would like to think of it as a double edged sword...  Upon playing nearly 500 hours of the game I have come to realise the truth that DE are trying to hide. Maybe with their new updates they keep adding.  The game has no point playing it at all. Not one bit. All your time farming, leveling and just overall grinding (to be the very best.... kill me) has not actually point other to give you 'bragging rights' so to speak (even though people dont because a nice community but I think deep down everyone does some without thinking about it) Getting that 20+ MR rank will take you quite a long time and you really don't have anything to do once you got all the weapons and frames you personally want. Yes there are quests even though only really one of the quests actually has meaning to the lore of the game (The second dream) and the PvP is bad because the game was not originally made for PvP in mind...  Another thing I would say for people to be wary off is the buffing and nerfing that DE does to frames and weapons. They are way to heaving in nerfing and buffing things. Somethings will come up and just look insanse. People will then hop on the train and forma the 'god weapon' 5+ times and then DE just say '♥♥♥♥ you' and nerf it to trash tier. Some people like it but I for one do not like it and I wish they would just balance instead of just making some weapons and frames unplayable compared to other frames (Love you oberon)  Overall if you are one of those people that like the grinding for the sake of grinding and want to show of your sweet MR level to people then this game is pretty much perfect. However if you play this game to get something out of the grind then I am sorry to say that DE hasn't really got much instore for you. However I still HIGHLY suggest you just try the game out.  Another this is the community in this game is one of the best I have seen and if you need help don't be afraid to ask in region. There is always people their to help you.  Sorry this has been a quick review I wanted to keep it kind of short as I could talk about this game for days and if anyone has comments or their own oppinions on the game leave a comment as I will be very intrested to see other people opinions on the game.  Good Hunting!

The premise of the game is a little odd, and the plot is well dry boring and best ignored unless you like obscure and wierd space drama. So moving on, the game play has alot of innovative idea's poorly implemented. So lets start with the big elephant in the room, the free to play set up of the game is a pharce. Without spending real money on platinum or items you are at a huge disadvantage. Gear , experience and money come slow grinding, not a little slow but insanely slow. Two weeks of playtime my gear is all around level 10 and everyone keeps telling me it gets better. So why suffer through crappy game play to get to end game content that once again favors people who are willing to dump real money in the game? Ahh spend money yourself you say, well here's my counter. When you swing weapons they follow a static path much like an old style mortal kombat game. Meaning things like hills or rocks or a slight incline will cause your melee weapon to whiff. Secondly try wall running or duck jumping, again confounded by terrair rocks poor control and slight inclines. And finally the deal breaker , mission types. Certain missions like say the spy missions , wretched at best. Where one twitchy mob or missclick causes mission failure. Now throw into that ability missfires and buggy mobs are just part of the game. I'm not talking about stuff that you can compensate with skill over, I'm talking about the game randomly screwing you because of crappy code. Hmm I shot the dude on the alarm yet he triggered it after he died, well balls. Or my favorite running an extermination mission and the wildlife attacks him and knocks him into terrain making it impossible for me to complete the mission. And my final beef with the game is its revive system, limited revives that you have to spend real money on to refresh or you fail on missions because you're out of revives when your randomly screwed over with a bug, Deal breaker. This game should not be played by anyone unless this sort of half arsed game design is your niche.

Warframe is by far one of my favorite games and for sure no game is comparable.  There are so many warframes in this game, there is one for sure to fit your playstyle if your in to 3rd person shooter / stealth games / mmo's  You can make this a fast paces shooter or a slow paced stealth killing game  There are A LOT of different mission types   There are many many MANY weapons in this game to benefit your playstyle, I cant even exagerate how many creative weapons are in this game  There are many mods in this game (Modules are basically parts to your weapons that make them more OP with Crit+Status effects, et cet.)  Varius enemy types you need to keep in mind when facing hard missions. There will be various enemy types you despise that make this game more fun by killing them.  Clans + alliances, so you can get the benefit of having friends to play with, and the access to more weapons like any MMO has .  Then theres Archwings - Ultra Amazing warframe jetpacks with OP abilities like warframes have - Archwing was a whole new game to me.  The only cons to this game I can think of is its a bit repetitive - and playing with random players you will not be able to execute the missions the way you want it done

A fun game with an interesting set of moves and combos that make each class very different.  That said, I found out tool late into my gameplay that resurrections, while doled out in abundance when you first start, require real-world money to acquire more of. It should be noted that there are upgrades that likewise require these platinum tokens as well. While we know it's free to play, most others out there give you the option to grind your way into extra lives, but this game is more free-to-play ...for the first 12 lives. After that (and it will come quickly) you either have to pay up, or bow out of every game that you happen to encounter one to many enemies.

Warframe is an Awesome 3rd Person Mutliplayer Coop Shooter, there is variety of Bosses, Characters and Planets. I Would Dislike only the same interior of some maps but when its only an interior its supposed to be on a spaceship so it makes sense why on different planets and same factions are same interiors of Ships. The Exterior of Planets is Amazing, rain, snow or sun.   Characters and building: there are many Characters or Warframes, usualy you will have to scavange blueprints and parts for it through bosses of some planets but it doesn't take long time to 'farm' but the longest is the building it self: Parts for Warframes: 12 hours, Warframe it self: 3 entire days.   There are 5 Factions: |Grineer|- Enemies from Earth. |Corpus|- technologically advanced humans that have a variety of troops and drones. |Orokin|: Corrupted by power and eternal live theese Soldiers Live Longer than every other faction, unless you came and kill them all, |Infested|: All Kinds of Other Factions and some exclusive Infested Enemies, these are things are infected with some sort of biological weapon or virus. |Tenno|: Ancient warriors that fight for freedom and truth and you playing as one of their Soldiers, Tenno are the only ones that can controle the Warframes and their power.  Nice things!: +Graphics!  + Character and Weapons variety  + Mods that can change entire game  + Updates that always add a Warframe and Guns  + Alerts or Time Limited mission plus Challanges  + Stalker and Other Assasins that can suprise you and drop something good if killed   Not so nice things about this game:  - Long Building times that can only be skipped by paying 5$  - Hard Levling up on profile level that rewards you with acces to weapons.  - Sometimes awfull long loading and Ping Problems.   Unselected:  +/ - Platinum isn't soo needed but you can buy Completed weapons and Warframes for it also some Prime Gear.  I would give this game a perfect score of 97/100 Cause of its variety and Updates that always add something new!   Please if you will notice any mistake feel free to write it down. Sorry for any Mistaked that could i have made, your RedyD.

If you are having second thoughts on weather you should get this game, let me end it for you by saying that you should.  Everything about this game is extremely fun and entirely possible for any player. Yes you can spend money to get things such as weapons or warframes, but the only things you have to spend money on are completely cosmetic things such as colors and scarves.  Yes, you will have to grind to get things in this, but if you have friends to play this with, or take every combat situation as something new, it doesn't even feel like grinding, it feels like playing and like fun.  And even though the mission have limited types, the amazing devolopers are always adding new things to keep the game fresh and new.  Even if they didn't though, a mission could change completely based on what Lotus (your contact on everything going on) thinks you should do, or your own actions on other missions.  And then there are weapons you can only get if your in a clan. You can still get them even if you don't get into a huge and powerful clan.  I know this because I am in a clan with one other active player, and have 2/3 of the weapons and warframes researched.  Trust me when I say it, you will love this game. Just look at my hours on it.

I can't seem to pull away... I try and try but Im sucked in...  Pros:  #1: Very well optimized, the game runs fast and smooth. #2: Heavily Co-Op, Got friends? Of Course you do? Don't always want to deal with competitive gamplay? HERES WARFRAME! #3: A suprisingly deep universe for a free to play game with no franchise or books to base all there backdrop on. Honeslty the quest chain of 'Natah' 'Stolen Dreams' and 'Second Dream' are huge for people who get lore boners. pay attention and obsorb this games history and lore, and then play those three quests.... No regrets! #4: Cool Concept and great gameplay! I mean common, space katanas and laser cannons in the same game.  Cons: #1: RNG will rule your life! #2: There is a bit of a learning curve, and honeslt they are working on the new player experiance. #3: Archwing (A certain ingame mission type) Is flat out broken, and honestly has no real purpose to make it something people WANT to play. Not that I want to be forced to play this broken Mode! #4: There is no cure for Warframe fevor, Once you got it... it's pretty much like hurpies you can get it to go away for awhile bit it will keep popping up!  While Hours played does not mean everything I think my time speaks for itself as to how much I am addicted, and how much I know mechanics wise about the game. but I emplore you to play it and decide for yourself, it's free and you can always stop playing... IF YOU CAN CURE THE WARFRAME FEVOR!! MUAHAHAHA!!! Back the RNG farm!

Ok, here's what you'll get with this game: A third person cooperative shooter with elements of Phantasy Star Online/Diablo loot runs, procedurally generated levels, a space-based ninja flight sim, a nice crafting system, quirky and amusing bosses, a good in-game economy and absolutely no pay to win anything.  The only things you can use the in-game currency 'platinum' that you pay real dosh for is to speed up crafting, expanding your inventory, or buy cosmetic things. And you start the game with a nice wad of the stuff to boot.  For a free to play this is THE MOST generous and non-exploitative game I have ever seen.  Also you play as a ninja, run&gun around slashing space marines, alien monsters and robots. The graphics are stellar and its just plain fun.  As of writing this I have logged more than 1200 hours into the game. I don't plan on stopping any time soon.

so, where should i start? i played the game for over 1600 hours according to steam. I come back from time to time to check for updates and new content.   to put things in a nutshell,you are a space ninja. (a warframe) and you have to kill the bad guys, basically. you can do crazy tricks like walljumping and bullet jumping. each warframe comes with their own unique abilities, looks and aesthatics. want to be a swamp monster?no problem. want to be a mummy? no problem. want to be a pink colored sassy pseudo body builder?no problem. i love a LOT of things in this game. but that doesn't mean the game comes without it's flaws. so here's a couple of pros and cons;  -Pro's- -A lot of class diversity -A huge variation of weapons  -A lot of customization on both frames and weapons -The game offers interesting co-op gameplay -The devs listen to their players -Both great artistic and unique tilesets and npc's -Companions :D (cats dogs and small flying robots) -Devs do weekly platinum givaways (ingame currency) -Red text <3 -One of the lesser toxic communites out there -F2P! -#Fashionframe -Weekly (mostly interesting) devstreams  -Cons- -Very Few and kind of repetetive mission types -The community doesn't tend to take criticism too lightly -Not a whole lot of content to go through -There's no real endgame (especially after spectres of the rails launched) -A LOT of RNG based farming (it's basically the main drive for the game) -Unbalanced pvp -It can take up to 3 days to craft new items -The game wont pose a challenge at all after after you get some of the less basic stuff -Leechers -A lot of bugs... -Clunky interfaces -Today's strongest weapon is tomorrow's mastery fodder  Know that the game is still in beta and receives monthly updates. The devs put a lot of work and effort in the game.  So obviously some of the pro's and con's might shift a little over time. I dont think there's a whole lot more to say.  All in all, not a bad game. The game is worth to give a try at the very least. I'ts a F2P game afterall!

Warframe. This game is amazing, to say the least. The AI was actually smart, and ran away to get off a good shot when I rushed up with my amazing Excalibur warframe with a huge sword out. This game also impressed me with how not pay-to-win it was. I expected every weapon to be locked behind a paywall, (because it's a free game.) but the game impressed me by adding blueprints available to purchase with earnable in-game money. The characters are very cool, and I found infinite pleasure in watching a surprised enemy slowly stumble back after I chopped the top half of his body off, watching in gruesome detail, thanks to the incredible graphics, that would put most $60 games to shame. Now, moving on to the bad things. The other characters were in fact locked behing the disgusting, overpriced paywall, angering me incredibly. I'm about 9 hours into this game, and I have still noticed little to no variety about the enemy characters. Every few missions, you find one new enemy character, but that usually only shows up for one or two missions, isn't exciting, and they are few and far between.  In conclusion, I shall quickly recap on what I think about Warframe. Graphics: 9/10. Variety:6/10. Sound: 7.5/10. Characters: 8/10. AI: 8.5/10. Overall rating: 8.3916. Warframe, recommended to any fan of RPG's or TPS's.

GAMEPLAY:  7/10  STORY:  5/10 (based on lore)  ONLINE:  7/10  Very P2W (Pay to win). You can buy everything and they even have donor deals that give you more elite items for giving over $100. Never the less, this game is fun to play with friends or online, just make sure you have a decent internet connection. Since it is still beta, there a few glitches(like flinging yourself across the map) but they are more 'WTF was that!' and don't destroy the gameplay. Most of the weapons you want are also craftable for mostly resonable resources and in game cost. So P2W slightly balances out for weapons. The different Warframes and difficult to get, so either be prepaired to fork over some cash to get the one you want or grind for the resources you need to make it. The Warframe you start out with is prefectly viable and works, so they arent forcing you to P2W.  Online is decent, people a generally very nice though not often helpful (whether though lack of knowledge or lack of input). Except lag issues though, especially with lots of other people.  I only recommend this because it is free, and you dont have to pay to have decent items to play with.

Warframe was fun for a while and running around as a space ninja is very cool, but it ended up being very repetitive after a time. Having only 3 factions to fight in the same boring corridors got old very quick. In addition, the way the mod system is designed mean that weapon and warframe upgrading essentially becomes dependent on the games Random Number Generator meaning that just playing for a long time does not guarantee any sort of improvement in a players stats. It eventualy felt like a grind to just find the right mods and it causes players to rush through levels just to reach the end instead of having fun fighting. The game is also very pushy about microtransactions by making some items completely unobtainable unless you purchase them with ingame money (platinum) and by making the creating of some items (namely, warframes) very tedious to do on your own by requiring you to posess the blueprints for 3 different parts, craft them each, then craft the final warframe with yet another bluerpint. By comparison, you can purchase the completed frame along with a pre-installed catalyst (an item that improves the mod capacity of a warframe) for a few bucks.  I feel like I've had my fill of this game for now. Perhaps I will come back later if some serious changes are made to the progression system.

I know technicaly warframe was based around the PvE and all. but one of the reasons i played it so long was to get better stuff and play with them in the PvP. and now they have changed warframe settings so that everyone entering PvP is stuck with unranked/unmodded gear and frame. so testing builds out in the PvP is no longer useful. and testing out how your build holds up against others no longer works either. now all that matters for the pvp is that you have the higher base stats.  The pve is ok but it seems like it gets a little TOO easy after a time. with the right build and game type you coul literally endlessly destroy your enemies. I use a simple valkyr with high ranked armor and a blade that drains hp for every hit. with that alone i cannot be killed instantly and i can heal back everything it does to me. so in a defense match I could literally just sit on the defend zone and cut up anything that comes. especially if its an infestation map with only melee units. atleast with ranged units you still need to dodge/ deflect. and run around in order to cach your enemies. but its pretty much the same thing for me.  the other pve game modes make it a bit tougher to tank and all since you have to move around quickly, though a maxed rush mod fixes valkyrs weakness there. and when in doubt just using ripline can get you around faster then almost anything else. so i guess valkyr would be the cheapest warframe there is. especialy with the hp drainin attack. with the right mods you could probably make the other frames just as cheap though. so its just a matter of your visual tastes on your character i guess. anyway i probably won;t be playing this game again. unless they make a way to CHOOSE wether to have an unranked PvP or not. atleast that way then if people wanna go with all unranked items its their perogative. don't force unranked and unmodded items on everyone.

Warframe is one of those games that's a diamond in the rough. It's a really great game only if you're willing to invest some serious time into it. It's easy to play this game for 30 minutes or an hour and say, 'I don't know what I'm doing.' or 'This game is bland and generic.' You really have to sit down with this game and give it some time before you find your own unique niche and fighting style. With each warframe you play with you realize you have to adjust and adapt your tactics to the strategic situation. Each frame has it's own unique powers so it's good to know how to utilize them for the right situation at the right time.   The more difficult battles in the game must be calculated carefully. Attributing factors about how to fight can be simply broken down like this: speed vs power, power vs technique, technique vs speed, power vs crowd control and crowd control vs stealth. Those where just some examples of factors to take into consideration when finding your fighting style but there are many more. Now with the right modifications for weapons and warframes you can begin to merge the abilities together into a super effective fighting style but again that takes time.   The fact that the game has multiplayer co-op in it as well really helps with the later levels of this game. Trying to go solo in this game works but for so long before you're going to need reinforcements. With the right team and proper weapons you can seem almost unstoppable at times. But that's also the beauty of the design of this game. It always makes you feel like you can always get stronger without making you feel like you're invincible and you have to stop trying. There's always something or someone out there that's just little bit stronger than you that's what keeps you going in your pursuit to improve yourself.   As I said before the game is a diamond in the rough and there are some obnoxious sections or situations the game might put you through. For example the drop rate for certain rare materials is ultra low meaning you'll be grinding on a level until you get the materials you need making so some stages very redundant. Or you'll find out you need to clear a specific level with a squad yet nobody breathes on that particular level you're trying to get through which makes waiting painful at times. If you don't feel like waiting for a squad to show up, they give you the option to start the mission by yourself anytime. But be forewarned you better be super prepared if you're going solo.   Minors flaws and nuisances aside, all and all it's a great game and a good time that's definitely worth a try. Even better when you bring your friends along for the journey. As with all reviews give it a try and play the game yourself at least once before you take someone else's review as gospel or fact and you decide for yourself whether or not the reviewer made a fair point or not.

Welp, straight into the pros and cons first  cons first  - has some pretty bad bugs (what game doesn't?) - some abilities and weapons may be sucky (what game doesn't have sucky weapons?) - there are no more cons, move on  Pros next  + bugs get fixed pretty quickly (some minor bugs are friggin hilarious and are purely visual). and the bugs that do appear are rather minor. + The Second Dream (it's a quest. PLAY IT. To start the quest chain:  use a scanner on a 'sentient'; a blue glowing, floating thing that makes a very distinctive noise. You can tell if they spawn by the flashing blue lights/ screen flickering. This will start you on the quest 'Natah' which is the prerequisite quest for The Second Dream.  ) + unique weapons and 'classes' (each Warframe and weapon excluding primes which are stronger versions of the base versions. You can get these with some effort as well.) + you can get everything functional in the game with some effort. + some cosmetic items (helmets and some weapon skins) are available during 'alert missions' + Music is glorious. + incredible cutscenes + Magnificent story-writing, and world-building + The three above create some of the most incredible things I have experienced in electronic media. Seriously. Cutting Onions. + Developers listen to the community and put user-made content into the game. And credit them. + more awesome content is constantly being added. + With very few exceptions: you can customize/recolour everything.  Tips = Hold sprint-hold crouch-melee is how you spin-attack with a melee weapon (it increases damage) = Hold Crouch-jump to bullet jump. You can aim where you want to go. You can even do this in the air after your first jump. Also, you can double jump. = Aiming while in the air makes you glide. = Scanners can be purchased from the store using credits (normal in-game currency) and are used to fill out the in-game cyclopedia. = Be mindful of your environment, there are explosive barrels (the video-game staple) and fragile glass (not normally a problem, but in a spaceship...well...don't worry though, you cant get sucked out, you just need to hack a console). = There are glass floors.Not in spaceships, though, and you can't break them. So feel free to walk all over that glass. = Orokin Catalysts and Reactors you can get every now and then through special alert missions. = Resources only drop from specific locations.  = However, some resources, such as Tellurium, drop from certain mission types ie. Tellurium drops from Archwing missions (missions where you equip an 'archwing' which are personal spacecraft and fly around in space. You get the first one from a questline) = after clearing all missions on a planet, you can use extractors to get resources from that planet while you play other missions. = The platinum (premium currency) you start with is 'free platinum' and cannot be traded with other players and will be used first before using platinum that you purchased. = save your starting platinum for getting more slots for warframes or weapons (slots for   more  warframes or weapons) = highlighting missions on the system map will tell you what type of mission it is = top left of the system map, you can choose to set the 'room type' to 'public' where anyone can join/ you join a random group, 'friends only' and 'solo', which are self-explanatory. = recommended to try public on harder missions or missions where you are unsure of what to do; other players will often help out greatly = coordinate with your team - Strategy is your greatest weapon. = there are locations which you can trade and interact with other players on certain planets (locations depend on your platform: pc, PS, or Xbox) = When you want to know about drop lists, stats, and such; Google is your friend = Patience is key = all weapons and warframes you acquire will need to be built (with a some exceptions). They will also need time to be built, weapons take 12hrs, whereas warframes take (depending on how long it takes to get the parts and resources) between 4 days to a week to build. (so far only one frame takes a week, every other warframe takes 4 days. This time assumes you have all the necessary parts and resources) = when you obtain a certain amount of level with your equipment your exp bar under your icon in the esc menu will glow, letting you know that you are ready to take the test to ascend in rank (Mastery Rank. Some weapons are 'Mastery locked', requiring a minimum rank to build). These tests range from parkour to stealth to combat, some with time limits, some without. = don't fret if you feel progress is slow, you'll get there eventually  Warning, side effects using awesome abilities may include: sudden euphoria, inability to say anything except scream'THIS IS AWESOME', unstoppable fits of giggling, feelings of being overpowered and scary (against the AI), and Terrible, Terrible Damage (against your enemies). Or just plain old have fun.  Have fun and a nice day!  P.S. seriously, go watch some of those prime warframe introduction trailers such as Nekros Prime and Saryn Prime. Overall, I highly recommend Warframe.  I like the whole 'space ninja' aesthetic of this game. The developers did a good job of making something original. There are some valid criticisms to the complexity of the game, but at least there is a great wiki and good developer support. The developers are constantly adding new content, which can actually be a little bit overwhelming at times, but there's always new stuff to do. The developers are involved with the community, and are generally fast with the bug fixes. Did I mention the bugs? There's new bugs with every update, but most of it is minor stuff that gets fixed quickly.  Platinum: You can spend large amounts of real world money on the premium currency and end up with very little to show for it. However, if you are smart about how you spend platinum, you can avoid some of the early-game 'grinding' and get some fun cosmetic items as well. Warframe is certainly not a 'pay-to-win' game, but at some point you're really going to need some Plat. If you don't want to spend real money, you can get all of the Plat you'll ever need through in-game trades. I have most of the cosmetic stuff, 90% of the weapons, and all of the warframes, but I only purchased $25 of Plat when I first started playing.

People who write reviews probably have a lot of gameplay time on this game, over 100 hours, but as if you are getting this game you will probably be a new player with no idea how to play and as I am still in early game myself I felt this might be helpful for the new players looking to get stuck in.  The game itslef is a MMO CO-OP shooter in which you and a squad, or just you solo, tackle missions in order to gather resources, progress the story and reach other planets. The game can be a bit overwhelming at first but as you progress through missions you will unlock various things on your ship, like the foundary where you build items, and through ranking up, new mods and weapons. The game does try to slowly introduce these to try and let them sink in but overall you might feel a little overwhelmed by them.  The community itself is nice enough but not very welcoming or helpful to new players despite the best efforts of the developers to make it so, if you do find youslef stuck or confused a forum or YouTube guide will probably be your best bet.  All in all if you're intrested by it then pick it up, it's free, what's stopping you?   Good luck out there Tenno

I have 13.3 hours of this game on record at the time of writing this and I feel like I've only scratched the surface. There is so much to explore in this game. Every time I get on to play, I learn something new. And I'm not talking about hard stuff, I'm talking about control basics (for instance). Now I think I've learned all the moves that my character can do but I probably haven't. Btw, the movement controls is my favorite aspect of the game. It's real easy to learn, but impossible to master.   Warframe never ceases to surprise me. You think you've got it figured out and then you realize something new you've never done before. I've never played a mission that was exactly like a previous one. Every day on Warframe is a new adventure. Love this game.

+ Slick combat + Fun ninja-esque running and sliding everywhere (especially the walls) + Really cool frames, makes you WANT to earn them. they're also unique and offer great versatility to pit them apart. + great drop in and out coop as you set out to do missions + genuinely good community that has great twitch broadcasts and fun seasonal events  ~ It's free to play so you should expect this: you either need to pay for some things to happen faster or just earn it slowly an ddo some grinding. It's a trade off but one I gladly made a lot. I'm happy to have put some money in this game given how much entertainment I've gotten out of it. Felt this needed to be a mixed reaction since yes this will become a wall if you have a goal, especially for your speedsters.  Honestly I don't have anything largely negative to say aboout the game. It's extremely fun and anything negative really comes from the waiting or grinding you'll experience but well that's a free to play game for ya.

I have never taken time to review a game but I had to make an exception for this. This is literally and without exaggeration the most boring and monotonous game I have ever played in my life.  Here how you play. Walk through a corridor to find the button to open the door to the next corridor to get to the end of the level. Sometimes there will be two buttons and you will require the presence of another player. A random online player will appear in your game out of nowhere to achieve this and then you can go about ignoring each other. Enemies without AI will shoot at you from the side lines while you ignore them and continue on finding more buttons to open more corridors.  - Environments are bland and unchanging. I'm not sure what my environment was supposed to be, but it looked like an abandoned warehouse labyrinth. The main features are long corridors between store rooms with a terminal operated door on each end, repeated ad nauseam. In space. I have not seen level design this bad before.  - Enemies are indistinct drones who do nothing interesting but stand on the spot and wait for death whilst very slowly shooting peas at you. I had to deliberately stand still in packs of them to find what it would take to kill me.  - The sword doesn't actually cut, it seems to just do damage points. You have to press E to 'cut the enemy in half' about 5 times to do enough damage points to kill them, while they shoot you at point blank, doing of course, no damage.  - I don't know what my character was supposed to be doing or why, other than opening doors to more doors. I hope I never find out because I'm sure it will make the game even worse.  I'm afraid I've actually made the game sound far better than it is, so whatever good impression you get from that, divide it by 50.  If you have played games before there will be nothing new here for you. If you are a mindless drone you might be able to use this game to fill the time between now and your death as blandly as possible.  Score: 2/100

This is more a rant rather than a review, but hey:  I've enjoyed this game for a long while, playing every now trying new weapons and frames as they're added. And it's a fun game at it's core. But.. this latest update killed any interest I've in the game. Farming void relics is incredibly tedious, basically turning every other game mode into void relic camp. Only one reward / void relic, too, unlike the multiple rewards you could get from defense/survival void missions earlier. And party is basically mandatory to have the slightest chance of the rarer rewards.  I could deal with the stupid energy system. The lack of any balance whatsoever (hello Tonkor!) was still ok, the game's fun regardless.
