Upadted!  Warframe is really not like any other game. The combat itself and the combat variables are phenominal. It legitimantely puts your skill over equipment level to win battles, unmatched by many other games who claim to have this balance. But better equipment does help speed up the killing, other then that, you can go to any level with what ever equipment you so desire and finish it, even if your gear is new level, with or without modifications.  The equipment makes each person unique. When I look around the net and stumble upon people asking 'What weapon or warframe should I use?' and the majority of the answers are along the lines of 'Whatever suits you best.' This holds true, as you can use a number of weapons, such as bows, swords, staffs, fully or semi-automatic rifles and pistols, and many other weapons, mainly influenced by the western and the far east arsenal. Which different people are more proficient with whatever equipment suits their style of play.  Any other info to get the idea of the game is, that you can craft stuff at a spot around your ship, have a companion to fight with you, join clubs formally called syndicates, start or join a clan and form alliences, oh and quite importantly! You can perform Freerun/Parkour/Agility around the land scape. Now with the new update, manouvering really takes the meaning 'The sky is the limit.' literally and has really taken my breath away, along with elevators and Excalibur's super jump.  The overall quality of the game is beautifully shaded, polished, and even replaced multiple textures, sounds, and physics, to where my computer started generating some more heat then in the beta, but still runs very smoothly. Though, I do have a slight irratation because of how darkened some tilesets have become compaired to your Warframe in the enviroment.  There are a lot of other stuff and quite frequent updates and additions to the game. Even to this day they make astonishing changes that builds upon what is already amazing. Thank ye for witnessing this passage!

This game has sucked me in.  To begin with it was weird enough to be fresh but familiar enough to be playable. To sum this game up quickly would be to say ninjas in space. But that would be doing the game a massive disservice. Its far more complex and deep than that. There are factions and groups and clans and all the other things you'd expect from a game like WoW but set in space in some distant future with space ninjas.  Sooo much to explore and do and a little bit intimidating to begin with. Where to put that little bit of platinum (in game real converted currency) to best use? Credits are easy to come by as are resources. But platinum will be a constant hassle unless you're willing to either grind or cough up some dough. But it is a free game and the passion and depth of the game makes it well worth giving the developers some money for their clear hard work and passion on the game.  I love this game. Really cool premise for the game. Lots of potential, but quite a few bugs. Most problematic are the defects surrounding forming and maintining groups, which is pretty much the most important thing for a 4-person squad-based game. Wasn't too bad at first, but I think they've done much better with the new update's. Lots of customization including;   Various types of Warframe's w/the ability to choose color's for the different parts of the Warframe Many different type's of Primary, Secondary and Melee weapons w/the ability of color choice  Customization of your 'ship' (Whatever it's called, don't remember right now) w/color choice Customization of your Kubrow companion (Pretty much a weird dog-thing) w/color choice (Though you can choose the color's of the other companion's, but not really too much customization for them) If your into clan's, you can create or join a clan. Clan's also come with a clan dojo, which can be heavily customized into literally a personal hangout place or even a base of operations. You can put statues, trees, ponds, bridges, laboratories, hallways, a dueling area, trading post's, etc and many, many other things in your or joined clan dojo's  You pretty much got the idea of it, a lot of customization is in this game. There's also various mods you can put on your warframe, as well as weapon's, companion's stuff like that which can increase the stats of whatever the hell you put it on. Ex. The mod 'Vitality' grants more Health. 'Redirection' (I believe) grants more Shield's You can also go to a large selection of planet's too. I only got around 6-8 planet's on my navigation that I can go to, each with 15-23-ish mission's, and I still don't have all of them.   Though there's a lot of plus sides to this game, the most frequent and annoying things I keep running into would be lag and difficulty. If you don't have a generally good system, your gonna have a good amount of lag (Obviously, yes I know. I'm just saying). Sometimes, it just likes to lag I don't know. Then with the difficulty, there are some mission's that (my belief) are literally impossible to do by yourself....just can't be done. Friends are a very lovely thing you'll definitely want with you in some of your mission's or putting your lobby to public for randoms, doesn't really matter. I would get into item grinding, but with these type's of games it's honestly expected, so. Btw, you don't start out with a lot of color choice's. You need to use actual money for Platinum to get different color's and color scheme's. Everything else you can get with Platinum if you want, but everything I've seen so far (including other warframe's) have blueprints if you don't feel like using money. Be warned, you'll be grinding A LOT. Though if your lucky, you'll get them pretty easily.   Moral of this review is: If you like Third-Person Co-Op Shooter's w/a Hack-and-Slash ability, and you don't mind that occasional ungodly lag spike w/minor rage fits...then give Warframe a try. Hell it's free-to-play and in my mind, one of the better free games you can get. (Didn't mean to spoil anything about it for you, but trust me I haven't even got to some of the good stuff. You'll just have to play it in order to find out more then, won't cha?)

First hours are not great: -Cryptic interface -Weird menu navigation -Unexplained controls  But once you got through this, you discover a game that offers: -Outstanding shooting ninja experience ('flip, shoot, slide, slash!') -Addictive grindfest through dozens of systems (weapons, mods, syndicates, frames...) -Lots of theorycrafting (not mandatory but if you want to get into this, this game welcomes you with open arms, and Warframe Wikia will soon go in your favs) -Very engaging coop experience (with friends, on high risk / high reward mission)  Monetization is present but not agressive. After 50+ hours I don't feel frustratrated because I didn't monetize, therefore I could consider spending a few bucks as a tip for the developers.

There are so many things about the game and the company that make it one of my favorite games I've ever played.  The gameplay is deceptively complex, and while players can spam abilities and shoot with abandon on most planets, the higher-level play relies heavily on teamwork and composition, as well as conservation of resources. Staying in a survival mission for an hour, for example, requires that every team member be able to quickly and consistently kill the constantly scaling enemies while still replenishing the ticking life support meter, which, as more and more time passes, becomes increasingly difficult. After about 35 minutes, the enemies are twice the maximum player level and spawn about 15 new units several times per minute. The mass of bullets and bad guys is almost incomprehensible, and even when they die, they rarely drop anything useful. Without a Nekros Warframe to loot the bodies of the dead enemies, ammo and life support are scarce commodities. Without heavy area-of-effect damage dealers like Nova, Mirage, and Mag, enemies would overwhelm the team and the mission would be lost. Without heavy tanks or stealthy rogue Warframes like Rhino, Loki, Ash, or Frost, reviving allies and activating life support (which requires a three second channelling time) becomes next to impossible. It's a tactical and action-packed frenzy.  There are now more than twenty different playable 'characters,' each with unique skills and stats. There is a Warframe for every player, from supports to run-and-gunners, tanks to backstabbers. There are also more than 150 unique weapons to build and collect, including some truly unique weapons, unlike anything I've ever encountered. Gas emitters, laser welders, automatic dart guns, goo guns, and even a few rifles that shoots saw blades make the thirteen-year-old boy in me that invented a saw gun when I was supposed to be taking notes giggle with delight.  What makes this game special is more than just the game mechanics, though. The developer, a company called Digital Extremes, is absolutely committed to providing the absolute best experience for their player-base. The game is free-to-play, but unlike so many of its contemporaries, it does not follow the pay-to-win model. Everything gameplay-related is obtainable through in-game work, and even some of the cosmetic items are obtainable through special 1-hour 'alert missions.' They regularly give away credit boosters, experience boosters, exclusive event weapons, and color customization options for free or, since their parent company, Perfect World, doesn't allow 'free' items, for 1 credit of in-game currency (each mission typically nets around 15,000 credits). They listen to the concerns and desires of the players on the forums, and tailor the game to fit the community. They provide amazing customer service to players who experience bugs in-game, and even to those who make mistakes that are their own fault. At the beginning of my Warframe tenure, my friend accidentally bought an icon pack believing it was an alternate helmet, and when he asked the helpdesk for a refund, they not only gave him his money back, but they let him keep the icon pack. They continuously surprise and delight me with their service to the community, and in return, they have a fiercely loyal and fervent player base. When the game was first in open beta, they were selling a Founder's Pack that included a custom Warframe and weapon set called 'Excalibur Prime,' which was (and remains to this day) the only Warframe that was exclusively obtainable by paying for it. Those who bought the highest level of Founder loyalty, the Grand Masters, got their gamer IDs listed in-game on the planet of their choice, as well as access to the 'community design council,' who would eventually single-handedly design and produce a number of weapons and Warframes. These fans and players make the game an absolute pleasure to play, and as it is an online game where players are often teamed with complete strangers, it is crucial to the game's playability that its players are at least approachable.  The player base of Warframe is easily one of the friendliest, least horrible groups of people I've ever had the opportunity to be a part of. I am consistently impressed by the support for new players, the intolerance for bad behavior, and the sense of community that the players of Warframe exhibit, and despite the fact that the player base has grown dramatically in the last few months (due to the PS4 and XBox One releases as well as advertizing), the average quality of play has not decreased. The toxic, horrible people that tend to frequent online worlds are just not tolerated in Warframe. It's amazing and refreshing.  Among the list of incredible features of this game is one of my favorites: The game isn't even finished yet. The Digital Extremes dev team is working tirelessly to complete the game, and even though it's in its 16th (and change) beta release, the game is always changing and growing more complete. Every Wednesday they release updates to the PC version, and the person behind the in-game update notifications possesses an ingenious knack for comedy and joy, making the usually dreaded update crash a tolerable (and dare I say fun?) experience.

This game is the kitty's t***ies!!!!!! My hours reflect how sad my life is. 5 days shy of playing for a month. Few glitches here and there, and definitely some mechanics that could be updated, but overall highly recommend this game. I've put probably about a new game price worth of actual money into this, and despite not getting all that much out of it, I still can't put the game down. Find a clan, work together, trade parts, run missions, fight bosses. You 'prestige' your warframe and add 'polarization' so that certain mods cost half price and you can beef that b**** up even more! Tons of different warframes to choose from to completely play whatever style you want. Stealth with Loki (primitive stealth gameplay), Crush and pull enemies with Mag, Torch people with Ember, go Invulnerable with Valkyr and rip mofos apart like Voldo in soul calibur (no 'cutscene' kills, i say that loosely, except for finishers and stealth kills). Freeze enemies, electrocute them, mind control them, just tear them apart however you can. Most warframes have a prime version, so don't polarize until you can get it. Best part about it? You don't HAVE to spend your actual money if you don't want to! But it's fun, so don't judge me. Play it, Love it, Hate yourself, and HAPPY KILLING!!

Quite the successful MMO that got shutdown as an idea when pitched to a publishers. Now they have their own game and I really liked it when I was in the alpha and beta. But the game was more about stealth and being a ninja back then, getting detected was a serious issue and it often meant you had to rush through the mission or die from the overwhelming hordes.  Now the game is about ninjas like Naruto is about ninjas. You are not someone meant to be patient and stealthy old splinter cell style. You are a giant krakken summoning, fireball casting, sound wave emitting bad ♥♥♥ that doesn't know the first word of stealth. Even the characters built for stealth are better off using them to just blow through levels. I know, everyone wants to be the bad ♥♥♥, but this game was about space ninjas. Now its not and I can't help but feel it lost part of itself along the way for more popular appeal. I cannot recommend the game, you are not a ninja and if ninjas play free then why do you push your pay to play items in my face all the time?  Instead of being about stealth now, its a MMO grindfest of gathering materials for recipes and farming recipes from bosses. Have fun as this is gets boring really quick.

Warframe is a multiplayer third-person Sci-Fi PvE action shooter. You take the role of a Tenno, a mysterious race of beings that equip themselves with biomechanical combat suits called Warframes.  Pros: - Fast paced and fun action - Solid gameplay mechanics - Unique premise and art style - Very fair F2P business model - Developers extremely active and friendly with community - Developers constantly updating and adding new content  Cons: - Little to no actual game narrative - Enemy AI is completely unremarkable - Despite claims of being 'space ninjas', stealth options are near nonexistent - Many rewards locked behind steep pRNG 'grindwalls' (earning it's nickname 'Warfarm') - A lot of content remains in game but serves little purpose     In depth:  It is easy to see why Warframe has a large and very loyal following across three platforms: It is fun, intuitive, and has just the right amount of complexity to encourage theorycrafting without boring more casual audiances. The developers (Digital Extremes) are constantly updating the game and interact heavily with the community.    So how does the game work?  You are a Tenno. A mysterious race of ninja-like beings. So mysterious, in fact, that the Tenno do not even know what they themselves are. These Tenno are unique in the world in that they have the capability to control these biomechanical combat suits called Warframes. You can equip a vast array of Warframes with different abilities that suit various roles, as well as a vast assortment of primary weapons, side arms, and melee weapons.  Warframe statistics and abilities range in a glorious cornucopia, suiting the playstyle of just about anyone. Weapons come is many of the usual flavours such as assault rifles and shotguns, but there are also a handful of extremely unique weapons concepts. Melee combat shows a unique level of depth for a shooter, allowing you to equip only a melee weapon and complete combo chains sometimes reminiscent of a spectacle fighter.  There are also a various array of 'pets' that assist you in combat, from the 'Sweeper' sentinel that blasts enemies that gets to close with a shotgun and sucks up nearby item drops to the dog-like Kurbows that can chase down and tear your enemies apart.  There is a vast array of ways to customize the modifications to the Warframe, weapons, and pets. This allows customizing everything from additional damage and defense to adding elemental effects or augmenting Warframe abilities with unique mechanics. These modifications are represented as card-like items (simply called 'mods'), that themselves can be upgraded to increase the effect they provide.  Confusing, though, is the sheer amount of what many veteran Warframe players consider to be 'junk mods'. Essentially, mods that offer little if no benefit to players due to abnormally low bonus values or arbitrary benefits that are too conditional to be objectively seen as useful. Considering that Warframes, weapons, and pets have a finite number of 'slots' with which to fill with 'mods' (ranging from eight to ten, specifically), these 'junk mods' only really serve to dilute pRNG drop tables, adding a level of annoyance in a perpetual 'grindwall' that only serves to alienate many players.     The damage system brilliantly simple but complex, having three 'physical' damage types (Impact, Puncture, Slash) and four elemental damage types (Heat, Cold, Electric, Toxin), each with strengths and weaknesses against various enemy types. The elemental damage is expounded further with the ability to 'combine' elements to create yet another set of new elemental types (Blast, Corrosive, Radiation, Magnetic, Gas, Viral). I have yet to see a game that goes quite this in depth with a damage system, yet still manages to keep it simplified enough so it does not overwhelm. Of all the elements to stand out in a game, this seriously surprised me.   The gameplay itself is fast-paced and extremely satisfying, allowing you to play your own particular style and not feel left behind. While the premise on paper shows a large degree of repetition and has no real story, the gameplay definitely keeps you playing far longer than one would expect a multiplayer RPG-esque game with no actual story elements. There is enough various game types ranging from standard endless wave defense to more interesting 'Spy' and 'Rescue' missions.  Unfortunately, the fun gameplay will only keep you starry-eyed for so long. The developers do try to constantly update and run events to keep things fresh, the lack of story content begins to show the hollowness of the universe. While more recent updates to the game have begun to fill this void with a 'questing' system, there is serious questions as to why it would take this many years to write a story for a game with such heavy RPG elements. Even games famous for their online communities such as Call of Duty spend serious time into the game's narrative. There is also strangely a distinct lack of stealth elements aside from two of the dozens of Warframes possessing an 'invisibility' skill, despite these Tenno supposedly being 'space ninjas'.    There is a vast array of enemies, from the basic level infantry types, to heavy machine gunners, to the obligatory bosses. There are even elite 'hunter' enemies that will randomly spawn in the level intent to assassinate you if you have merited their feared 'Death Mark'. Bosses show some unique premise, ranging from heavy armoured military generals to insanely nimble robotic 'hyenas'.  Unfortunately, the enemy AI is very simplistic on all but boss encounters, and even then the AI is mediocre. Most basic enemies will literally stand in front of you, dumbfounded, as you cut down their allies. A few may take cover, but little else. None flee in terror of the almighty killing machine that is decimating their numbers, and more importantly, there is little to no group tactics. No feints. No sneaky flanking enemies using their more heavy allies as a diversion. No use of cover-fire-and-advance tactics used by basic infantry. With the endless droves of enemies being thrown at you, it would be nice to see difficulty defined not just by and increase in damage output and defenses, but also in intelligence.    Now, with all Free2Play games, there is always the concern over the business model. Happily, Digital Extremes does it right. There is a 'premium' currency that one can pay real money for called Platinum. The only thing exclusive to buy with Platinum is aesthetic/cosmetic items. They do occasionally release 'Prime Access' packs that give you a sum of Platinum with special Warframes, weapons, and gear. You can even purchase normal weapons, Warframes, and pets with Platinum (albeit this is not recommended due to the high Platinum costs for these items).  However, all Warframes, weapons, and mods are available without Platinum. Furthermore, Platinum is tradable with other players, meaning that extremely valuable items your just received for which you have no use can be turned into Platinum by selling it to another player. Most importantly, however, is that no items purchased with Platinum give a particular 'competitive edge', if one could be fathomed in a PvE multiplayer game.    In conclusion, Warframe is an amazingly game that throws together elements of traditional shooters and RPGs in a sublime balance of fun and complexity, with fast-paced action and wonderous gameplay mechanics and graphics.  However, this game does suffer from extreme repetitive gamplay, due to a confusing lack of story to motivate players onward, an abhorently unremarkable enemy AI, and the absurd amount of grinding that puts some of the worst MMOs to shame (earning the infamous nickname 'Warfarm').  Fortunately, the developers seem to keenly listen to their players, and the unparalleled level of interaction from it's developers definitely shows a bright future is ahead.

A surprisingly fun and addictive free to play game that, unlike many free to play games, doesn't forget the fun. Aside from a team I played with recently who seemed to be rushing through the game like it was some chore to be over and done with, only to whine the tired litany of 'newb' because I dared play different (Still annoyed? Me? Nah, that's crazy talk), the community is quite friendly and helpful, and joining a random group is a relatively painful process. A handful of whiny norms (okay, maybe just a little annoyed) is a small price to pay for an excellent third person shooter with a nice variety of weapons, powers, and some truly impressive locals. The free to play is true; you can get pretty much everything in the store through the game if you are patient; you can even trade extra mods and rare parts in the trade channel to earn platinum (the currency normally you'd have to pay for), giving you access to the pay stuff without actually having to pay money.  Mind you, I'd still recommend going into this game with 1-3 other players, as it is more fun with friends.

Now this is one of my first times reviewing a game, but I'll try my best. With over 180 hours of gameplay, I guess you could say that I've played this too much; however, this also makes it easier to say that i would definitely suggest this game to anyone looking for a very good free-to-play game. Unlike most free-to-play games, Warframe doesn't require you to pay to win. There are also lots of different types of charecter types that you chose from such as the Rino Warframe which is a pure tank and also my favorite. There are also Prime versions of some Warframes. These are upgraded versions of their corresponding lesser. Speaking of upgrades, there are hundreds of weapon and Warframe upgrades to chose from that you aquire through completing various missions. To wrap up, I would say that this game is a very easy way to pass the time and still enjoy playing a game. Watch out for resource grinding!

The game is definitely one that requires a good amount of grinding. But it helps make it at least tolerable with the various frames and strats to make it quick and easy. A friendly community, good gameplay (with an upcoming update to change things for the better) and plenty of guides to help, this is one of the good Free-To-Plays on Steam.

One thing not mentioned in many reviews saying 'The Grind is Real', which it is. Is that you really don't NEED to grind that much, it's just that you will. You don't NEED all those weapons (The starting Braton can be modded/forma'd/catalysted to handle whole game really, but it becomes the thing that the game is. Now hopefully more and more content will be added. To give us more to do other that get weapons/stuff just for the sake of it. Unfortunatly the Devs lately have been wasting time with PVP and screwing with a star map that doesn't need screwing with. Just make more maps/tiles/planets/enemies and we will be happy. I would love to see more progression for progression sake rather than for RNG drops.  Everything about this game is great and no other game makes you feel like such a badass, a fantastic control system is the reason for this and it's only getting better. Play this game for fantastic gunplay with (contrary to other reviews I'm seeing) a fantastic assortment of Weapons that all play very different. Many games weapons are just re=skins but not here.  Then of course the Warframes, The grind is real but nothing feels as good as getting all your parts finally then having 'Ready to Collect' in your foundry, then going onto the field and seeing what powers you have, how they will come into play. They make it very tactical. There are many players who build one way per frame according to Meta. Screw that, they can be a boring spreadsheet artist, I'm gonna have fun and use everything I have.  Conclusion, I Downloaded to just check it out, well I checked it allright. Just for the gunplay variation alone I would recommend.

To people who look for addictive game and stopped here for reviews;  I downloaded so many mmo's so many multiplayer games to lose my self like old times. Nothing worked until this game. 20 hour of gameplay in 36 hours since i downloaded and i can't stop. Look no further. I don't know how but this game really pull you to itself. You forget about time.  You pick 1 of 3 warframes at the beginning of the game and start level up. Not just him your Primary weapon, secondary weapon, melee weapon too.  And Leveling up is really rewarding. You can pick from massive amount of mods to improve your arsenal. You can build guns. And find its components from massive numbers of missions from numerious beautifully designed places. Warframe brings the best parts of Destiny and Metal Gear Rising with gorgeous graphics, satisfying gameplay, and hardcore sci-fi action in one free-to-play package.   Pros: This game fulfils every childhood dream of being a ninja and an astronaught at the same time; I personally spent five minutes running back and forth across the map with Warframe's parkour system which allows the player to traverse areas smoothly and quickly without hampering gameplay.   Cons: The only downside I found while playing Warframe was the Archwing missions. It's a really cool idea to be able to fly around in space and fight enemies, but this mechanic is executed poorly with mostly repetitive defense or exterminate missions; thankfully there is only one archwing mission per planet, and even then they are optional.    In conclusion, Warframe is the perfect free-to-play MMO for any sci-fi junkies who want a game literally about space ninjas or just to hang with friends within Warframe's many hub areas.

First thing first; it is hard to start if you're new to the game since the start is very VERY slow due to the long tutorials that doesn't go in to detail (I had to find most of the usefull mechanic by myself or friend teaching me). And not to mention the griding and waiting that gets old just to get one item. There are many cool Warframes (charatcers) to choose from but they only let you choose from three (out of 20-somthing and counting) in the begining of the game. Which was a total let down for me since I DIDN'T like the first three warframe they let me choose form (I WANTED TO START AS FROST). And bossed are kind of plain and some are just annoying (F-ing Vey Hek gave me head ache casue he is SO ♥♥♥♥♥ ANNOYING PEICE OF SHIEEET)  So why am I recomending this game? Well this game is one of the well crafed game I've ever played. Thight and fluent control, high speed action, diversity, and beutiful grafics. the control does take time to get used to but when you do you'll be running, jumping sliding and killing like a ninja, if feels fantastic. You will feel like a total bad-♥♥♥, killing everybody that foolish enough to get in your way. And it is constantly updating bringing new things to the table. Each warframe is unique and just by changing one warframe to another it can alter the game play. The guns are usually very satisfying to shoot each gun have unique characteristic that motivates you to get more guns.   Although it is a HUGE grind fest it is definately not a pay-to-win game like other F2P games; you can get all of the items they offer in the game(except for some exception **frost prime**) it just take... grinding. Yes they do have a market where you can pay real money to instantly get what you want but I say it's not as invasive as other games.   but here's the complain I have that I don't see from other players. The sound tract is kind of dull. I guess I'm not used to that kind of music but I always wish that they put a music that gets me PUMPED during the battle. the music here is just another 'dark omnius' music. Yes it is appropriate for the setting in some extent and it is no where near bad but nothing special. Most of the time I find myself turning off the music and put on sound tract from Metal Gear Rising or Undertale as BGM, which to me works better setting the mood of bad-assness.   Over all it is NOT a perfect game but it sure is a great game (easily one of my favorite game). It have it's flaws but it does make up for it. Plus it's free. Just give it a try and let the world of Warframe consume your life!! Like it't doing to me.

I have played this game for 2 - 3 years and have recently stopped playing. The game is very grindy resulting in burn out and frustration. There are other problems on top of it. Over time for myself and other vets I know the game has become nothing more than a fitting simulator.  - Players are only willing to do the same thing over and over again before it starts to get to them. That means players start finding the most efficient path to get an item making for a more rewarding experience. The devs in return keep nerfing those efficient paths and adding even more grindy items. Sometimes it really gets out of hand and you have to grind for the opportunity to grind an item. For example, a frame was released a while back. In order to get him you had to farm a specific faction for a rare item 3 times. Then you had to use those 3 items to make another item that would allow you to fight the boss. once you fought the boss you had a small chance for it to drop the part you needed.  - Another problem with this is it leads to power creep. In order for devs to keep players interested they have to release frequent updates. In order for the content to maintain appeal it also has to be better than the last. This continues until it causes balance issues resulting in OP mechanics and leaves previous content obsolete. The devs then either nerf newer content hard or buff older items causing the last set of released items to become obsolete.  - The rushed nature of the releases means the devs don't have the proper amount of time to test items and really think it through. This results in balance issues and broken mechanics after launch that could have been avoided. It also causes them to release a lot of half baked projects and to use players as guinea pigs.  - The in game money purchase system has become an issue for a problematic scam. Platinum is an in game currency required to purchase slots and in game items that can be obtained with real world money or trading in game. However, if a player purchases platinum and trades it with another player then cancels the buy order on the credit card DE will ban those associated with the trade. That means if you trade for platinum or an item purchased with platinum it can get you banned for 20 years. The chances of this happening to an individual are small but not impossible. This scam is also becoming increasingly popular. In order to avoid this you can trade with only those you trust.  - If you do play this game there are some things I suggest doing to keep it worth playing.  Don't get to attached or to heavily invested in anything. The constant balancing means if you invest a ton of time and resources into something it can become nerfed or made obsolete. This also goes for game mechanics that can suddenly break or become frustrating. This is a social game so play with friends as much as you can. It makes up a large portion of the game play experience.  Don't play too much. Play in bursts so you don't get burned out and there is always something interesting to come back too. While that could be said for many games this especially applies to Warframe. Coordinate with friends so that you can all cover every aspect of the game. That way you can help each other to accomplish everything you can in the game together.

It pains me to give this game a bad review. I love it... I have almost 600 hours into the game. But there are a few things that need to stop.  1st, the bugs. The same old bugs persist. Inviting someone to a game can take 4 or 5 tries (using all the various methods to invite someone) before it finally works. Inviting them to trade is also buggy. General animation bugs that have been around for such a long time (liset flying into another liset, wrong tenno coming out of your liset, weird errors when the boss introduction scene comes into play) that you forget they are bugs and start to think of them as normal parts of the game! For example, does anybody even know that during the boss fight with lephantis, all three heads are supposed to pop out of the ground and rip the ground out from under-neath you? NOPE, because it's buggy. They just assume they randomly appeared on another platform... after all it's warframe and crap like that happens. Some people call this game BUGframe, and others call warFARM... heck some even call it BUGFARM. which brings me to my second point.  2nd, the grind and the farm gets a little redunant. The nerfed triton and added a semi-okay core reward system for the t4d/s to compensate, but it just takes too darn long to get enough cores/ neurodes/ plastids/ o-cells/ oxium/ neural sensors/ morphics/ gallium/ mutagen mass/ so many other parts i don't feel like naming them. I'm not saying they should make it TOO easy to farm... just a LITTLE easier. Only a smidgeon.  3rd, it offends me that so many games (Bethesda is a perfect example, and so is WARFRAME) come out with beautiful graphics and a fun play style and NEVER fix the bugs. Worse for WARFRAME, their attempt to make us forget is to constantly make new shiny frames and weapons to keep all of us distracted. Well it's not working. We aren't distracted. The only reason why we keep playing is because we love the game and are loyal to it, and we hope that some day ya'll will get the picture and spend more time resolving bug issues/ balance issues, and LESS time making new warframes and weapons.  Honestly, this is a good game. I love this game. It has the potential to be a GREAT game. The DE's just need to spend less time coming out with new crap, and more time fixing the broken old stuff.  Oh, and fill in your DANG LORE!!! After 600 hours in game I still have no clue what half the storyline of the freaking game is! lol XD

Okay, this is probably the one game I've played the longest. Though 363 hours may not be much compared to most reviewers here, I have played the game enough to give my 2-cents on it.  Warframe is a F2P game, it's fun, because who doesn't like space ninjas right? No, not just that. The game starts out bland like a lot of other F2P games, but past the beginning of the game and you have yourself absorbed into the game thinking you're the character. That's not all, unlike most 'F2P' games, everything in this game can be acquired through time... and a bit of effort, with the exception of cosmetics. The gameplay is great and I hardly see any bugs or glitches. Updates are constantly being pumped into the game to make it more enjoyable for us. Overall, I had a blast playing the game.   When playing the game, don't question why buying platinum based items are so expensive, as it being a F2P game, the company has to find a way to make money. Hence, over-priced 'PRIME ACCESS'. (I just contradicted my own statement, ah whatever)  Would I recommend this game? Hell yes.

So much love/hate!  {...........So you've gotten into warframe, 'WTF is all of this stuff? So much stuff,' you say. Then you start asking around for answers.... oops you got banned from that chat tab, need to relog.  Try to buy a mod but you can't because starter plat can't be traded. Waste it on looks instead of slots. Ask again, oh now you get it. Off to go score that shiney you saw.... Live Die Repeat so hard! 'Help please,' you cry. Finally a savior comes along.... they have LOTS of shineys and you're so jelly. They help you crawl your way through the basics, you cling to them like a lost puppy. Eventually you start grinding out on your own, two weeks later you have that shiney.  Realise that the shiney isn't so good.... start looking for a new shiney New shiney is so hard to farm so you start begging people to sell you mods for pennies and you grind for them any way. 'Cool I can kill stuff now...' but then you get cocky and go on a planet far too tough for you yet. You grind and grind some more til you have what it takes to farm for Tower 1 missions in the Void. But you're only hanging on by a thread in the Void, you're a good decoy but want to be a Tenno.  You go and buy yourself another visual to make yourself feel better.  On your down time you go chat and Loki master race is a resounding chant. Stalker hunts you and you shiver in fear, suddenly he spawns and disappears. You turn around just in time to watch him assasinate you.... that makes you feel like a noob all over again. Finnally you reach mastery rank 8 where all of the good weapons to help you farm are unlocked.  You're asking habitually which rifle is best.... you don't get a straight answer but you're pretty sure it's Boltor or Soma. Farm grind farm grind farm grind 'OH Stalker has a dread?' The hunt for stalker is on but you give up since he won't drop that ONE ITEM you really want. You then get your first taste of Prime there is no turning back now. Hours and hours you spend begging RNG to give you the next thing your heart desires while trading the fodder away. First pro-build 'I am a Tenno' you say. You main that one gun/frame until... you guessed it the next one comes along. 'I want to make it even better!'  So you inquire about Primed Mods but you're all out of plat but you look dank now so you've got that going for ya. Finally you're able to easily farm for what you set your eyes on, the search is more tiresome than challenging. One by one those items come to you and there is no satisfaction like having the RNG Gods answer your prayers. Til one day you hear the cry of another asking for help.  They cling to you like a lost puppy..............}  So much love/hate! Yes it's hard at the start and it is a grindy game but the shiney is too bright to resist and the satisfaction of getting that item FINALLY is too fulfilling. So start it up already and don't lose hope.

For me the game started off great because of the gear system. This system allows frequent modding and testing. With a single set of mods you can improve every weapon and warframe in the game without having to reacquire the mods for each item, letting me experiment without hassle. The number of interesting weapons in the game also makes this experimenting seemingly endless. This one feature is the only positive aspect of the whole game I can come up with.  Lately (end of 2015) the development direction has accelerated down a path of greed. They have been implementing new research and material gathering methods that are atrocious. It is pretty obvious to the whole community that the game developers are just trying to coerce us into buying everything instead of playing for it by making the gameplay even less appealing than it was already. I can't recommend this game.

DO NOT PLAY! Wasted WAY more than 9 hours and cannot recommend. I will not go into a bullet list review as it isn't worth the effort. I will instead bring up some 'memorable' issues and what's currently wrong with the game. I don't know where it all started, possibly with their constant 'its in beta!' excuse or the day they made the UI into a resource hog for 'immersion'. In a third person game! Ha! The game is a perpetual grind and the fanboys will defend it like you're insulting their mom. The RNG has been diluted beyond belief along with some items (Oberon parts) mixed into an already diluted item pool. Aside from this the Movement System 2.0 has made movement during combat and stealth clunky in the aspect that you can no longer fluidly 'fly through the battlefield like fire' and instead have a haphazard and dull movement system. 'Coptering' was said to be a problem but really was only a show of minor 'skill' (it was just a fun thing really), not to mention they never really solved it and you can still progress faster. The speed was just nerfed a little (use dual Zoren). Looking past coptering you would have to run and predict your jump, or perhaps take out an enemy too. Maybe you want to continue with a crouch/kick combo or let go of your direction and do a downward attack. Good luck with the last one. Speaking of attack, lets talk about gun attacks when jumping. Now its got a slowdown feature reminiscent of a John Wu film. If you're attacking during a jump, because y'know, you need help with that, it'll slow down so you can take your time to aim. Why not have your frame automatically regenerate health constantly if you're hurt? Maybe hide behind a chest high wall because you're a idiot. You even aim at where to dash jump. This is ridiculous and only serves to make the player more self entitled to being good at the game. I'm not trying to be an elitist, but I see this with so many games (hey Blizzard!). Lets not even get started on the draconian report system. Your allies extracted after telling you'd they stay just to f with you, fun right? You get to stick with one frame at the beginning, no test runs, and MUST stick with that frame. If there is another you'd like then good luck getting to the planet for it, they screwed up the map LONG ago and changed the progression with it. Have fun! They keep dumbing it down and anyone who calls out the mistake is told that they are antiprogress or that its not going to change because of a few people 'qq ing'. TL;DR I love it, It's free just try it and find out for yourself!  yes, this game is a grindfest.  yes, online players love to speedrun missions.  yes, there is a lot of waiting (weapon and part build times range from 12 hours to 3 days depending on the item, 3 days being exclusive to warframes).  yes, it takes a while to get really good gear (RNG or saving up for a trade).  It is not pay to win (pay to speed up and for cosmetics) every non-cosmetic item can be obtained through gameplay, some items come a little slow, but it has never been too slow.  After hundreds of hours, I still have a lot of fun playing and interacting with the community and always ended up coming back to this game. The devs seem to really care about the game they've been making. Sometimes they get a little overzealous and don't finish things, but it almost always works out to be positive. They seem really fun to be around, and it makes the game more enjoyable for me. The community is typically very nice and helpful, one of the best communities i've played with (excluding the post-patch whining on the forums).

Totally recommended.   It's among the few games with an actual fair trade beween RNG and reward (and no, you getting tired because you didn't even cared to learn the basics before screaming 'paywall' and running away doesn't make this statement any less truthful), the amount of things you can't get with other than money aren't significant at all aside from the Founder pack, which is exactly that: an incentive to people who practically gave money away to get some perks in-game when game's was in a REALLY early state of development.   Players with some brains can get platinum (the in-game significant currency that you regularly buy for real money; eg; LoL's RPs) by farming different things.  Of course, the game is not perfect and devs seem to focus more on stopping easy ways to farm and level up weapons and warframes than actually 'tweaking' stuff for the good. Up to date, Mesa's Shooting Galery stills the weakest buff ability, and Peacemaker stills draining ridiculous amounts of energy for the little it does because it's consumpting cap is way too high so making it a duration + efficiency affected is barely significative.  Saryn got an awesome mechanics rework that made her interesting to play with, but is still being an energy expensive Warframe and I can't believe their programmers greenlighted the stupidly unneficient way Spore work because it becomes an awesome resource hog and it hurts more your hardware than your enemies, regardless of what their youtube PR machine unanimously stated since the early ours after the rework (at least it's decen't now, it used to be terrible when they released the first instance of the rework), Toxic Lash is rarely used and I still don't know anyone saying it is good aside from people who uses full ♥♥♥♥♥♥ melee builds focusing solely on it.  Mag's Greedy Pull got an underserved nerf, it was like shooting someone with a shotgun in the face for calling you names. making it a personal utility would be enough, making it a requirement for stuff to be on line of sight AND not bypass walls reduced its usefulness like 1:100.  There is a story for every 'farming friendly' Warframe out there that got nerfed. Digital Extremes do great things when they want (Raids, Spy 2.0, Rescue 2.0, Natha, Second Dream, Orokin moon, Saryn's new mechanics and synergy, sorties) but some other times they also do borderline stupid things that feel arbitrary at best (Mesas' and Saryn current energy consumption, Archwings are an uninteresting module whose resources spent on could have been invested on the actual game -what's next; Tenno Kart?-, some AoE from enemies just insta-kill u on higher levels, combos are more spectacular than useful -this is not a melee focused game, you can't even rely on it on higher levels-, their UI design is 80% focused on aesthetics and 20% on function, and more... ).  I haven't talked about graphics because it is pretty obvious that the game is way ahead of most (if not all) F2P currently in the market. Sound isn't spectacular aside from a few exceptions mostly quest-related things, but it accomplishes what it's meant for.  I think this game is a solid 7/10, it isn't just decent, it is good, at moments very good such moments are more and more frequent since I started playing, although, consistency isn't one its qualities. They could easily sell this game for $50 bucks if they reduced the grind by reducing the grind and adding more story, so, I don't think trying it (or getting back into it) will hurt you.

God help if you aren't willing to hunt guide before, while, and after you play. I had no idea the starting tutorial's weapon choices were permanent (you are allowed to pick up and discard weapons freely in the tutorial level) and chose weapons I didn't like to experiment with and got stuck with em. The experience is frustratingly unguided; even the main story quests eventually force you to Google where to find certain mats that may or may not be (most likely, not) represented in the low-level daily quest.   Even if the game was more accessible, the means to grind in the game aren't terribly fun or varied until you get to later in the game (that's what people tell me; I didn't play on to that point). The best way to grind for necessary-to-advance Rubedo was to do 'protect-the-healthbar-in-the-center' missions over and over again with different map set-ups. They didn't design everpresent, introductory grinding missions around this mainline story quest. HOW?  The game completely lacks basic tutorials, too: I had to learn the ins and outs of fusing mods, mods being a means just as important to customization as Warframes and weapons, from a YouTube video. It's also unclear how different elemental type simpact different enemy types without looking it up outside of the game, etc.  People who invest in the game often really love it, but I wanted to put my experience down here: if you want to just try it for a bit and see how you like it before dedicating, you might not get a very good experience.

I had to think twice about giving this game an reccommend but reflecting on the fun I've had with this game, I can say that I reccommend this to SOME.If you're the type of person who expects a game to be fun at least 90% of the time then this game isn't for you. This game is only fun once you've aquired a weapon and character that you like, and you have access to all the higher level missions, but sometimes even then it can start getting repetitive. For example, I usually quit playing for long periods of time sometimes because of how boring some of the missions can be. I play for a month but then stop playing for 3 and then come back to it because I know that they added new content by then.  If you're not scared off by the fact that it takes an investment of time for the game to be fun, then listen carefully. The game has a lot of flaws in terms of gaining rewards. It's a free to play game where you can either farm the equipment you need, or you could just simply buy it. If you were offended about how World of Warcraft offered level 90 character boosts for $60 then this game isn't for you. If you think you're going to be offended about how the game is designed to make you want to drop money on this game then this game isn't for you.

What I like about Warframe:  Free to play: everything is obtainable for free, even platinum (the currency you can buy with real money). You can sell your rare items and mods to get platinum. I myself obtained hundreds of platinum by selling unwanted items. Free DLC: Devs constantly update the game. Trading: I like trading and getting that plat, don't get me wrong, I hate the trading chat, that's why I use a site called warframe.market. Grind: Now some people see grind as a bad thing. But in Warframe's case grind is good because if you like the game then it's enjoyable to grind. Different mission types. Customization AKA Fashionframe. Uranus (If you know what I mean). Warframe (class) variety: at the moment there's 28 different warframes. Melee combat: from slashing and dashing with swords to ragdolling enemies all over the map with a hammer Parkour: after all it's a ninja game :D Modding: collect mods, upgrade them, make your own build (or multiple builds) for each warframe! Having my own spaceship: hanging out in my own ship or being stuck in menus? I'll take the ship please. Kubrows: who doesn't like weird... dog... pet... things? Carrier: this guy picks up (or vacuum's) things for you! Rebecca... I mean Lotus. Ragdoll: enemies flying all over the place. What else should I say? The Second Dream: dat story tho! Getting loot: I like my loot. Crafting: now put that loot to use. Community: wow I've met so many friendly people in warframe (except from that one russian guy that yels at you via voice chat). Ordis.  What I don't like:  Chat system: seriously, you have to look for group in the LFG chat or if you want to sell something you have to spam in the cancerous trade chat. Thank god for the 3rd party sites. Waiting for things to finish crafting: it's like you're an 8 year old and your mom buys you a toy you always wanted. And then what does she do with that toy? She puts it right in front of your face and says that you will only be able to play with it in 3 days. Weird bugs (or whatever) that makes you disconnect in the middle of a mission: that doesn't happen that often but it does happen. Ordis.

Where to start? Well, I know. Ive played mostly single player rpgs most of my gaming life until I discovered an introductory mmo, if you will, called Team Fortress 2. I loved it and still play to this day. However, ever since the release of Fallout 4, I have been playing that till today too. Heres where it gets interesting. I decided to take a break from rpgs and look for a 'fresh' approach. I saw that Warframe was free to play and so I tried it out. That was 3 months ago. I already have 112 hours on record but, the deepness and complexity of this game is extremely refreshing. Sure, the farming aspect of this game can get repetitive but like anything in life, working hard towards a goal is worth the while. The gameplay is fun, fast paced, intense, and after a while can get strategic. Graphics wise, its gorgeous with its heavy light system and heck, I would dare say its on par with current gen graphics. Would I recommend this game? Absolutely! I know this game can look intimidating but the community of gamers I have encountered help each other out and dont worry, I ll be out there too!   JON P.

It has the potential to be great. The combat, with the exception of boss fights, is really good.  The grind is ridiculous. To craft a warframe or weapon, you have to run missions for blueprints and parts. The game does not explain which missions to run. The only way to know is to ask another player or look it up on the wiki. You are not guaranteed to get the part you need and will likely have to run the mission 20-30 times, maybe more. 'Prime' weapon parts come from special missions that require keys which are used up when you finish the mission. The keys must be farmed and have the same RNG issues. You have to grind so you can grind.  The bosses have long phases where they are invincible and there is no way to know how to make them vulnerable without, again, asking another player or looking it up on the wiki. The game does not explain anything.  New players start with 2 warframe slots and a few weapon slots. These will be filled quickly, forcing you to buy premium currency to unlock more slots. Weapons and warframes need to be 'supercharged' with items that cost around $1.20 to be effective at higher levels. You can get a few for free every now and then but they are extremely rare. You need one for each weapon and warframe you plan to use. Having a large arsenal will require a ton of waiting for special time limited missions (as in they appear randomly and are only available for maybe an hour, so you have to be watching it constantly) that give you the item, or a lot of money spent in the cash shop.  The developers discourage experimenting with different loadouts and builds. They have decided a few weapons and warframes will be the endgame meta and if they notice it is possible for anything else to compete with those, they get nerfed to the point of uselessness. If you 'supercharged' it, you wasted your money, time, and/or resources. If it makes the grind somewhat bearable, it will definitely be nerfed ASAP.  If you don't look at it as a free to play game, and instead spend about $20 or so to unlock slots and only use the 'correct' gear, it's not so bad.  I've been playing since closed beta. I am a founder. I want to like it but DE won't let me.

There are 4 diffrent ways u can get gear in games. 1- u simply get it, eveyone has the same experience and strays no where from the liniar path to get the item so everyones gaming experence it the same.  2- u find it. Its a secrect, something no one (unless looking up info about the game from someone who has played it) could know was there, only your random choices led u you to find it when other may have passed it by.  3- you earn it. you build, craft, get it as a reward for doing the level in a special way, whatever it is u know 'i must do this to earn this' so everyone can pick what they want to obtain.  4- you choose it. you are giving a choice. a few more paths open but everyone has the same options   Of these 4 how yould you like to obtain your items?  If you didnt have to grind (play the game) for hours to get that item would it be nearly as cool? if u could just click a button and have the best gear would you really want to? whats the point then? well funny thing is you can, for money. thats the best part about this game is that there is a trading platform. so if u grind out to get that super rare part u can then trade it for real in game money and buy something otherwhys unobtainable unless u spent actual cash. so every item in the game is possible to get for free. Warframe has been a game I've been playing, and paying attention to for a long time. First started in the beta and was a founder because I thought the game had potentiel that I wanted to support, but was not without it's glaring flaws and disconnecting mechanics. Now after about a year and a half I will say that my money and faith was well placed. DE has done an astounding job of making this game fun, unique, and easy to get into. For people who looked at this game in its early stages, give it another try. This is not the same game I played in 2014, and for the better. I've come back very recently and started spending a lot of time again in the game now that there's about 400% more content than what I began with. DE's come a long way since the begnings of this game, and I hope it continues to grow and become better.  Pros: Quality graphics (really beautiful on max settings) Really interesting gameplay Best experienced with friends or clans you get to know well hundreds of options Really well optimized (And I have a basic laptop i've tried playing on, still runs at 60FPS) A surprisingly good community for the most part Incredibly responsive dev team regular content updates and fixes Lord Red Text Life Sink  Cons: Soloing can be a bit boring. End game challenges are a bit slim (proper builds will destroy almost everything the game has to offer) Lots of wiki visits for information (no seriously, Wiki is your friend) Some content is a bit short handed or lacking (archwings mission tweaks still needed, and more raids) Perhaps a little too much RNG for some people's tastes Life sink

This game is f***ing amazing and heres why:  It is not pay to win. At. ALL. You can get everything in the game just by playing. No exclusives for people that pay a bunch of money. If you like a certain weapon and think it looks cool then you can just play the game to get it. Even if someone on your team has payed 1 million dollars it wouldnt be affecting you in a bad way. They would be helping you since they are on your team. The only downside to this is that it is very grind heavy... And I mean VERY grind heavy to the point where you will spend days trying to get a certain item... BUT this doesnt matter if: 1. You like grinding 2. You can find other things to do while grinding (leveling up warframes, weapons, sentinels, etc.)  3. You can put on some music that you like (because trust me, if you are grinding and you put on some music you are going to have a blast, you wont even notice the fact that you are grinding)  To add on to the fact that this game is heavily free to play, I sold on item on the game for a total of approximately 50 dollars. And I got that item by JUST playing the game. As easy as that. Its amazing. Also, this game is essentialy never ending! Meaning you can play however long you want and there will STILL be more stuff to unlock.  Pros: -Not pay to win at all -So much content -Always new things -Creators are always hard at work creating new content and fixing bugs  Cons: -Very grind heavy -Can get sort of stale at times  While the game still has a lot of bugs, DE (the production team) is working extremely hard all the time to fix bugs. Not only that but they are constantly releasing new content to add to the already stacked game. This is an amazing game and I definitely recommend it. Since it is free there is no reason to not try it.  I give this game a  FIVE OUT OF FRICKIN FIVE

At the time of writing this review it is my most played game with 375+ hours. That should give you some indication as to my opinion of this game...  The game has fast gameplay, nice graphics and some of the story is incredible. The game has a lot to offer people, even if they have played for years, as new content is constantly being added. The community is (generally) nice which helps as the game emphasises heavily on team work to do a lot of the game. There is a nice variety of weapons that can suit your play style however, a lot of them are underpowered and are not viably for use on harder missions. This does mean that the player has to keep upgrading their weapons and mods, use to improve certain aspects of the weapon, which gives them something to work towards. There are many different 'warframes', characters that the player can use, that all have advantages and disadvantages which helps keep the game interesting and makes people think about team compositions.  This all being said, there are a few things that I dislike about the overall experience. I actually hate the new navigation system that got added a few patches ago and considering I have to use it to get to every mission it does take away from the overall fun (this is probably me but I felt I should add it). Grinding for materials can become tedious and boring but is required for the improvement of your weapons and warframes. After 375+ hours the gameplay has begun to become stale and repetitive, although I know people with over 1000 hours and still enjoy it. If you wish to fully experience the game you need to buy the ingame currency, which allows for the purchasing of cosmetics, weapons and warframes (all of which are horribly overpriced). There are also 'prime warframes' which are better versions of other frames which game be obtained through void missions but not purchased through the ingame store. This leaves two options: farm it or buy it from another player in the trade tab. As a new player the trade section is confusing and takes time to learn but sadly the game doesn't explain how to properly use it (or at all from my memory).  I would recommend the game as it is enjoyable and has fun combat but like most games it has its flaws. But it is free which is nice.  7.5/10

I post reviews of free games I enjoy so I can go back to enjoy them in the future since they are not saved to your Steam library list, I'd really like to see Steam incorporate another section that lists free-to-play games you've installed in the past  I love Warframe, I played it so much that I had completed every mission including nightmare raids, and had the opportunity to obtain any weapon I so desired, including discontinued, extremely expensive mods and weapons, enough materials to last forever (other than the timed resource which I believe also factored into me leaving the game), the clan dojo me and some friends founded even displays some trophies from our clan securing a ranking during large events. The only reason I stopped playing was because I had beaten the game...there was quite honestly nothing left to do. The devs are continually updating the game but I feel content with having beaten the game when I left it. I would strongly recommend giving it a try to anyone who is interested in playing it.

Hands down the best business model I've seen in a MMO. Rather repetitive, somewhat more so than most MMOs are. The way they handled player specialisations (i.e. character classes) is close to perfect. There is some time-gating for the crafting, which is rather annoying at the start since you don't have a lot of gear to play with in the meantime. There is a general lack of guidance in-game, so I strongly recommend finding some guides elsewhere (most notable example I've seen: Tenno that don't know they can glide... until the game requires them to - and thus get stuck, and have to find a guide -, which is pretty far in). The parkour system in this game is fun, but I frequently find myself unsure of where I am supposed to go (be it using the mini-map or in the parkour challenges). There's a free flight mode. Seems great on paper, but it still needs work. Also, maybe it's 6DOF (I've never managed to control the roll though), but they don't support 6DOF devices.

TL;DR: This game can suck you in and not let go if you let it. The main focus of the game is about min/maxing and collecting loot to improve said min/maxing, so if you don't enjoy that style then this isn't for you. Best played with others enthused about Warframe  You will feel like a god when you play this game, spinning around murdering anything even remotely hostile with lightning guns or rocket launchers or swords simultaneously electrify and blow up people. Or hell, just punching a guy into orbit is a viable method of murder that this game provides. I found it a great game to play while socializing with your friends; Get a bunch of people together in a teamspeak and play while talking about whatever. At the highest level of the game (read several hundred hours in) most missions can be done with casual ease and discussing different builds and combinations of warframes can keep conversations going for hours.  The biggest downside is that Warframe is undoubtably a grind and time sink. You must gather the credits to purchase the blueprint for a weapon which then has specific material requirements, some exceedingly rare, which must be ground for. once completed then you must wait 12 hours to even get the weapon and even then it will need to be leveled up to become useful. EVEN THEN you still need to upgrade it in two different ways to get the absolute most out of it. total time spent depends on the weapon in question but it can take anywhere from a week to a month to get a weapon from unowned to pinnacle of achievement that weapon can reach. and this is assuming you have all the required mods to reach that pinnacle, which themselves can take a long time to acquire.  However with all that said it is still one of the most addicting games I have ever played. 8/10

Okay I downloaded this game, realized I need to register on a website and then shelved it for about 3 months (so tired of having to pre-reg). However once I got over my laziness and signed up for WF, I found this game to be amazingly fun/additive.  4/5 for game play. Initnally the game is kind of overwhelming, lot of mods and different way to configure your Tenno. However once you start peeling back the game layers you realize there is so much to do. DE found a way to merge simple with complex. All the while encouraging you to try every aspect of the game.  4.5/5 for graphics, style, ambiance. I rarely use the word 'cool' anymore to describe things but this game is actually pretty umm ... cool. The look and feel of WF aesthetic is consistent for the world. When you first see a stalker or are invaded by an enemy, it looks powerful, intimidating. The way opponents a game should look. It enough to draw everyone's attention and prepare to survive.  Only draw backs are some Tenno frames go HAM with the graphics their abilities output. When you have 4 of those frames in 1 mission all spamming abilities things do get chaotic. Also, mission maps tend to repeat a little bit to frequently for my taste. However the variation of the enemies/modes slightly makes up for it.  5/5 Sound. The voice overs and ambient sounds are superb! The enemies sound intimating. The world feels immersive.   4/5 Story/lore. I really love the lore of this game. It's post-post-post-post apocalyptic type setting. Filled with plot twists and requires a little outside delving to discover it all.  They streamline the plot through a few quests to bring you in the world. However, I do believe they could offer a bit more lore this way. The story quest are too few imho and the game would benefit from of them.  Now as I type this they have just released: The War Within. DE seem to remain frequent on updating the story and lore so this could be a good thing.  Community. For the most part the community seems good. Everyone is super excited about the game and most people are quick to offer explanation or help when asked. I can't really tell the size of the community because of the way the game is set up. However it seems there are a ton of people a endgame/near end game. And fewer people who are working their way up.   The Devs are very interactive with the community. Often doing a little RP in chat. The ingame HYPE for The War Within on release was wild and energetic. I really like that they thematically hype their own game.   PvP pvp is okay. The population for pvp is low (at certian times). The balance is questionable. My suggestion to you would be to clear most of the pve before you attempt pvp. Learn how to use your frame, how to move and dash around like a ninja.   Basic New Tips. It's not p2w imo. It's just pay to get things a bit faster.  If you are serious about the game and actually want to progress faster. Do a little research on youtube/wiki before you start. Clearing planets sometimes requires certain tasks be met. So look for the junction requirements asap and complete the tasks as you go along.  Trying every weapon and every frame is the best way to level.  Join a Clan  Not all missions need to be completed with other players. If you have a hard time finding others just try to solo it.  Use your beginning plat wisely. Also once you find a weapon/frame you like, dont be afraid to  upgrade it early. Yes, better frames will come along but the wait could be a while. It's not super fun to struggle till then (unless you like that challenge).  Keep an eye out for promo codes.  And finally repect CLEM! <3

On the surface, Warframe is a game about robot space ninjas. Once you go deeper, you find out about wars, betrayal, patricide, torture and, again, robot space ninjas. Basically, a fun game even if you don't care about the story. And a better one if you do.

As a preface; I exclusively play Warframe through their own launcher and not the steam one, so don't take the hours listed here seriously. As of writing this review I have at least 900 hours in the game.  Warframe may market itself as a game about ninjas, but that isn't really a very good description of it.  Warframe is a player vs enemy randomized dungeon crawler / third person shooter / Hero shooter / grind for progession free to play MMO-like centered around the idea of obtaining and mastering loot and weapons.   The gameplay itself consists of moving around the map quickly through use of your warframe's high air mobility while you shoot enemies while performing an objective on the map. Sometimes this objective IS to shoot enemies. Every mission in the game basically boils down to this. But missions happen in such short spurts and have such a jump in/jump out quality to them that they manage to be addictive and entertaining, despite not being all that varied.  This game is free to play, which means there are microtransactions. Most of these microtransactions are extremely fair, you can get around almost all of them by grinding in the game (Not factoring in trading through the in game economy). The grind is, obviously, not the quickest thing in the universe. It is however much quicker than most other Free to Play games that I have experienced.  There is a lot of grinding in this game, if you enjoy games like Monster Hunter you'll probably have fun here. If you hate the idea of grinding, this game might not be for you. I do find that the grinding doesn't often feel bad in Warframe since Warframe's goal IS getting that next item or maxing that next mod. Unlike other games, progress isn't often locked behind getting that item. Instead, getting that next item IS the progress, and if you arn't happy with your progress towards that weapon you can swap your focus to getting a different one since there are so many of them. This tapers off a little bit once you hit the end of the game as I have, where the things being grinded for (Riven mods and Primed Items almost exclusively) often are based entirely on RNG, so you lose the feeling of every mission you do serving as some form of progress. I do feel that's fair after accumulating the number of hours that I have, however.  The dev team is pretty involved with their community. Even when they don't listen to popular feedback they usually do address the fact that the feedback WAS present and read. Which is more than most devs these days, who seem almost scared to be even slightly open with the community.  The game is constantly updated, and not in the way you expect from most f2ps where it's like 'every six months or so they add a pay to play episode that lasts 10 minutes and has unbalanced drops.' Warframes quests are always free, and while they've slowed down a bit recently, manage to come out fairly frequently. New weapons are added to the game at a pretty fast pace. There's usually at least one update per week, though the update doesn't always contain new additions.  The game isn't without issues, though. First of which is balance. The game is PVE so balance isn't AS high a requirement as it would be in PVP games, but the lack of balance is still there. Most weapons in the game can perform throughout the entire star chart, but theres very noticiable performance gaps that grow larger and more noticiable the longer you play.  Inventory Slots. Earlier I said that most of the microtransactions are super fair and only save you time. There is one exception to this. You start the game with a handful of slots for weapons and warframes. Each built weapon or warframe requires a slot. Since the game is all about gaining new warframes and weapons the starting ammount of slots, while they will not prevent you from playing as long and to as hard of difficulties as you want, will definitely hinder your enjoyment as you're forced to ditch your weapons pretty regularly. Slots arn't that expensive, and though I think they could give new players one or two slots more, they're still pretty fair considering. You can play with just the starter slots but slots are definitely the area you will feel you're forced to drop money on the most during your time with this game.  Bugs. The game is pretty buggy. Rarely unplayably so, but they're still not exactly rare. DE doesn't really seem to have any kind of large internal testing team, so whenever any new quests or new modes launch, you can expect to encounter a lot of bugs with them during the first two days of their implementation before DE manages to smooth them out some.  The game doesn't explain itself well. A lot of things you will need to look up on the wiki or ask other players about.  I would recommend Warframe if you're looking to just jump into a quick game at your leisure on occasion and don't neccesarely want something that costs much or is in depth. I would also recommend it if you don't mind playing a game with no real goal other than having fun while grinding out whatever looks cool or is new. I wouldn't say that Warframe is for everybody, but I do think the majority of gamers can probably enjoy it for what it is.

If you like the idea of space ninjas and don't mind, or perhaps even enjoy, grinding then this game is for you.  It feels fair for a f2p title. Cons: - RNG - meh skins for weapons - u can get burns cuz of the grinding; - i feel that they sometimes neglet this great parkour system; - bad AI, like really really bad (this includs bosses) - this year many many spongebullet/invulnerable enemies ( to reduce the 1 shot killing enemies but used in a bad uninspired way) - RNG - repetetive after a while: few maps; even if u have like 100 missions only a few are usefull/worthy - sorties: repetetive, boring and bad rewards, after TWW comes with extra burns. Can't talk about raids, i was never interested. - now its worthless to push yourself in endless missions cuz reward nerfs; - lately very toxic community; - bad pvp; - new bad riven mods that comes with even more RNG: new reward from sorties that can be used on a random weapon, with a random mr req and random stats ( if you're bad luck brian u could get a riven mod for a sentinel weapon with 100%/200% on useless stats); - vaulting prime weapons/frames   Huge con: constant nerfs to resouce/xp farming; i understand that it isnt normal to max everything in a couple of months but honestly even if you are a new player u can feel the burns:  - farm a tremendious amount of rare resources to make weapons/frames( oh you managed to get a decent amount cuz u got somehow a (stacked) 4x / 8x booster? let's introduce a new ultra rare resource req for new weaps/frames - after u leveled a weapon/frame and want to improve it you have to relevel that weapon/frame, ah and btw xp farming was rnerfed this year about 2 times ( xp range, stealth killiling)  Why do i still recommend this game with so many cons? It's great and fun if you play it with friends. It's good to take pause from time to time to cool off the burns.
