My time played does not include my hours playing Warframe without Steam. Total Time according to in-game is 1.5 thousand hours. Holy sht  Pros: +Space Ninjas +Customer Support will respond if you email them +Consistent Game patches as well as Major Updates (Expansions) +Anything that could be considered a usable item is attainable for free +Only things that cost money and are otherwise not grindable are cosmetics, but the cosmetics are pretty nice. +Like Destiny but actually not achieving War Crimes against your wallet. +Overseeing-Company (Chinese company bought majority controlling stake in Devs, but actually don't interfere) is giving a fk-ton of money for game development, resulting in mo-cap cinematics, more creative freedom, an actually great and rare example of a win-win buyout +High-levels of transparency from Devs; Consistent, entertaining-even DevStreams and other things on a common schedule, they make sub-sites online with information on upcoming updates and features. +The community (Forums + in-game + there's a fan-run wikia) is extremely friendly and welcoming to new players  Cons: -RNGesus may not bless you in your end-game grinds, but such is the life of the grind. -Sometimes you get stuck in the environment because you're ninja-ing too fast and you forget to /unstuck command -They added a tutorial campaign, but new players may be overwhelmed by the content (there's a lot of sht to do and not everything is handed on a platter) -It will destroy your time spent on other games -Sometimes a balancing fix comes out that makes your favorite equipment not as sexy, but you'll always find a new meta fast

Let me write a bit of a comprehensive review of this game. Also, my play time is only slightly deceptive simply because some of my friends have used my rig to check in and play on Warframe.  I have 1,000 hours by myself on this game. I have been playing since the day before Update 10. Let me tell you, the changes I have seen.  I am rather unsure as to where to begin with this review, but here goes.    Pros   The quests are rather well done and do let you in on some of the lore in the game itself. As much as the quests can be slightly grindy themselves, they are still worth doing.  Customization of weapons, warframes, colors and accessories never ends. Millions of colors to choose from, tons of attachments to make yourself look more pretty. Please for the love of whatever god you believe in, do NOT be that guy in the game who has no stance and basic colors on all of your crap. You look like a chump.  Companion Mechanics aren't so bad, you can have Dog [Kubrow] Cat [Kavat] or a sentinel. They all give benefits, bonuses, and can fight alongside you. (Insert inert vacuum update appreciation here.)  There are plenty of alerts, challenges, invasions, syndicate missions and relic runs that you can do to get better mods, rewards, weapons, and customizations.   Syndicates and their rewards are great and extremely useful.  The player ships was a great addition to the game and helped organize the arsenal, mods, foundry, relics, etc, in a much cleaner fashion.  The enemies come in all shapes and sizes and difficulties, and trust me-I might be mastery level 19 but I still get the crap beat out of me in some missions. The challenge is always there and that's a great thing.  Recruiting chat is useful-USE IT.  Clan system  It's great, although it is hard to start one and run it efficiently, I started one with the help of a few and it grew to over 250 at one point. The more people to help contribute to research and builds, the better. Plus, there are clan based weapons and warframes that only come from clan research so joining one is beneficial to you.  The Mastery Rank up missions.  They start easy but holy crap, you play long enough, the devs are gonna make sure you're good at what you do. Don't even get me started on the MR19 test. It was fun, but a true challenge.   The tilesets of missions have changed over time and many of them are quite pretty.   The factions all have their units, and even they change over time. I remember when there weren't mutalist moas...those were the days.   The bosses are always fun to go and fight, just remember to let someone else get the kill shot. You know what I'm talking about.  Scanning and getting things put into your codex is actually fun, you can go to easy missions by yourself and just relax and scan, and get out.  The Simalcrum is a wonderful addition as well, allowing you to test your weapons and frames on multiple enemies at different levels to see how much damage you can do. Or, to test whether or not a certain frame build is good.  Passive abilities being added to warframes was another great addition to the game, and helps give you a little bit of an edge sometimes if things go south.   The Void Trader was an awesome addition, as well as primed mods. This also gave you some pretty weapons too, at the expense of your credits and ducats. Which unfortunately you have to sell prime parts for but hey, everyone has extra bronco prime parts.   The relays are an extremely useful place, as well as a cool place to go see and talk to other players (occasionally even the server will bestow it's great wisdom upon us).   ENDO.  This was a massive change especially to those of us with over a few thousand fusion cores. Okay, so endo is what you use to power up your mods that you put on frames, weapons, companions, and the like. Used to be that you had fusion cores to do so, and there was a fusion core market. With the change to endo, the market was all but vaporized. As extremely unfortuante as this was-the endo is still a nice change, to me at least. I still sorta miss my cores though...  The Trading system is much better than it used to be, I recall when it first came into the game.  NO. YOU CANNOT TRADE BASIC WEAPONS/WARFRAMES/BLUEPRINTS OR MATERIALS. Carry on.  Dark Sectors Now I know that the invasions are off for now, but let me remind you that these missions give LOTS of credits and TONS of materials and XP, so please, if you need XP, go for one of these. They all have their benefits.   I believe that's as many pros as I have for now, and if I think of any more, I will add them. Now here's what we all need to talk about.   CONS  ARCHWING.  This is quite literally, to me, the MOST HATED mode in this game. I will say that when it came around, it was pretty cool. I would sometimes run an archwing mission because, hey, space ninjas...IN SPACE. Am I right?  But here is where it went to literal ♥♥♥♥ to me. The second it was shoved down our throats.  When the relays came to be, there was one orbiting every planet. Then this boss character by the name of VAY HEK decided it was time to 'destroy' them. Which forced many of us to begrudgingly get out our half-leveled archwings, level them up, mod them, and go spend our time protecting these relays. Mind you, there are only three left at this point. Four if you count Maroo's Bazaar. These relays orbit Mercury, Saturn, and Pluto. But the only way to defend these were with our archwings. Yes, we got nice and dandy rewards from it and all, but this game mode is total CRAP. Plus they added in the stupid ♥♥♥ submersible missions on Uranus. There are already so many things wrong with that statement right there. I could spend all day trashing the abortion that archwing is, but I have other things to cover.  The Grind IT SUCKS. But what sucks the most to me are the relic missions. Yeah it makes things a little more organized and changes up the void rewards, but holy crap guys and gals. It is one horrific thing to go through. It made this game more grindy than it was, which I did NOT think was possible. Yes, you have to wait 24 hours for weapons to build and 72 hours for warframes. It's a wait, it's true. It sucks. But the wait is well worth it. (So what I rushed Inaros, leave me alone. I was excited)  PLATNIUM I ONLY put this as a con because well, you pay for it with real money. Oh and trading it, the tax rate on it is INSANE. Plus the discounts you get on it aren't always that great. I've passed up so many 20% offs, it's bordering on crazy.  The Introduction and Starting Out Now this is much more lengthy and grindy than I remember it being. I even played through the beginning and tutorial to see what it was like when it was changed. So, what. Everyone starts on Earth now, rather than Mercury? I guess that's part of improving the game though, showing off your new tileset and such. I understand. I guess the tutorial needed a change at some point. But SERIOUSLY. DAMAGED MODS. It's not all that hard to get INTO the game, but the damaged mods make you feel like a peashooting crapwad. It's embarassing to say the least, and honestly I feel like it's slightly discouraging to any new player. But that's what a new player is being all about, right?  Side note- Maroo's Bazaar. Okay New players and anyone looking for something in particular. Do NOT. Bother those of us there that have set up shop with UNSOLICITED BEGGING. I WILL NOT GIVE YOU MY ONLY BERSERKER MOD. I came to see if anyone was up for trading what I had set up shop for, not what you came there to beg me for. I know the Bazaar leaves you open for unsolicited trades, but that is ♥♥♥♥ing annoying. Try trade chat and the warframe markets first, or even your buddies, before you go looking to trade with people who don't want to just hand you their hard earned things.   That's all for now folks, postive review from a 3 year veteran.

This is one of the first 'formal esque' critiques I've ever done, so take it easy on me.    PERSONAL OPINION  : Personally I love this game, and have dropped a little sliver of money into it(just to get a little boost ahead), even though I have done so with a twinge of regret afterwards. The game is much easier with money being dropped into it, but is still enjoyable even without dropping any of your hard earned cash on it. The game seems slightly pay to win to me, because you can buy special weapons that you normally wouldn't be able to get with real money, you can buy rare materials that you need to craft certain warframes and weapons, and you can also buy some other misc stuff you wouldn't normally be able to get if you don't drop money on the game. But otherwise, the game is pretty good.    OVERVIEW FROM EXPERIENCE  : From my point of view, the game seems very repetitive and grindy, BUT , It is extremley fun if you have a group of friends to play with. Playing online with random people can be a struggle sometimes, because some people have no idea where they are going, some people die constantly, or simply just go afk at the start. I have to say I am a culprit of this some of the time, but it is extremly annoying if you are trying to rush throuhg a mission online. Solo play can be a little bit of a struggle, as some of the missions are almost uncompletable solo ( mainly the defense missions). So you need to do much more grinding when you are in Solo Play rather then multiplayer. But leveling up your warframes, weapons, and drones is very thrilling and fills you with a sense of delight when you see the 'LEVEL UP' with your weapon under it. Getting to the new planets can be a struggle sometimes if you are underleved for the planets, as the enemies get much more difficult, but the rewards of the missions get much better and newer materials are avaliable on these planets(such Gallium and Orokin Cells). In my experience some of the best weapons in the game to use are the melee weapons. They seem very strong and can take down enemies in seconds, unlike the bows, which seem very underpowered. It still takes 2-3 shots to take down some enemies, even with headshots/crits on the bows. Some of the most enjoyable missions are the stealth missions. It is so much fun to just run around all sneakily and just assassinating all your enemies! Some of the least enjoyable missions are the mobile defense missions. You have to carry around that datamass and run around with only your secondary and melee weapon, which can cause for some tricky if you run into powerful enemies(yikes). It is also a pain defending the control point(in solo at least), as in some missions you're in one sector of the room killing enemies to keep them away from the console, but at the same time some other enemies are destroying your control center, so i really dislike the mobile defense missions.  Now let's end off with the pros and cons.   PROS :  -No bugs(that i have encountered) -Almost no glitches -Good Graphics -Smooth Gameplay -Fast load up times when flying to and from planets. -Good movement options while on the planets(ziplines, Running, rolling, dodging). -Enemies are fair and are fairly challenging to take out. -Materials are pretty easy to come by, as there are deposits everywhere on planets. -Communication with teammates on online play is simple -Matchmaking doesn't take a long time at all -Very interesting warframes with unique abilities -Cool looking weapons  -Intriguing lore -Lots of lore -The game's sounds are balanced(not overly loud or quiet) -Pretty visuals -Nice soundtracks -Good storyline -Not too easy, but not too hard -Updates quite often -Interesting enemy designs -Clans you can join have the capability to have a lot of people, clan communication is easy. -Mastery Rank System is easy to figure out and unlocks many new items -Syndicates give you access to unique items, and can get you items that help greatly with gameplay. -End game is pretty easy. (I probably missed alot, but oh well)   CONS :  -Repetitive Gameplay -too easy for experienced gamers -very tedious when farming/grinding for rare materials -Can buy almost all rare materials with real money -Finding people with your skill level/play time to play with is difficult -Weapons aren't very balnced,  -Some weapon types are very underpowered(bows -Pvp is boring -Buying in-game currency(Platinum) is very relevant and necessary -Platinum can give you gigantic boosts in-game -Very limited storage space to store Mods/Weapons  All in all I love Warframe, even though it has a lot of faults, but i believe the Pros outweigh the Cons.  If you made it this far thanks for taking the time to read my Review (*^w^*)

Warframe is a long running free to play game with premium options to spend real money on.   You'll likely read and hear that Warframe is grind heavy, and indeed it can be, but I've always felt that a grind can be made to feel unimportant so long as the game itself is fun, and the grind does not feel necassary. Warframe is grindy, but it is not a necassary grind.    The actual gameplay, that of third person combat is highly satisfying. The movement feels mostly very fluid and quite easy to manage complex and badass moves that leave you feeling as if you're more than just the common enemies. You're more agile, more skilled, and far more mobile. The weapons range in feel from average shooter, and beyond. Finding weapons that you like and prefer over others, even if slightly weaker, can be very satisfying. Melee weapons are not the best aspect of the game, but they are easy to use and are done far better than most every other shooter game I've ever played. Not the high point, but considering how great most of the guns feel, the melee weapons not being as satisfying is not a gross condemnation of the game by any means.   The movement and guns feel great. The missions themselves are usually fairly short and feature random maps. The maps are not like a lego set with a million different pieces arranged for your running pleasure, rather the map makers have created rooms and hallways that are semi-randomly matched together so that while all of the missions look somewhat similar, the maps themselves are greatly varied. It's a servicable solution to keep burnout at bay for the player. There is much to hide behind and flip about on. The gameplay is further varied by each frame or class that the player can use. Everything from a warframe that can hurl fire and burn everything in sight to a quick cowboy-like frame that blasts enemies with a pair of pistols.   The grind is not severe. It will take a lot of time to attain what you want, but for the most part you don't need any of the truly grindy items. You'll mostly just find yourself setting a goal and grinding for it because you enjoy the gameplay itself, the goal itself is pretty much secondary as you revel in slaughtering hundreds of hapless enemies.    Everything can be attained by not paying any money, though some items may naturally require longer periods of time to acquire without paying real money. The player economy is strong and obtaining the premium currency by trading away valuable items that other players want is not a severe affair, though may require some luck and timing if you're unwilling to negotiate.   Try the game, and if you enjoy the movement and gunplay then you're likely to enjoy sticking around. If the movement and guns, even the starter weapons, don't sound, look, and feel satisfying to you then I'd say that the gameplay will not quite manage to hook you, and so the grind will quickly exhaust you.

As you can see, I spent a lot of time in Warframe. A whole lot. I've been with this game since it became available in closed beta, years ago, and I have plenty of memories connected with it.  Is it really a game I can recommend? Well, yes and no. It depends on you and you alone. It's one of the games that have as many people hating it, as many there are loving it.  Pros:    Not pay2win  - you can trade items for premium currency   Movement is smooth as butter   Sick parkour moves   No matter what weapons you like - you'll find it here   No matter what playstyle you like - there'll be a Warframe that allows it   Nice customization options   A quick mission? You got it! A long mission? Got you covered! An easy mission? Sure! A hard one? No problem!   The community is amazing   So are the developers. Most of the time. Fortnightly devstreams and such.   The pool of various systems, mechanics and whatnot is incredibly wide...   Cons:   ...but just as shallow   Prepare for all those cool mechanics and systems to be left abandoned in a barely working state, because the devs are chasing some new shiny   The developers are worse at enemy balance than Sean Murray is at PR   Basically, you either oneshot everything, or are getting oneshotted   Despite not being a P2W game, it still does seem to scream SPEND MONEY at every corner sometimes   PvP is a joke    There's more action-packed gameplay in Telltale Games' games than there's endgame content in Warframe    The grind can be atrocious. Like, really. A chance to get a thing you need to craft to have a chance of having a chance to roll for an item you want   The developers did pull some ♥♥♥♥ moves in the past, nothing stops them from doing so again

Warframe is a third person futuristic RPG. You play as a Tenno. You will get to choose your starting weapons & Warframe. A Warframe your suit of armor with its own unique abilities and stats. You can also have companions such as Sentinels that will follow and defend you, or you can have creatures such as the Kubrow.   The game is always being updated with new missions, features, fixes, core content, ect. Sometimes I think the game feels fresh and new after some updates. Warframe has come such a long way and I can't wait to see whats next for the game.  The game can be grindy and repetitive but I love the combat and trying new weapons and warframes. Every weapon and frame has a level cap of 30. you can apply mods that you will get from missions and NPCs to improve there stats.  When you build up enough overall XP you can gain a new mastery rank, with each new mastery rank you will need to do a challange to go up in a mastery rank.   Customization seems endless, you can change the look of weapons, warframes, pets, ships, even clan Dojos can be customized to your personal choice. You can make yourself stick out from the crowd. A lot of these customization options will require you to pay some platinum.   There is somthing for everyone in Warframe, you can play the way you want. I personaly like being a tanky Rhino Prime warframe along with the Hek Shotgun and the Scindo axe. I have friends that like being more of a support build or even going in stealth.   Graphicly the Warframe looks amazing and is up to par with some modern AAA games. The game is also very well optimized and runs great on my PC. You may have a better or worse experience depending on your PC and its software and hardware configuration.   Its such a great game with truckloads of content

'To some, Warframe is a game. To some, Warframe is a fandom.  To me, none of this amounts. It does not even come close.    Let me tell you how my adventure went...    A little background on me. I used to be a human soldier for the United States. I lost my legs in Afghanistan (Landmine+Humvee=Not Good). After coming back home to a wife who cheated and wanted a divorce, I fell into a deep depression. I thought my life was over and my existence had no purpose. That was, until I found this game.     I thought this game was a joke. A Space Ninja MMO?!? This'll be hilarious. It even had DLC on sale! I invited some close friends over, we needed to kek together at this glorious joke.   We booted up the game and set the graphics quality to 'fantastic' Upon hitting play, our lives were changed forever.   The screen lit up with the radiating energy of the sun, accompanied by the roar of 1 trillion lions. The angels of heaven rode down from Valhala one the backs of giant white doves, singing 'Hallelujah' from their based lungs. Our eardrums deafened as the intertwining storylines of this gift from god put our minds on a new level. My computer exploded, but the game didn't stop. Because... we were the game.  We were the game... and the game was us...  Warframe ascended us to a new state of being.  A voice descended from the sky. 'Clem!' (My children, it is time.)  We were sucked into the world of Warframe. The game is the way it is today because of us... we fixed the sins of this previously hellish world. It was time. We cured cancer, we ended world hunger, we stopped the birdocracy of the government.   It was over... Everything was right in the world. so please, buy this game and let my hard work not go to wate... You won't regret it.    10/10 Would travel interdimensionally again.'  - basedokosan |  {LINK REMOVED}  kickback.com

I started playing this game way back in its earlier stages. Back when the gram was the best weapon because of its charge attack and the UI was an opaque grey box with your health and abilities. I have since been playing this game on and off for awhile because of its solid combat, sound, and art that I had found very pleasing. During this time I would easily rate the game 6/10.  However this was all before the colossal changes they made, changing the game immensely to the point that now I play it for at least 20 hours each week. I try to get as many of my friends to play this game as I can and I don't even mind doing the same missions over and over again to help them progress. This game is so fun and addicting that it easily has become one of my favorite games of all time.   Gameplay 10/10 it leaves nothing to want, I am completely satisfied with everything the gameplay has to offer.   Sound 9/10 I really enjoy the subtle music that varies from each planet and faction type, from stealth to open combat.  Graphic 9/10 even on its lowest settings it looks amazing and runs really well, and on max graphics this game is stunning.  Overall rating 9/10, I would recommend this game to anyone and everyone I think it is a very enjoyable game.  With this game now adding its next expansion to the story the War Within which is a great sequel to the previous expansion The Second Dream. This game has much to offer in terms of content for new and old players, and its evident that new content will be coming out in the future.

Ahh Warframe. I used to spend hours on end, school days, weekends, even all night on the ps4. Now that I've moved on to the PC, heres what my expierience was like.  At first you would probably wonder why the hell am I playing this game which has nearly 9 GB worth of my space, but once you get in it may be hard to understand at first but you'll get the hang of it. After a while it gets more addictive with more story's more planets to explore, joining your friends in an endless battle to defeat the Grinner and Corpus (the enemy's of the game if you didn't know). And then comes the bosses... Join the game in an intense battle between different bosses with different powers. But thats not it! There is your character, your own character with your own weapons and clothing. There are different warframes (characters) to choose from with different statistics, abilities and overall power. To be honest there hasn't been a day since I haven't remembered playing warframe with my friends on the PS4 and having overall fun and RAGE! One minor thing I don't like about this game is that its kind of a pay to win game. But luckily for us there is a system where players who dont like speding money on the game can use in game currency called credits to build weapons and warframes using different materials you find in-game. So... Everyone has a story, What's your's. I would highly reccoment this game to anyone who likes a third person shooter with amazing graphics, a futuristic sci-fi like story and, overall good gameplay.

If you want to play this game, I highly suggest you take a look at and compare its various communities:  - The Forums - The Subreddit - The /vg/ Thread  And really, actually look at these different perspectives of this game. I'm serious, go to ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥♥ before you decide to spend time on this. Your life depends on it.  This game will destroy you over and over. I find it difficult to say it's not my favorite game as of late and to be honest, I'm playing a lot of much better games.  The main issue is the developers, and I'm going to name drop. Reb, Megan and Geoff are the only people I respect in that group anymore. Rebecca, a community manager, is one of the nicest, coolest people I've ever come across and she does a really good job connecting to the community. She spends a lot of her time playing the game and messing around with players.  The people designing the game itself do not understand their game, have extremely poor judgement, or are actually ♥♥♥♥ing with us.  One day they say they're going to try to eliminate the grind, and look where we are the next day. RNG to have something spawn in a mission, a difficult ordeal to destroy it, and a high cost to reroll the stats on a mod that only works for one random weapon, and then you might come out even worse than before, because RNG controls the stats and their values.  In essence it's not a bad system, but they're not going to do anything about it. I have very little hope that they're going to fix a game I gush about so much because the last time they 'fixed' something was an Archwing overhaul that actually made a couple of my friends stop playing.  They took a year to get the most recent update out and it's barely two hours of content before we hit a very, very mediocre grind. It's not even that much to grind, either. Riven Mods are such a tiny thing. Come on, guys, if you're gonna make us grind, please at least make it meaningful? Give us plenty to do?  The story, the aesthetic, the graphics... everything else is so ♥♥♥♥ing amazing, but the gameplay is actually beginning to drive me up the wall. I want to support DE, I really do, but I can't even TRUST most of them not to half ♥♥♥ it.  I wrote a review for this game before that begged people to experience it while they could, because things like this don't stay around forever. Honestly, after this update... it can wait.

Redefining F2P standards.  Everytime I introduce this game to somebody the first thing they ask is 'How is all this for free? There has to be some catch'.  There is a catch. It is that you need to grind huge amount of time to get certain items especially the latest brand new items. But it's not as bad as you would expect, as a long time hack and slash and 3rd person shooter fan, the gameplay in and itself is extremely fun and I find myself just grinding these things out passively. Before you judge this game you must look at it from a developer's point of view.   I've played my fair share of F2P games, from Planetside to War Thunder to Hearthstone and almost every single 'WoW Killer' MMORPG that's ever released. Hell, I've had worse experiences with B2P games *cough* Black Desert Online *cough*. This game is always that one game I always find myself defaulting back to, and it has very rarely ever let me down if ever, with certain hotfixes that are immediately fixed if they face negative feedback. Why then do I keep returning? Well for starters, it has the best F2P model I have ever seen in a game. Nothing is Pay2Win, period. What you can buy from the shop another player can farm and get. There is no single best weapon, most of them have their strengths and weakness and can be stronger than the other based on the type of enemies you're facing and the way you use them. Rather you can have multiple types of weapons for each situation. The same applies for the Warframes themselves, they act as the classes in game, but instead of the norm, you need to consider them as tools you change out based on the requirements of the missions you're going into. Loki can be useful to not alert enemies and hack data vaults in spy missions, Frost can be used to create a defensive shield around a cryopod or extractor you're trying to defend, and so on. Secondly, you can play how ever you want to, if you love that Devil May Cry hack and slash gameplay you can hold F with a great sword equipped and equip your melee weapon like your primary, allowing you to deflect bullets holding down block, or execute combos based on the stances you have equipped to deal just as much or even more damage than you would just shooting a gun from afar. Vice versa, if you enjoy shooting, you can mod out your gun to deal insane amounts of damage. However, a good player does both and uses them based on the requirements. Might I add that the community in this game is wonderful, which is wierd as it's an F2P game. Join a clan and there will almost certainly be someone to show you the ropes and answer any questions you have. End game content like the high level void relic farms and sorties is also really easy as players are only happy to carry you, just so long as you don't get in their way or do things to inhibit them completing the mission.   Yes you do need platinum (premium currency) for weapon and warframe slots, but these are easy to get, there's a large amount of void missions that are available to you starting from level 6. These missions drop prime parts that can be used to create better primed versions of warframes or weapons. These can be traded to other players for platinum which can be used to fund all your requirements. There is nothing unnatainable in this game. All it takes is some time.   My only issue with this game is I am unable to play any PvP or Conclave matches as the ping is really high probably because my region is far from their servers. They are working on a fix to this by introducing player run servers with rewards. Other than that yes, there are certain issues with buff and nerf hotfixes or the way the implement new systems in the game, for example the new Riven mods rely too much on RnG however the developers always considers player feedback and works on fixing a majority of these issues ASAP. If they do not or cannot fix something they always explain why on their devstreams on twitch held every alternate friday, I would definitely recommend watching those if you're interested in the development of the game. Be a part of the community and contribute by posting any of your issues on forums instead of flaming the game and it's developers, because there really isn't any other game like this out there.  To conclude, I see a lot of reviews saying that you can judge this game after playing for 3 hours, that quite simply isn't the case and you would barely be scratching the surface of what this game has to offer and to truly experience how it's grown in the past few years. You wouldn't be introduced to the archwing mode for example (lets you equip wing-like technology and its own set of weapons and fly around in space and complete all new types of missions). But by far the one thing you need to experience in Warframe is the Second Dream quest. Just to put things in perspective it made me, a long time strong F2P player actually dig up my wallet and buy platinum, platinum I still haven't used, just to support the game and their developers.

I have absolutely despised all free to play games I have ever played. I used to think the model was the worst thing to ever enter the video game industry. However, after having played hours upon hours of Warframe my opinion has changed.   Warframe has the greatest free to play model of any game I have ever played. You are not locked out of any content in the game in any way. All things in the game are completely accessible by simply playing the game. You can pretty much play through the entire game without paying a cent. The benefits to actually paying money into the game are totally worth though. Warframe's core gameplay loop is the largest grind I have ever seen. The best way to rush the grind is to simply use actual money. If you have spent to much time grinding for that one item and have never been able to aquire it and are way to frustrated to continue actually trying you can simply purchase the item for a reletively fair price. I have never once felt like the game was trying to cheat me out of my money.  As for the game itself it is all around enjoyable. The gameplay loop is a great escapist fantasy where you get to play as space ninjas with superpowers and incredible/impractical weapons. If that wasn't good enough for you there is practically infinite customization for anything. Your ninjas, ships, weapons, pets, and shoulder companions are all available for customization. There are also many many subsystems in this game that are poorly explained but completely worth digging into.  Be warned that this game is one giant grind as you try to make yourself an even more badass ninja. The game isn't exactly friendly to newcomers so expect to resort to many a youtube tutorial but the community is incredibly helpful when it comes to finding out what the hell to do. I could not suggest this game more if you are just looking for a fun experience with friends that will leave you wanting to just make one more run despite all those important things you should probably be working on.

Well, what can I say about Warframe?  I love it? Over 300 hundred hours in game would kinda suggest that I guess.  Thats purely subjective though so maybe a little more explaination is called for.  Pros:  - Graphically, its pretty damn beautiful  - Shooting element is very smooth  - Leaping from wall to wall, landing a headshot mid leap from 50 metres away, burning enemies with a draconic effigy all at the same time is pretty cool. You know.... just a little.  - The game just keeps getting more and more added in. The game I play now has so much more to it than it did when I first started playing, and the devs actually care about their game. Which is always a plus.  - One of their quests blindsided me emotionally. Never thought a 3rd person shooter in this style would hit me in the feels but they managed. Any game that actually gets a real emotional response from me is instantly on my praise list.  - A very good free to play model. Theres only a handful of items you can't get by playing the game. Platinum (the real money currency) can be earned by selling mods and parts to other players in game. I've put money into the game but only to unlock more slots for frames and weapons. This wasn't actually necessary as I could have just sold things over the market but... meh. Paid for convenience and to support the game. No regrets.  - Nice pick up put down style game. Log on. Do a mission before going to work/school/that place you have to open your door to access (outside or some name like that... I don't know I try to avoid it whenever I can). Then log out and do whatever. Game will be waiting for you to come back. It won't even judge you. Well, not too much anyway.  It's not all sunshine and rainbows of course. No game is perfect and this is no exception.  Cons  - Controls can be pretty daunting for new players: Once you have this down you'll be leaping around a 3D area and loving every minute, but it doesn't change the fact that; yeah. It's pretty confusing to begin with.  - Pretty samey. I'm gonna expand on this as I know it's a game breaker for some. I personally usually get pretty bored of grindy games. I've enjoyed my fair share of Japanese RPGs but I can count the number of them I've completed on one hand. I start with the best of intentions but after hour 100 of grinding my level just to beat that last boss (I'm looking at you Star Ocean 2. Level 250 to have a chance? Really?) I usually find myself questioning where exactly it all went wrong in my life. Warframe for me, appears to be an exception. Theres a number of different mission types to keep things at least modestly different and fresh, but all of it usually boils down to: Point and shoot until everything is dead. I'd recommend you try it before you knock it as, like me, you may find that actually this is one grind game you can get into.  But it IS still a grind.  - It's pretty complex, what with the numerous weapons, mods, relics, space dogs, space cats (no those last two are real. I'm not making it up), frames and such. There's almost limitless build potential for each weapon, frame or space pet but, obviously, some builds work better than others, generally speaking. I think this is awesome! So why is it under the cons section?  Because if you're looking at the screenshots and hoping for a straight up, mindless shooter where you hit play and kill everything you're gonna be disappointed. You walk into one of the high tier levels unprepared and theres gonna be a lot of holes in your suit and your patience. I won't say this is a cerebral experience but I will say that there's quite a bit of research, planning and character building goes into making an end game frame and weapon build. Also mods. See previous section about grindiness. 300 hours in and I'm still looking for a number of mods to complete some of my favourite weapon builds.  -RNGesus is stong with this one. No seriously. You are at his mercy almost entirely throughout. Unless you're willing to drop that magical Platinum I mentioned earlier. I personally would have preferred to see a bit more control and a little less of RNGesus' smirking face but.... well I love the game enough to forgive it with only one or two desk slams and curses that would go some way to making me poor dear parents question how they raised their son.  Overall, I would highly recommend this game to anyone for the resons I listed in the pros (and possibly the cons depending on whether you thought of them as negatives or not) but there are a number of elements in the game that may turn people off.  Still, which other game gives you the ability to shed your draconic cloak, tunring it into a stationary dragon turret, and dance in the embers of your foes to the music of their dying screams!  ....  OK now I'M questioning my upbringing.

Great game, really and truly. The gameplay is great, the graphics are top notch, the lighting is very interesting as well. the fluidity of the combat, from the gunplay to the sword play is very nice. Warframe is a fun, F2P which tens of thousands of people enjoy very much. To me, Warframe is a great game! First of all, let's talk about the background info. Warframe is a third person game, which is comfortable to my liking circle, and there is a crosshair so it's not SO hard to aim in third person. There are weapon slots, which is good. And the variety of weapons are AMAZING. Bows, to assault rifles, to Corpus/Grineer rifles, to sniper rifles, to crossbows, to laser pistols, and many other weapons including melee. Melee is also amazing. I recommend this game, no doubt!   More details here.  Warframe's settings has a variety of choices, which is great for people with a weak computer, and also the HUD is very nicely set out in a neat and not all over the place setout. There is a global chat menu, with different sections such as the trading section, recruiting section and most of all, there are clans! Clans are a group of people, and the max member capacity is 1000, AKA Moon Clan. Yes, when clans reach a specific number of members, they will be known as a different clan. Such as my bosses clan Raindogs which is a moon clan. Clans have there own personal building, but we call them Dojos. Varieties of buildings are built in the dojo's, such as hallways, barracks's, weapon labs, and the newly updated lab, Warframe Research Lab! You can research and begin projects in the labs, but this feature requires resources. Well, I can't tell you anymore! It'll be a fun killer! Play this game yourself and you won't regret that you made an account!
This is an AWSOME GAME!

Amazing third person game. it DOES require a speperate account then your steam account, but it is super simple compared to other games. amazing costumbility and combat system. if you are looking for a game to play for hours on end this is your game. online multiplayer is buggy, if a match ends the game freezes on the loading of the menu, but minor bugs like that are to be expected in an open beta. amazing game. if they got rid of the in game 'crystals', which is in game currenct that you have to pay for, and charged about 15-20 dollars for the game i would still buy it. amazing game. i give it a 11/10

One of the more unique games I've played in recent memory: Loot grinding space ninja co-op RPG shooter.  Going from planet to planet, clearing out all the zones and getting good loot, and upgrading said loot, is some of the very fun. Think 'Borderlands' but with a mission list on a solar map, good if you just want to do one match at a time or hunker down for a long night of gaming.  This game can be a bit difficult to figure out at times, the movement and melee feel odd at first and many of the RPG mechanics have a sizable learning curve, but once I figured them out I found it very enjoyable and rewarding to play.  The free to play model works well for this game, putting money into the game is more a way of saving time than becoming overpowered. Having said that I've put over $100 in to this game (counting the PS4 version as well).  I haven't done much soloing in the game but it is an option if you prefer, however I find the co-op mechanics very unobtrusive and as long as you stay within an appropriate level range you won't have any trouble with other players. That's beside the point that the co-op is an intrinsic part of the game and more importantly is quite fun.  A very fun and addictive co-op RPG shooter.

The concept art design is top notch. This is the main reason I recommend this game. I believe it is done by the same artist that did the design for Pacific Rim, Don't be Afraid of the Dark, and Borderlands 1's alien weapons -- Keith Thompson. The weapons and warframe feel very unique, blending organic and mechanical feels together. Almost like Giger's works.   Gameplay is grinding heavy but kinda fun. The system has a lot of depth, like the damage 2.0 system, which allows some theory crafting. Gunplay is OK, animation is OK. Overall 5/10. Mediocre but there is nothing else like it on the market (other than Mass Effect 3 multiplayer which I refuse to pay for to Bioware).

Good fast paced third person shooter. Match making system is pretty randomized, tossing you in with whatever group has an opening on the map you're trying to play (if there is one) at any point of the level. A lot of people like blowing through maps very quickly, so low level play can be frustrating as you wont get many kills grouping with high levels, and you wont be able to pick up things while trying to keep up.  Still, solo play or playing with friends to start off as you learn is fun, and once you get the hang of it you should be able to jump right into games with the more experienced players.  This is a free to play game, so micro transactions are rampant. They aren't required for success, but they do make things quicker and easier for you on the crafting end. Crafting can take up to 3 days on some items, and there is an in game pay option to make them finish instantly, or just outright buy the full item for real money.  I would suggest playing without paying till you know for sure it's the game for you.

I was in this game for beta, so I'm not sure how the standard player feels about this game, but the steps it's taken all the way up were satisfying and interesting every step that I could play in. while the original mod setup was fun, the trading card aspect makes it a more social kind of feel. Missions are randomly generated around common tileset, positive or negative, it's a feature that it is well suited to. Tenno (the player's class essentially) are an ancient warrior race in organic-looking powered armor, fighting a crumbling military structure and an intergalactic corporation... it's actually an okay overarching theme to the third person shooter market. While the 'four revives' thing sounds terrible, if you're playing online there will be tons of squads. Teamwork is vital to solid gameplay, so lone wolves may need to spend a little time slumming it before finding a solid loadout.  Overall, I like this game, and definitely plan on playing it more. Solid combat with simple controls at its core with a visually interesting thematic for the rest of the game. some sets are a little repetitive, but the sheer combinations of setpieces they're putting together is staggering, and they're always improving. Play it or don't, I've said my piece on it, Enjoy.

Take the Sci-Fi Action aspect of Mass Effect 3's multiplayer mode, cook it over a flame built from Collectible Card Games and Tradional RPG Advancement, apply a thick Pseudo-Samurai glaze, and dribble 'Guyver' aesthetics over the whole thing. Serve on a Free-to-Play platter, with a side dish of Item Crafting with a light Trade sauce. Add a Guild Base/Bank for dessert, and you have a 5 star shooter experience.  In all seriousness, good gunplay, sweet abilities, awesome melee weapons, a solid craft system, and a well-paced effort/reward setup allows and encourages grinding for specific item materials without making it a horrific chore, and allowing the purchase of key mats if you just can't wait. The ability to build your guild's dojo room-by-room, and individually decorating each room to your liking is freaking awesome.   9/10, Most enjoyable F2P on my game list right now.

Interesting F2P game about being a space-ninja called a Tenno. The gameplay reminds me of Mass Effect 3's multiplayer where you run around 3rd person camera and shoot stuff while using four powers based on your class. Your class and weapons can all be modded with cards that you pick up by killing enemies, but you also need to level your gear to gain points to use to equip the mods. The crafting system takes extensive real-time (12 hours for most pieces of gear and 72 hours to craft a new Warframe which are the different classes.)  I enjoyed the game, but I don't like the restrictions on F2P characters. You are limited to only having 2 Warframes unless you pay real money to unlock additional frames. Perhaps this is fair, but the only other option is to sell the warframe you spent so much time leveling in order to try out a new one. Do you get a lot of money for selling your old friend? No, you don't. If you decide that you actually liked the older frame more you have to gather materials and wait 72 hours to recraft and then relevel it. Not fun.

Pros: Free to play, great graphics, good amount of replayability due to many many different kinds of suites being available, powers and customizables make for a good amount of variables.  Cons: Free to play, but pay to win/have fun. I am getting worried that game companies are going to start adopting this method and it scares me to no end that it will spell disater for the game industry. Its almost ruined a whole generation of games for me and many many others.   Overall: Fun to play for a while, but to keep having fun money is to be spent and alot of it unless you spent the huge amount of money on a founders pack already. Decent overall free to play game, at the very least try it out cause honestly there is no harm in playing a free game.

Pros: 1. Controls are tight & responsive (however aiming with a gamepad feel a little odd for some reason?) 2. Combat is fast, fluid, & exciting. (Reminds me alot of how Mass Effect 3 felt while playing multiplayer) 3. Loads of mods, weapons, warframes, artifact, etc. to keep you busy for a long time. 4. Graphics are very good  Cons: 1. Will try to 'nickle & dime' you at every opertunaty. 2. While the graphics are great I noticed some textures failed to load on a few missions. This only happened a few times & it   didn't hinder 'my' enjoyment, but I wanted to mention this. 3. You have to pay to unlock basic colors for weapons & warframes!? (Yes really)  This game plays amazingly. It offers alot in the way of customization & options to personalize everything to your liking, from your powers to your warframe to your weapons, colors & all. However, with all these options there comes a great evil... lots & lots of microtransactions. Now I'm not the kind of person to besmerch the use of microtransaction, in fact its the oposite! I play lots of games with microtransactions in them, such as Dead Space 3 & Mass Effect 3, both of which offer quick ways to get what you wanted for a small real world cash fee. These kind of microtransactions do not bother me at all. Most of the items in Warframe can be earned through lots of hours simply playing the game. This concept is great... until you see things like, having to buy colors to recolor your warframe or weapons! Yes you have to pay real cash to unlock something as simple as color options! I understand having to pay for 'special' color options, but basic color options? Come on, no one should ever have to pay for something that simple.I.E. if you want to make your warframe black, well guess you will need to fork over some real world money for that.  It may sound like I'm hating on this game, but really I'm simply pointing out the same kind of things that are wrong with most F2P games, they expect the player to pay for everyhting in the game with reall money. While I don't mind microtransactions that allow me to simply bypass spending hundreds of hours grinding to open it up through playing, I hate when developers decide to put even the most basic of things such a colors behind a pay wall. That all may infuriate me, but there is no denying that this is a great game with solid controls & great fun to be had in it. Just be aware that while most things can be gotten through hours of play something must be purchased with actual cash. Don't beleive anyone that says it's pay to win though, the things that you can't unlock without paying real money are all just cosmetic things. If you enjoyed Mass Effect 3s multiplayer or just simply love action, RPG, 3rd person shooter hybrids then give Warframe a shot, because inspite of all the microtransactions this is a fantastic game. My Score- 8/10

What can I say about Warframe? Well, as you can see I have like three hours on it, so many of the features have not yet been touched. Also, what I can say is I am not really a hard-core gamer. I mean I used to be. But now I got married and a job and everything and I just don't have time like I used to to play video games. So this is coming from... a moderate gamer with some programming experience.  First of all, graphics-wise, I think that the graphics are pretty amazing. The game always manages to catch you in poses and shots that just look great, and the DOF that is in the game only assists in that. I am not running a super high end computer, but it also supports it quite well, meaning that their memory consumption is done quite well; another game of that capacity would have me lagging horribly. I guess that is necessary though, seeing as it was made for PS4 as well. Their particle systems are amazing too, I mean blowing up a crate and wow, the explosion looks fantastic!  Secondly, the controls are the standard controls; no surprises here. In fact, as a 3rd person shooter, there weren't too many surprises, I mean it has standard AI, standard physics, etc.   So what stands out from other games that I have seen? Well first of all, I DO like the customizability of the characters, and their super powers are pretty cool. I love how you can level your character and then based on your level you pick up what is called 'mods' that you equip to the weapon/'tenno'. Also, what I love is that sometimes, just sometimes I am not in the mood to play with some random person, and you have massive control over that. In fact, you can just solo if you want. And speaking of levels, there are upwards of 250 levels in the game!   Now the bad: First of all, this game is still in development and in some ways you can really tell. This is mixed because you know that if there is a problem it will shortly be fixed, and updates are constantly happening. But I am an amateur 3d designer/programmer and sometimes I run into things that make me groan and hope that they fix it soon, and to be fair, these are small things like no enemies on the mini-map, and the containers need to be worked on. One big hitch for me was that I had to dig around to find out how to customize items. The tutorial didn't really offer anything to help me along the way, and everything (from a beginners standpoint) is so expensive that I know that there will be a huge grind to get anything done. Lastly, it seems largely as a 'pay to win' sort of game. Or rather, I suspect that if you pay cash, you probably won't be required to grind like the rest of us. But in this, I sort of understand, I mean it's not really a PvP game, nor is it charging me anything to play, so in the end it isn't really hurting me.  In the end, I give Warframe 8/10 for great graphics, playability, and overall sheer size of the game.

This is one of the best free to play games on the steam store by far!  Pros - Stunning graphics - Plenty of content - Creative gameplay - Fun boss battles - Diverse warframes and weapons - Constant updates - An awesome co-op title - You'll never have to spend a penny - SPACE NINJAS! (You can't go wrong there!)  Cons - Costly warframes and weapons on the store - Certain levels may feel repetitive - Lengthy process of acquiring materials and currency to earn items (WARNING - GRIND ALERT!)  However, at the end of the day, you're getting an amazing free to play co-op game, which could easily pass as a fully priced retail title. So spending a small amount of money on a warframe or a weapon shows a good sense of appreciation to the developers. So STOP reading these reviews and download the game NOW! :)

So, uh, Warframe. Where to start.  Basically the trailer shows you as a kinda ninja robot thingy who kills whole groups of enemies using unique powers - that's half-true. In Warframe, most of ths stuff is actually gun play. It's third-person, which means you get to stare over your own shoulder a lot, but it's FAST - ie. stupidly fast physics-defying (as in, not even theoretical physics-defying) fights where you say 'hey, I want to kill that boxheaded robotic guy over there. Do I a) slide along the floor, spin around and slice him into two pieces at the waist LIKE A BOSS, or b) shoot at him? Which one is faster? Did I hear a)?'  Crazy trick stunts aside, there's a variety of weapons (although I have to complain that primary weapons are ALWAYS stronger than their secondary counterparts), and the thing that makes this game unique: Warframes.  Warframes being that robotic suit of armour which lets you do really absurd stuff, like pull whole groups off ledges to laand at your feet and get finished off by that great big reaper you just happen to be carrying. Or go so crazy that all the enemies in a large radius around you get confused and start attacking each other. Or shed your skin, or hit the ground so hard everything around you goes slowmo, or maybe even just bog-standard turn invisible.  There are warframes to fit most playstyles - support, tank, glasscannon - and all with unique ability sets, but none of them are biased towards a set of weapons. You don't get a sniper frame. You get a whole load of frames, whether fast, light and high-damaging, or slow but resilient, and you can lump whatever weapon you like on it. One good example is the primary healing/support frame, with her ability that directs all damage taken to nearby enemies while reducing damage done to herself, and slap a manually-detonated 5-shot grenade launcher on it. You can even get a compound bow/railgun with a high Critical chance, put it on the Warframe with an ability that highlights weakspots on enemies and massively amplifies damage to that point, and then run riot in a Survival mission where you need to kill LOADS of enemies to keep your oxygen supplies up.  All in all, this game is fast (if update-intensive), and well worth a try.

I should've reviewed this a long time ago but I forgot okay guys! Anyway...  Addicting. Very Addicting.   Everything on the table. Graphics are great, though style is a little dark/moody and might not be for everyone. Gameplay. Is. Amazing. The mechanics work so well in sync to bring an enjoyable experience of kicken royally kicken ♥♥♥ (until end game that is). You're a space ninja that can run on walls while pinning someone to a lamp post with space bow, or annihilating swarms of enemies with a grenade launcher while soaring through the air menacingly. The special ninja movement skills like wall running and sliding all trigger really smoothly (some more then others but whatev's :P), and the community is really great for a current f2p. The team stays really active within it, for instance prime time, their weekly thursday night live stream talking about current happenings. Honestly I totally support the community. Oh also for an f2p its not even pay to win because all of the best gear isn't even available for the real money currency, platinum. Warframe is basically a game where space ninjas are assigned missions to different places on the planet; whether it is to destroy reactors, capture a high value target, defend a cryopod, or assassinate someone of importance. Warframe has many different aspects to it, including creating a clan dojo of your own; living a code of honor that you see fit. In essence, you can create any weapon that you find the blueprints for, and about 85% of the items in the game can be found while going through the missions on each planet..  Is Warframe worth the download?  If you enjoy stealthing or running through killing any and everything in sight, creating weapons, doing parkour..then yes. By all means, download warframe and give it a try.

If you don't like grinding, I suggest you discontinue this read.  'Expensive game. Made changes to compensate against speed runners which ruined the potiental in this game. Enjoyed choosing between being stealthy, or switching to combat. Now near impossible to do multiplayer stealth.' - This was my old review.  I now do recommend this game, however it still is a grind fest. I am happy that they fixed the spawn rates, stealth system, and included a few new game modes to help grinding.  Positives  +Many Game Modes: Survival, Defense, Capture, Spy, etc, all a bit different.  +Lots of different equipments and warframes to chooe from to help ease the grinding.  +Multiplayer runs, dojo/clan systems.  +Clans can build their own base.  +Interesting PvP system for dueling, clan wars, and territory ownership.  +Everything in the shop can be built, best items aren't avaliable for purchase on cash.  +Trading system that includes trading in-game currency and cash-currency  +Material listed planet by planet to help find the materials you need.  +Neat Damage 2.0 and Melee 2.0 system to put a lot of details into equipment and battle.  Negatives  -Lots of items require 12-24 hours to build. Warframes being 72 hours (After the 12 hour parts are built)  -Only option to speed build items is real money.  -Cash store is really really expensive. (Ex: 20 Plat for a colours to customize your own warframe)  -Customization to personalize your warframe all cost money, very few choices can be earned by in-game currency.  -Some of the warframes are a little overpowered, and some are very underpowered.  -Limited slots of owning weapons and warframe. (Cost money to get more slots)  I find once you find your kind of warframe, and weapons. The grind isn't so bad.

'An indie game turned Tripple A' - ACE That may sound like a bad thing, but believe me I have nothing but praises for Warframe. Well I have the occasional Nitpick, but every issue I have with this game is counteracted by the fact that it's Free 2 Play. The good kind of Free 2 Play too none of that 'Free 2 play but if you spend money you're better than anyone else' BS. I wish there were a few more people playing PvP, but that's a personal gripe. The guns feel great, the powers feel great, and the freerunning; my god the freerunning. This game costs nothing so why are you still reading this? GO INSTALL IT!

Four steps to playing warframes - Pray to RNGesus - Farm - Rage - Build Repeat  10/10 Would farm Hieracon again  GAMEPLAY This game is really something, its F2P and you can still aquire every weapon and warframe is obtainable through hard work and dedication well unless you want to move on into fashion frame ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°) that may cost a little pocket money, but if you really are mindset of sticking F2P you can use trading for plat. The gameplay is all around satisfying, the variaty is amazing, Melee: Hammers, Swords, Staves, Polearms, Daggers and many more Guns: Machine guns, Shotguns, Snipers, Bows, Laser Cannons, Rocket Lauchers and many more. You can mod all of them as well to a very complicated level, you can adjust your weapons for different status effects Corrosive, Radiation, Fire, Cold, Toxic ect. or go with a crit build to make your crit chance & damage ungodly, there are also many utility mods to add accuracy, ammo amounts, reload speed ect.  EVERYTHING ELSE The graphics are shockingly amazing for a F2P and the soundtrack that comes with it is beautiful. The variation of areas, the icy tundras on pluto, the overgrown forests of earth to the void. The community is pretty damn good, i have not met a single hacker in my many hours of this game and most people are very helpful and polite. The game will last you ages, as there is no clear end to it as it gets updated pretty frequently.  Overall i suggest this game 100% if you can be dedicated and handle a little frustration once you get past that you wont regret downloading it, there are some Cons here and there such as bugs or little things that you may not like, but they are nothing compared to what the good part of this game has to offer

I think Warframe is probably one of the best free 2 play games that have been released through out the last few years. It offers alot of diversity when it comes to weapons, items, fighting styles etc. And a big point is that it isn't a Pay 2 win game since you can nearly get everything in the game without spending a single cent. As for myself i only spent 5€ once to buy some warframe slots, which can only be bought with platin (ingame premium currency). But other than this weapon slots and colors there is nothing else which can't be farmed. I do recommend to be a fan of grinding games though since you will need some patience to get certain mods for example (it also doesn't go any faster with plat).   The Mod System is also a great feature which makes it possible to fit your own playstyle. Whether you want a stealthy gameplay or a full aggro tank is your choice, but keep in mind that you should always try to pick something teamfriendly because especially in highlevels it's important to have teamwork at it's not really useful going solo into a group of enemies which maw you down in a few seconds.  All in all i can really recommend this game and I'd like to see you soon on the battlefields too. :)

Warframe is a great game because it has a little something for everyone. The game's 'Warframes' supplement each possible playstyle. A few bugs are present, which should not deter players since it is in Beta stage. Warframe has crafting for the people who like to make cool stuff, small puzzles for geniuses, a looting mechanic, the ability to make any weapon a total beast, and a variety of weapons to fit any playstyle: the sprayer, the sniper, the heavy hitter, etc. The music is awesome at first, but gets a bit repetitive after a while, but gamemodes are fun and are challenging if given time, even the first stage has challenging levels. Bosses are a bit overpowered but drop great items. Warframe is incomparable with other third-person shooters, you could say it's a different breed.

Where do i begin?  Warframe is in my opinion the single greatest F2P game Ive ever seen, even though it has quite some space for improvement. The main thing is the lack of endgame content second is the fact that you will have to spent some money on Ingamecurrency, if you don't want to spend tonns of hours on getting your gear onto a level from which you can get everithng without platinum (ingame currency).  The developers have announced what the Endgame will look like and it seems not to be to far away, but even without Warframe has plenty of different feeling weapons to craft, level up and upgrade so the wait for endgame isn't that tragic, I think it's amazing how long Warframe managed to exist without endgame content, somethng where many games like Guild wars for example have failed.  To the Pay2Win point: It really isn't that big of a deal as it looks at first, the developers regularly give opportunities to get some of the most important Items which can get you trough the game without paying, but it will take some extra time and i personally reccomend spending e few bugs for a smoth start. The only Thing i would really buy are Warframe and weapons slots to keep up a good diversity of weapons and characters  The really good things about the game: It has a very fast and dynamic gameplay with a huge amount of different weapon and 'characters' the three different enemy factions all desire a different strategy and with advanced levels and levelmodes it stays challanging for a really long time.  It has really fancy graphics and every faction has a different stile of tileset, which look amacing (the architecture of the Orokin Void, 'hidden places of the original faction which is mostly wiped out, just looks amazing).  Right now they are recreating some of the old features, like Meele fighting will get an improvement and many of the old lame bosses get new mecanics, there are many updates quite regularly which keep the game interessting.  And last i want to point out, what is the best feature: Each Warframe, they behave like character classes in other games, have a different theme and the amazing thing is that each warframe makes you play differently and the feeling of the different classes really comes across very well, something i haven't managed to find in a game this intence since World of warcraft. right now there are 18 Different Warframes and the game makes you wanna play in diferent stiles, from offensive pre Force (Rhino) to tactical deffensive (Frost) over an exposive antimatterwarframe called Nova to stealthy Warframes every shade of tactical Warframe is available and quite balanced.

Very much a grinding game, but in the third person style. Before I get deeper into anything I'd like to say that this is a good time passer, as defense and survival missions (endless until you want to leave) can take an hour (plus) depending on your group.  All of the weapons (except a few that were for founders only) are all available in game, purchasable with the credits you earn fighting or by their platinum (Real money). Using in game currency you have to purchase the blueprints through the store (They don't cost platinum) then you have to grind for the materials. And I mean grind, look at what is available where before you purchase, because it'll take you a while to get to the next location and time to farm the materials in that sector, then it takes 12 hours (Yes, realtime) to complete it, then you have to level it up to add mods.  Basically rinse and repeat that cycle of buying, farming, building, and you have Warframe. Some people hate games like this (Usually myself), but given it's allotted me the ability to kill an hour here, an hour there, it works for what it is.

I am reluctantly giving this a thumbs up. This game is a lot of fun and often hard to stop playing, but it has some real flaws.  It's a grindy PvE FPS with RPG elements. Warframes and weapons are crafted and upgraded. There are several mission types and a large number of levels.   The problems:  -Each level is one of about 6 designs. -The missions types all come down to running into a room, guns blazing, and pew-pew'ing everything. -The endgame is the same shooting and grinding as the early game. There really isn't anything to do once you have your weapons maxed other than collect rare items. -The trading environment consists of many many players who have lots to sell but very few players who are interested in buying what they can grind for themselves. -The warframe balance just doesn't seem right. There are definitely some OP abilities. -It doesn't really matter which warframe a player uses since there isn't really any class diversity. Just pew pew with any warframe, and when you have the energy, use your autokill button. -Low and high level players are often grouped, resulting in the high level players running to the end while the low level (or unequipped) player frustratingly gets to kill nothing. This also leads to a perception that the game is trivially easy, which it often is.  On the positive side,  +it's easy to play this game for an hour or two, leave, and come back the next day since there are crafting times.  +Almost all significant items in the in-game store can also be bought or crafted without spending real money. +Grinding and collecting items is a staple of a lot of video games. It's popular because it keeps players interested. +The most recent update added a number of new weapons, a new mission type, a new warframe, and a HUD overhaul. +Periodic alerts offer quests for players looking for purpose. These occur about twice an hour.

Totally underrated game with a surprising amount of depth. Very cool visual style & graphics, loads of playstyles and weapons with a mods system that allows for a lot of customization and control. Free to play with premium currency(platinum), but here's another bit of awesome: almost all the frames & weapons can be built using blueprints that drop in game; these require in game credits and resources that also drop. So you can spend a little bit of time farming and build something that could've cost you 5, 10, even 20$ worth of platinum(real money).   CONS: It's still in its infancy and has some bugs, but for the most part, I've seen the majority go away in the 5ish weeks I've been playing. Also, the voice acting is horrible. The voice of the Lotus will get very old very fast. You can just turn it off and pay attention for what is changing/happening. Some of the drops can be irritating. For example, if you want to build a particular warframe, you have to farm the assassination (boss) mission that drops those parts. You need 3: a helmet, a chassis, and systems. Then you can buy the frame blueprint in the market. Once all 3 pieces are built, those become the components of the frame blueprint. This is a great system, as I've said, but it can get tedious when you need one rare resource and have to start farming for those. So far I've not run into much I couldn't build with a little farming/grinding/patience. But keep in mind some higher level and rare blueprints will take some rediculous amounts of high end rare resources.   All in all I highly recommend more people start playing this. It's set to launch with the PS4, and it deserves that larger market. Pretty cool to get in it while it's still being built/open beta.

Warframe is a F2P game that lives up to most of the conventions associated with the payment model. Once you get beyond the first few hours, it does its best to try to loosen your purse strings. However, unlike many other free-to-play games, Warframe is honest in its assertion that it is, in fact, a free game to play. The time investment required to gain notable progress is not unfair. You won't find yourself hitting any brick walls in terms of progression or difficulty. All in all, Warframe is playable for those without much (or anything) to spend--something to be appreciated in the present landscape of F2P offerings.   With the F2P issue covered, lets look at what Warframe does well. Firstly, it looks great. The technical graphics and art direction are both top-notch here, especially for a F2P title. The animations are fluid and dynamic. The gameplay is easy to to pick up and the default keybindings are fairly intuitive. The warframes (classes, essentially) are all distinct and, for the most part, fun to play--I'd recommend avoiding Excalibur for new players, it's a boring warframe. The weapons and abilities are unique and feel impactful. Levels can be entered into quickly and generally don't take long to complete, which allows for players to squeeze in playtime when time is an issue. Finally, the servers are fairly stable and the cooperative play is well done.   There are, however, some things that Warframe doesn't do well. For one, the AI is pretty poor. Most enemies act as nothing more than cannon fodder, running headlong into your stream of projectiles. The levels are largely recycled and very samey. Also, there isn't much in the way of weapons and powers. If you're looking for deep customization beyond aesthetics, you won't find it here; which is peculiar considering most F2P titles attempt to load up the unlockable content to as large a degree as possible. Lastly, the game can be a huge timesink. While I stated earlier that the time required for progression isn't necessarilly unfair, Warframe manages to fall on the high side of grindy timesinks. This can be seen as a negative or perhaps simply as something that comes with the territory, your choice.   My recomendation of Warframe comes with a qualification. This is a grindy game that appeals to people that enjoy a bit of mindless farming (or in this case, a lot of mindless farming). If you're looking for a game to sink some hours into with simplistic, yet polished, gameplay, then Warframe is perfect for you.

Warframe is a great game. They created a 3rd person shooter unlike any other. The amount of weapons, pets and warframes (suits) is fenomanel and you can get almost everything for free.  So first I'll tell you the negatives. This is a game where you will need to hide behind cover but there is no proper cover system witch is a big problem. At first it may be hard to adjusting to having to crouch behind objects and move out of cover to shoot people but it is easy to get used too. The great thing is once your character ranks up a bit this becomes less and less of a problem.  I would suggest playing this game while it's free because it's going to become a full game (is in beta at the moment) and so this may add a price tag. Premium is something that can really make things easier but i don't suggest getting it because buyihng stuff always seems to be a waste.  The extensive amount of stuff is another thing. While there are about 14 warframes (suits) which are all completely different some a really overpowered and others underpowered, it doesn't work. The overpowered ones are hard to get and underpowered ones you start with (the best starting warframe is Loki btw) (second best is excalibre. I recommend buying blueprints for everything because their so much cheaper the only issue is you have to wait to build stuff and you have to collect items. Sentinels are really overpowered and bad for stealth (unless you get the one for stealth). They are basically pets and shoot enemies for you.  All around this is an awesome game with great gameplay it just has a couple of flaws. If you have enough friends to play with it can be very addictive but if you don't have any friends that are interested don't bother playing it because this game is made for multiplayer.

Warframe is, as you already know, free-to-play. It's a very fun game- the unique art style, extremely fast gameplay and fun weapons make the the first three or four hours very enjoyable indeed. I can say it's like no other game I've played before, and the idea of Space Ninjas still amuses me. The HUD's pretty slick and minimalist, and I do like the enemy design and the variations in the factions. The bosses are pretty fun to tackle, and the community is very good, as free-to play games go. However, there are some limitations. I'll ignore the occasional bug or glitch- it's still in beta. Level design can be a touch repetive, and there is a definite pay-to-win mechanic. I found that after about ten hour's play, I hit The Wall. I wasn't leveling up fast enough to compete with the other players and I couldn't buy any new weapons or any of the titular Warframes.  Overall, I'd recommend this if you're looking for a new way to play a 3PS and don't mind occassional glitches or paying real money for better ingame items. Also, space ninjas. Space. Ninjas. 7/10.
