Updated after Warframe Update 18.  My last review was to short and not prised the game enough. so i decided to make a full review on it.  For introductions. This is a 3rd person Action/Adventure game. Were you play as a space ninja. Many mysteries of your history is kept secret from you. You a Tenno, wake up in a solar system much like ours with some additional planets. Current status a war has broken out where one side figths to perserve, while another fights to progress. These two factions are known as the Grineer and Corpus. However there is a third faction that wants to conquer all. The Infested or Infestation. You as the playable Tenno can decide to perserve balance or pick a side, in the end all weapons are pointed at everyone regardless. Selfishly to say that its more fun and better that way.  For the game itself. On its own it too good to be a Free-To-Play. This game litteratly is the defenition of Free-To-Play. Altho the grind is hard but very rewarding. Game is highly optimised to where any old clunky computer can run it well enough to enjoy it. (I am one of said people.) This game is customizable heavy. You can pick any warframe, any weapon and set it up to your hearts content. You can even customize the color or said warframe and weapon to even add little decordive bits and skins to it. As a Free-To-Play everything is at your reach to obtain. Movement and controls are very fluint and smooth. Graphicly is to amazing to be a Free-To-Play, Brilliant colors and textures. The combat come in variaties depending on your weapon loadouts but overall combat is excellent. Nor much of a story to it but the story it has it going for isnt to shaby at all. In fact its perfect setting for the game as well as the immersion. Many mission and content thats is better shown than explained.  Altho it is Free-To-Play there is a micro-transaction system. However you can absolutly play the game fir free. No level limits, no area limits, no weapon limits, and no monthy purchases. The buying currency is called Platnium. Its mostly used to buy cosmetics and making the game progress twice a fast.  The community is absolutly helpfull. As long as you mind your P's and Q's people are happy to assist. Once again makes it unbelievable that this is a Free-To-Play. As for the developing team Digital Extremes [DE] for short. Are at nutbusting pase to always bring you new content, and wonder even if this new content is what the players want to begin with. DE is always puting the player first rather than there wallets. Weekly hotfixes and patches. Everyso often a game changing update that blows minds and gives the player another warframe fix to get addicted on.  Pros of Warframe. [+] Free-To-Win by beyond generouse defenition [+] Constant pacthes and updates [+] Tight but happy Community [+] The choice to play alone or with others. [+] Verioty of Combat [+] Content plue end game Content. [+] Craftable goods and weapons. [+] A plethera of Warframes and Weapons to chose from. [+] Warframe and weapons are upggradable through modifications. (Also completly free) [+] Unique different playstiles to chose [+] Many explorations as well as random generated level desing. (Rouge like almost) [+] Intersingt story, enemies, bosses, and assasins. [+] Simple to learn, Complex to explain.  Cons of Warframe [-] Grind heavy, but not as bad as Destiney because here is very rewarding. [-] Time consuming crafting. Making a new Warframe, Weapon, or Goods. Can last about 12 hours to 3 days. [-] A small window of exclusivity. More of my own personal Con than a overall. Its only a small window and the exclusives arent always the best. Just look better.  My perfetional opinion rating would be a 9/10 My totaly biast opinion rating is 10/10 Portable Orokin Technical Augmentaion Tactical Offensive.  POTATO for short.  Personal notes:  The game is a bit of a slow burn at first. Mainly all you have to soak in. However once you learned something once your ok for the rest of the game. Even though this game can be grind heavy that dosent make it a bad thing. I personaly like grinding if the grind is rewarding in some ways. I personaly tossed money in, but not because its required. Mostly because it deserves the money. I'm more than happy to invest into this game. There is plenty to do. im already over 1000 hours into the game and only fell i got another 3/4 to go before im through. Even so with new stuff keep getting pumped out i doubt ill ever retire from this game in the next 5 years. Even then i still have doubt i could even retire. This game is oddly satisfing in many ways.   Anyways thank you for reading my review. there prolly were some shorter version out there, but i hope you enjoy. This game is too good to be true for a Free-To-Play.

Fun free beta game with a few bugs, but constantly being worked on. 3rd person RPGish co-op shooter. up to 4 people can play missions, a lot like Global Agenda. Some good customisations for weapons.  **Updated review** Seeing as how I wrote my first review a long time ago, I figured it would reinstall and give it another shot and update.   It is fun for awhile, but VERY repeatative. There is virtually no story to this game. Bits and pieces of lore are sprinkled around, but nothing substantial.   -You are a good guy (or bad guy, we still dont really know) -1 of 3 factions are in a world and try to stop you from your objective (Rescue hostage, access computer/get data, carry briefcase to terminal/defend a few times, Endless defense, eliminate all enemies), then you run to a finish line -You get a pet to help you, either a robot or a dog, but you gotta farm for it -Collection game, gotta get all those cards to upgrade your weapons and armor. Dont forget about the micromanagement of said cards, gotta wade through TONS of duplicates to merge and upgrade the ccards themselves -All armor requires a fairly lengthy grind due to RNG -Sometimes a deadly boss appears randomly to 'avenge' someone else you killed -At any given time, theres really only 2-3 good weapons you should be using. Everything else is just a leveling grind to up your account level for bonuses  It looks good, especially at high settings. But it gets boring. You are mindlessly killing enemies without really knowing more than they are in the way. You can co-op with 3 other players for missions, but really you need to speed run to keep up with them. Dash to objective, complete, run to exit. Repeat  If you are looking to kill a weekend, by all means give it a shot. Long term, you will be burnt out on this never ending beta.

Warframe is amazing, you're a space ninja that can wield giant swords, katanas with ♥♥♥♥ stances and shoot arrows from pretty much the same bow with different stats and artwork, but no one cares because they are awesome, furthermore, you have rocket launchers, snipers, battle axes, pole arms, only one gunblade that is stupidly fun to use, you also have glaives (giant shuriken from naruto), shotguns, kunais, actual shurikens from naruto, some ♥♥♥♥ weapons that do look good and that are only really useful for ranking up your mastery level, and a sword and shield made of fire and awesomeness (Silva and Aegis). for all these weapons you'll need to farm resources, craft the resources, farm the money to craft the resources and the weapon, start the crafting process and wait for them to craft for ♥♥♥♥♥♥ amounts of hours and that is only for weapons.  Warframes are all so creative beautiful and unique and it never feels quite boring to play with them, the normal versions are also grindy to get and each component has to build 12 ♥♥♥♥ing hours and the warframe itself takes 3 days to craft once you've started the process. New warframes will need a new alert (daily missions) only resource called nitain extract to farm which is soo bad to get for newer players who just want to vary their playstyle and do something fun in the game not saying excalibur isn't fun, but he is no mirage who makes booby traps and disco balls of death. But even though it sounds like a terrible amount of grinding, weapons and warframes are quite rewarding, especially for first-time players who just got an interesting warframe like valkyr or chroma. And now for the primes, OH MY GOD, I HATE FARMING FOR PRIMES! they are special variations of the normal warframes featuring higher stats and polarities (let's put a pin on this one), the are visually stunning either black and gold or white and gold (depends on how you see the dress), they might have special particle effects and you are generally a pretty kool dude if you have one, but it takes time and a lot of praying for RNGesus to spray you with glorious prime part component blueprints for either warframes and blueprints, you'll have to play certain void missions to get a chance at the prime part blueprint you want and trust me, it feels SO GOOD when you get them. there are a few prime warframes in the game currently and you can buy one in the current pack they are offering, which is the latest prime released, then they'll withdraw the pack to introduce the new prime and make a new pack (note these cost a lot of real money), these also generally come with new weapons (primed) and cosmetics for you and your pet, the kubrow (doggy) or sentinel (space robot worms that fky and break your stealth game, except for shade, i love you shade :3)  The pet system is amazing, because you have different sentinels and breeds of kubrow, each specialising in something that helps in battle, and they are adding new pets which are the kavats (my own space kitty, yay), but you have to craft sentinels, by getting their resources, primed sentinels which are a pain in the ♥♥♥ to get, you know, the recurring torturous farming, grinding and temptation to buy platinum which is stupidly overpriced but makes the game so easy to muddle through)  Platinum.... ♥♥♥♥ you platinum, it's expensive but a not a necessity, one of the giant benefits in warframe that is very good and convenient but not needed to make the game fun, it's no Pay to Win game, it's a new type called grind and bullet jump to win, not like some games that literally ask to get prmium memberships and buy premium currency or else you'll be stuck with ♥♥♥♥♥♥ stuff forever, which in turn makes the game annoying and not fun, which is sub-optimal for a game, but warframe is free to play and not P2W, so platinum is there to make the game easier for you to play and make the game easier for the devs to make and they actually deserve the time and money some people put in this game, because honestly it's amazing and is constantly evolving (except for the AI of the enemies, seriously DE, fix that ♥♥♥♥!), and they are very in touch with their community and knows how to make everyone ride the hype train, they make anything sound awesome. They stream every week with the devs and the amazing community manager and space momma, DERebecca (she voices the lotus).  So all in all, warframe does have some flaws but they have over 18 updates so far, U18 being my favourite, they introduce new elements, renew old ones, substitute outdated and impossible to salvage things like your warframe abilities counting as mods and taking mod capacity, thank god they took it out. Finally they are amazing people at DE the community is amazing and full of hate and everyone bashing about how saryn is not OP anymore but instead is more dynamic and rewarding to use, so 8/10 objectively and 2000000000000000/10 for me, if you disagree......              ♥♥♥♥ YOU!!!! :3

Free to play games are usually shunned among alot of gamers, often written off as nothing but a trap hoping to make the player pay even more than they normally would. And it's undeniable, there are some really big names out there which give this particular part of the industry a pretty bad name. When done right though, it can be the poor mans way to gaming.   Warframe is a game that does this better than many others. First off, Platinum(the games special currency) can be used for these following purpouses:  -Speed up crafting -Buying weapons and warframes instantly withough having to get the materials -Buying cosmetics -Trading with other players -Buying slots for warframes and weapons  None of these provide an unfair advantage in the end. Players have the same potential for being good at the game no matter how much or little they pay. They simply cut down on grinding and waiting. Also the only purchase you'll ever need to make is more slots which are super cheap anyway. Note the fact that you can trade it with other players. This of course means you can earn Platinum without paying a cent as long as you know what to do.   But what about the game itself then? Well...  Warframe is an action-RPG shooter hybrid where you play as magical space ninjas with sparkly superpowers. The sole purpouse of the game is to shoot stuff so that you can get resources and blueprints so you can shoot stuff harder and get more resources and blueprints. You also have a quite robust parkour system at your disposal. It's not quite Mirrors Edge but it works and it brings alot more style and excitement to battles.   The game revolves around crafting and buying new warframes and weapons. Weapons can be all different kinds of rifles, launchers, laser miniguns etc. while melee weapons range from dinky knives to greatswords bigger than its user. Warframes on the other hand are basically different characters. Each warframe has a set of stats and four abilities.  Pros: -Parkour system is fun and makes the game feel uique from other shooters -Lots of lore to explore for those who are interested -Always satisfying to try out a new frame or weapon -Good f2p model -Tons of gameplay hours to be lost here -Generally polite and helpful community. Of course a-holes are to be expected here and there  Cons: -Grinding can sometimes get tedious if RNGsus is not on your side -Trade system could be better -Some things take way too long to get *cough* Equinox *cough* -Some weapons and frames are not worth the work to get them -Might be hard to know how to start out. Try to get help from someone more experienced if you find yourself not knowing what to do

Typically, free-to-play games lack in content, this game is an exception. The combat system is fantastic, it is both entertaining and extremely well-done. For a free-to-play user, the combat may become a bit repetitive, but for a paying player, there are many weapons to choose from, which keeps the game exciting and fast-paced. Warframe does a wonderful job at getting increasingly difficult through the stages. My only complaint about this game is the map, the atmosphere within each level eventually all begins to look the same, it is hard to tell at some points if you have already done a level or not. Regardless of this, I still highly recommend the game to everyone who enjoys a fun, combat-based game.

Warframe is fantastic game! there is at least one Frame that suits the playstyle of any player, and the developers did a great job in giving each frame unique movesets. They also went far enough to make each weapon look unique! You don't have to pay for anything if you don't want to which is a nice touch, yes there is a bit of real time waiting for when constructing something (12 hours for a weapon, 72 hours for a Frame) but its worth the wait. there are only a few things here and there which you would have to dig into your wallet to buy, but those things are justified, otherwise they are really hard to find/farm for. Speaking of which, the Farming/Grinding for specific blueprints or materials is way more fun then in other games as you'll more likely than not come up with other intriguing rewards, they may not be what you're looking for, but almost everything that you can find has a use.  The one teeny tiny problem I have is with a little bit of the voice acting. mainly with Lotus. Now don't get me wrong She's beautifully designed, the one thing she's lacking in my opinion is any real emotion, but I guess that is kinda explained in one of the stories (Second Dream). Second Dream was a great story speaking of which, however (without any spoilers) I can honestly say that I was mind blown, but after a while in the end a little dissapointed but thinking back on it I still like the ending because it still leaves some questions/secrets which I hope will be answered soon. I can't say what specifically disappointed me about it without spoiling a huge lore secret so I'll just leave it at that. However, that out of the way, Second Dream was all in all pretty damn epic.  OH MAN!!! I almost forgot something else that's really well thought out about this game. The extra (DLC like) stories (or episodes) are completely free! you just have to rank up, buy the blueprint for the specific episode and craft it.  I can't wait to see what else is to be done with this game, and believe me if I could make 3D models I would be designing helmets for a lot of the Frames (IVARA IS LACKING A LOT OF HELMETS!!!)

Great game!  The main feature that attracted me to this game was how free to play it is. You literally have to buy nothing with real money to actually 'win' the game. The only things that cost money are compeltely uneccessary cosmetics, most of which can be 'bought' completely free!   Here are some factors that led me to my mad addiction:   ~Through farming (How rigorous depends on the rng gods) you can buy pretty much anything with the in game with the 'money-costing' currency (Platinum) with the trading system allowing for the trade of parts/upgrades for platinum.  ~The Graphics are AMAZING for a free to play game!  ~Sounds are nice, new updated sounds are soon to be released. ~Many many frames(classes essentially) available, allowing for a diverse gameplay.  ~The crazy amount of builds that can be experimented with given the ample amounts of mods in-game. ~There feels like an endless amount of missions, as completing planets opens up more planets. On top of that there are special areas that contain specialized missions with specialized rewards from a specific loot table. (A very special place, as you can tell)  Cons:  ~Lots and lots and lots of gridning.....but this is counteracted by the vast amount of frames and weapon combinations, allowing for a more diversified gridning experience.  ~Certain builds are preferred by other players more than just a random build, making recruiting for a mission a bit tedious if you're running with an uncommon or made-up build.      TLDR; Great game, would definitely recommend to anyone looking for an in-depth, interactive mmo-rpg-fps-3rd person game.

Really fun game. Tons of unique weapons and characters to choose from and collect; tons of materials to collect; tons of missions to play- just tons of everything. The best part: you can trade for the real money currency! No need to actually buy anything (even though its always good to support the devs), but it does quicken the journey if you choose to. Most things are very well balanced (even though some things have fallen through the cracks...), and the customization is near-endless.  The biggest downside: most people just grind the heck out of a select few missions. If you need help with a mission, its hard to get people to join anything except for those select few misisons. Another downside is the trade setup: its just a constant, endless band of text in a chat tab. Good luck trying to read it all.  Overall, the games amazing. When you get bored of doing one thing, swap characters, and its like a whole new game. With probably around 20 characters, good luck getting off the game. Especially with blast damage on a hammer (enemies launch extremely far). I'm quickly closing in on 1100 hours on this game, and I'm still not bored of it. I HIGHLY recommend this game

One of the most enjoyable action/RPGs I've played. Not pay-to-win, either. The premium currency can be used either as a shortcut or for cosmetic items. I've probably spent more than I should have on this game for cosmetics or items that I didn't feel like grinding for, but at no point did it feel like a rip-off or that I 'had' to spend cash.  Each frame (think of a character class) feels unique and dynamically alters the way you play, and each are viable and uniquely suited for a given situation. After you get past the clunky tutorial, the missions flow easily - you can solo most missions if you feel like exploring and opening every single loot cache. . . or you can find other players fairly quickly to tackle the harder missions. Mastery ranks encourage players to try new things and keep their experience fresh, but the forma mechanic also allows you to keep any item you enjoy viable at all levels of play.  I'm a little ashamed of the time I spent playing this, but let that be testament to its replay value. I normally burn out on games much faster.

Though there is no actual visible end point to the game, it has a way of keeping you hooked on to accomplish goals. These goals may be certain quests and small (what i like to call) Candy Treats that give you a sort of high whenever you accomplish something that you wanted to. Even building a new semi-automatic rifle is a pleasure, because you get a new goal to make them better, stronger, and find what works, and though this may seem boring, this game actually gives you a sense of pleasure by watching yourself start weak and become strong. The crafting system is what gives the game a sense of Candy Treats because it gives you breaks inbetween the game so whenever you come back, you have something new to use and it is not the same as always. There is a high degree of costumization, and though it is hard to obtain, it is obtainable just from playing the game enough. It perfectly balances out time spent grinding, and time spent earning, and focuses more on the FUN of what a game should be, rather on the difficult challenge some games tend to exadurate thinking impossible quests are fun. I highly recommend this to anyone who is looking for a fun game to waste a ton of time on, and I highly recommend this game to anyone who loves beauty of design and story and costumization.

Phat loot EVERYWHERE.  NOW, make it free to play. This is Warframe. Ninjas play free.

TL;DR good game, trash company, dont you dare spend a dime, play for fun only!  Great game, but it's a shame it's been had by such a money-sucking company.  There was a point where I had about 99% of all items in the game, missing only exclusives and 2 boss-dropped guns (RNG for the lose). So I know what I'm talking about. Warframe goes through the standard MMO cycle; Release OP thing, profit, nerf thing, release exclusives, profit, repeat forever - printing money. Gammacor being a good example. And don't get me started on the horrible development cycle and spam of compile errors, but they managed to hold it together with glue and tape. This is almost the only game making them any money at all so I see why theyre milking it so hard. But frankly it's a giant negative for the game, and its likely to, and indeed should, turn off new players.   If you can play responsibly, and not throw money at the game, then it's great. Completionists and competitive-style gamers be ware.

I'm about to type out my first ever honest review...   Warframe is absolutely amazing for a F2P game. The quality that the developers have put in to the combat systems, the visuals, and just the gameplay style in general is way beyond a lot of newer games that you have to pay to play. ** COUGH COUGH *  DESTINY  * COUGH *. In this game, as you grind for resources to craft weapons, new frames, and other things, you find yourself getting hooked on the whole batshit-crazy ninja mechanics where's you're jumping off walls and murdering enemies simultaneously. I've seriously never experienced a more enternaining combat system that has been executed so perfectly. You'll find that not only are the gameplay mechanics extreemly fun, but generally, the atmospheres are really well established with very simple techniques, for example, when you're about to fight off some infected, you'll find that the area is dark, dirty, and just straight ominous looking. It's crazy to see such a well-detailed game be free to play.  all in all, if you're looking to become a futuristic, interstellar space ninja, fighting along-side your interstellar space ninja friends and ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥ up, look no further.

I have not played this game enough, I am still a scrub, please, carry me ;-;  But in reality, welcome to the most awesome grindfest, I have ever played.  Pros + + You are a space ninja called Tenno + Wanna run everywhere? No problem + Wanna get any weapon in the game? No problem + Wanna get any frame in the game? No problem (Except for effing Vauban)(and legacy Prime frames) + Wanna battle creatures and have some sort of a backstory + some form of a story line? No problem + The game has amazing visuals for a free to play + You can access everything fast through in game currency, but that is not necessary as you can acquire everything by completing missions + You can join Clans, many of whom have completed all of the avaliable research and thus you can acquire items, whose components you can't find through missions + Overall my personal favourite free to play with constant updates coming out, the devs have turned this rock into a marvelous gem, that only gets better + The gameplay itself is awesome, the Tenno are responsive to commands and are easy to manouver.  Cons -  - Grindfest lord - you can obtain everything in the game, but you will spend DAYS to acquire that ONE LAST component you need for an item - The RNGezus tends to be a ♥♥♥♥ - Occasional bug here and there, I once stuck in a wall during a mission, sometimes the frame doesn't go where you want to - You might grow bored of the grinding after a while - If you get into Warframe, you don't get out... you WILL come back, there is no escape - Stalker will ♥♥♥♥ you up, so prepare your ♥♥♥ during early levels  Overall, great game, 250hrs and I am still a noob, but atleast I have Rhino prime, so suck it. I rate it 9/11

I only recommend this because I remember the fun I had, and sometimes still have. It's worth what I've put into it and I don't regret it. I love the game, but the developers need to focus on longevity real soon. Right now, the main drive this game has going for it is the thrill of finding the pieces you wanted. The loot. And updates containing more to hunt down. It's also worth noting that its' community market's economy is pretty well balanced and even addictive.   Anyways. It's fun at first. Very fun. But quickly becomes rinse and repeat grinding. Some games do that well, but Warframe is a different story. It's core is too confused and a myriad of poor balancing from weapons to the Warframes themselves which make a portion of playstyles frustratingly inneffective. It's a viscious circle. You get the tools to be a slick ninja, but it's balanced around the fact that anyone can pick up a grenade launcher and blow the hoards away, or pick a Warframe that makes things trivial with the press of a button.  Two things need to happen to make this game a total must play. - An AI overhaul. (They don't even try to dodge your aim.)  - Severe weapon and Warframe rebalancing.   Because right now, the game only gets harder with numbers and caking on more health/damage. It doesn't get smarter or faster. Dial back the quanity for quality, and this will be as awesome as it seemed when I first picked it up.

Funny thing, this game. When I first tried it out, I honestly hated it. I uninstalled it immediately. The PvE seemed dead, and I hadn't tried out PvP because I'd just started. And I don't know, maybe having bought one cheap platinum weapon changed the game for me or something because I love the game now. I've gone through the steps of grinding out blueprints for a new Warframe and then grinding out the material, and it feels good to finally put on that new Warframe and try it out. Having played for about two years, I can say that this is one of the most enjoyable games I have played. Of course the lore of the game is limited as it is a F2P and muliplayer game. However, the game was not meant to be lore heavy and is all about making your 'personal world' via the grinding and playing of the game. The frames are very numerous and quite diverse and DE is constantly bringing out new frames and equipment. The stories continue to be upgraded and the community is overall very friendly.   This is a game of grinding to build your own ecosystem of sorts. If you are not into such games, Warframe will not interest you. However, if you do like leveling up your equipment, interacting with other players and creating a place for yourself, Warframe is a wonderful place to do so.   Oh and one final word. I have never 'Had to' pay for anything in the game. The only time I did was to give something back to DE by buying Pt during a 75% off deal (I already had thousands of Pt but did so anyway), or to buy Tennogen products. This is definitely a F2P game if you are willing to play it as such.

Aww man what a gem of a game. Almost 400 hrs in and I just scratched the surface of the content. Not even sure if I am mid-game already. So much to unlock and achieve still.   Pros : -Space Ninjas -Space Ninjas doing parkour -Massive crafting system -Massive research system -Dynamic builds. Meaning, you can customize and mod a Warframe that suits your play style, the way you want it, and if you do it right, it will be competitive. There are so many Warframes with so many abilities and so many weapons gears and modifications, that truely everyone is catered for.  -Interesting and involving quests and quest lines to discover and complete, spanning over multiple planetary systems. -Space Ninjas in space, with almost robotech type suit. Called archwings.  *-Very addictive  Cons : -Waiting walls. There will be times where you have nothing to do but wait for completion of a foundry project. Which time you could do something else or farm resources by repeating previous missions. -It is free to play, not pay 2 win, but the line is very thin, as you can buy just about everything through in-game means, but it will take you very long. -Game is very confusing at start. You will find yourself bashing your head with frustration through the first few days. Things are ill explained, and community is like ' Well, you should have known that. We do, since we been playing for so long' etc. No real helpful guides. You just have to push through and learn everything the hard way. *-Very addictive   Those are the big things that stand out for me personally. Definitely worth it though. I have managed to not only survive the first few days, but have managed to build a Dojo with all research structures and a lot of research, I have built 8 Warframes and 30 odd weapons. Done it all without having to pay. Just by trading in-game. I'm not even a power gamer. So jump in and get good, as that's all it takes to enjoy this awesome game.

Edit: Now that I have put a lot of time into this game I hit the 'farming point'. What I mean by that is I have unlocked all the planets, completed the main story line quest, and obtained most of the warframes you can get from bosses and grinding the same mission types over and over. When you get to this point the game just becomes a relic, vault, and void fissure grinding experience. It turns into this experience because to get 'prime' gear you literally have to run the same missions over and over to get relics. Then you have to take said relics and run the same missions types over and over to open them. The catch is that you have a slim chance of receiving the gear item you want from the relic, vault, or void fissure you are grinding. When you run void fissure missions you are given a chance at six different items from just that one relic. Even when you spend hours running void fissure missions to collect void traces to refine your relics its seems to help very little in terms of getting the exact prime item you need. I have run void fissure missions 50+ times with a refined relics and not gotten the item I needed (takes about an hour of grinding void fissure missions just to get enough traces to refine one relic). All this grinding doesnt even include the other materials you must grind to build said prime items after you have collected each piece. This style of game play is pretty much all that you experience once you have reached the end game content. Overall this game is excellent for the first 40 hours or so of gameplay but dies rather quickly when you get to the end game. Since end game content is a key feature for me in any MMO, I have to change my recommendation to 'no'.   8/10 for first 40 hours of gameplay  2/10 for end game content     This is a recommendation but it has some heavy undertones and issues that I am assuming will be fixed. If the below issues are not fixed then this would be a non recommendation.  Backround: I have only started playing this game since the new patch has been out. So I have no bias based on how the game use to be and how it is now. After reading the recent reviews I can tell that the way the game is now is worst off then it was before.   Problems: Simply no other way to put this other then you need friends with all the planets unlocked to even remotely progress as a new player. You will need crafting materials that can only be obtained on planets that you cant even unlock yet in order to unlock that hyper gate to said planet..... I think when they developed this patch they did not connect all the dots or test if a new player could advance off the first two planets on his own.   The second problem is arch wing missions. These are flying missions in the game and specifically they have timed ones that you must fly threw a very poorly designed level with very poor map icon indicators. Essentially you are flying through a randomly computer generated maze and 99% of the time it doesnt flow right. I have yet to beat a single one of these mission types. The patch notes say they fixed archwing flying mechanics but they still feel broken to me.   The good stuff: Game play is fun All the different moves and mods you can get keep the game intresting  It isnt a pay to win game its a pay to not wait which if your patient its a plus versus the pay to win system Everything in the game can be obtained by crafting and not paying real money (again have to wait for the items to build, you can pay real money to not wait) Fast flow missions, you can do a bunch of missions quickly or you can take your time. This is a bonus for me because some types are boring and you just want to knock them out fast.  Graphics are great on a good machine (Never tried on a low end machine but on a high end one it plays great) Multiple different warframe builds to play multiple different roles on a map. If you like chopping stuff then you can chop stuff, if you like shooting stuff you can shoot it, if you like blowing stuff up you can blow stuff up, if you like being a ninja and sneaking around then be a ninja.   Overall I like the game a lot but the not being able to advance past certain planets with out materials you cant obtain as a new player is going to drive you mad if you dont have friends that play. This seems like something they will clearly fix because it doesnt seem like they purposely designed it that way. Only time will tell where they take the game next.

First things first I play with intel onboard graphics so my playing experience will differ from others.  I started playing Warframe in 2015 after a friend showed me the game, i can say after almost 700 hours that this is the best free to play game currently on the market, DE have really done well, especially in making this game non pay to win which many other games promote and actively encourage *cough* Call of Duty *cough*.  Regarding my gpu the game often crashes on mission end and i can only load the missions if im not in the warframe window, but by no means does that ruin the fun of this game, the replaybility is endless no matter how many times you have to grind for a certain prime item, no two missions are the same, even boss fights.  Every Frame is unique and offers alternative playstyles for every player, even if they are not that good (hydroid), most frames are available by simply farming bosses, others can be get from quests, alerts and sorties, might aswell mention that my favourite frame is Nova Prime, but as i was saying every frame offers unique gameplay, unlike me though i reccomend playing every frame before you choose a favourite.  As for missions there are a huge variety of missions and map nodes to play (love the new starchart btw, also RIP Draco) there are lots of unique tilesets and due to the level being proceduly generated on every load up hardly any two levels are the same, the quests are also really fun and have interesting stories (War within hype).  Sorry for this generally short and unstructured review, but to write about all the positves and negatives of this game for me would take a while, but in short I would reccomnd this game to absolutely anyone that games, if you want a fun triple A quality game for free then this is the right game for you!

This game is simply a masterpiece, and a work of videogame art at its finest.  If there truly is anything from Warframe that needs to be mentioned, it's the phenomenal and optimized performance of this game on almost any hardware, including integrated graphics cards that aren't dedicated nor meant for gaming.  For one thing, this game's minimum system requirements are enough to get you interested immediately. It only requires two gigabytes of memory. Yes, two. Considering that the average memory today is thought to be eight, the requirement of only two for this game is almost too hard to believe, but it's true.  More so, the graphics card this game requires can have as little as half a gigabyte, not to mention this game only requires a dual core processor with two gigahertz that's ten years old. Even with those specifications, it's likely that you could still play Warframe at medium settings with a steady thirty to forty five frames per second, and that is impressive.  If the requirements still aren't enough to make you download this game, the visuals are very impressive in comparison to the hardware that this game requires. Considering how little power the minimum required hardware actually offers in comparison to modern day gaming hardware, the visuals far exceeded my expectations.  As a matter of fact, while I was in game, I even noticed that, while I had my framerate display visible, it showed that the game was still using up less than a single gigabyte of memory, even while you're in heavy fighting. Because of this low memory usage, lag spikes are essentially non existent for anyone who has at least four gigabytes of memory, even if you choose to play on maximum settings.  And finally, to top it all off, I have experienced very few issues or crashes while playing Warframe. During my time in missions, for me, bugs are almost non existent, all the while I have experienced, quite literally, only a few crashes over the course of six months since I downloaded this game.  As for the sound effects and music, many consider Warframe's soundtrack to be an underrated and hidden gem of the current generation of videogame music and sound, and I completely agree. What's even more delightful is that the voice acting is actually quite good, along with the actual quality and clarity of the sound effects.  What's even more tempting in a technical aspect is the incredibely expansive and wide variety of display and audio settings to change, many of which are unavailable to change in other games through conventional means. In short, Warframe is a rare gem that will easily attract the attention of those who enjoy technical customization.  To finally give you an idea of just how superb Warframe's performance really is, I am currently using hardware that would've been considered acceptable for a heavy gaming setup at least five years ago. The graphics card I use is at least five years old, and has roughly a third to a fourth of the memory that most people would have for a gaming setup. More so, my memory is at least half of what most people would have today, not to mention both it and my processor could be considered up to ten years old.  And yet, even with hardware that aged, I still manage to play Warframe on its maximum display settings, all the while maintaining a minimum framerate of at least thirty, even during an extremely heavy fight with three other people doing the same alongside me, and at times, even exceeding sixty. A game with that type of superb performance, combined with visuals that, at maximum, were considered impressive for the year it was released, is a very rare gem to find, and does not come often.  After all that I have said about the game, it should be more that enough to tempt anyone into downloading this free gem of shining beauty into their library. Warframe is nothing short of a work of art, and those who first developed the game should be very proud of themselves, because, in a technical aspect, they have done what very few games in the current decade have managed to do, if any at all. I can only begin to hope that other game developers learn from what Warframe's developers have done, and follow their example.  With all of this said and done, this is the perfect next gen and intensive game for anyone who is on a budget, including myself. If your computer's hardware is no more than ten years old, then it will play Warframe. Even if that means you have to lower your display settings, you will still get a playable framerate that is considered acceptable and average by most gamers, many of which would say thirty.

What DE has done up to this point with this game is amazing! I was playing this since the closed beta and they've come a long way since the days of one gray spaceship hallway after another. The game is huge, varied, colorful and chaotic.   While it is true that you can get every weapon and possibly every warframe for free just by playing. Don't know if this is still true but back 2 years ago you could build the warframe by collecting parts in the more difficult planets. The slots you have to open up to hold them in your inventory though, take real money. Also, you have to griiiiind in this game. It could potentially take you hours a day just to get enough of one item so you can build what you need. That means doing the same mission, doing the same thing over and over and over again. In a way this is a casual game but in another way it isn't.  You have to be willing to commit your time and money to this game if you want all the weapons and warframes. If you aren't a grinder type of player and don't have the money to spend on inventory slots, you can still have fun with this game for a little while but then there will eventually be that threshold where you have to decide. How far do you want to dive in? For me, I spent about $40 from the start to when I stopped playing and got over 400 hours of game time that I really enjoyed. The grind got to me though and I was unwilling to spend anymore money on slots.   This is one of the best co-op games out today. It's massive! the shooting feels nice. I've never had any problems with the community. Flipping, running along walls and sliding around like a badass ninja feels great! There's just that one problem of commitment. How much time and money are you willing to spend? At least give this a try since it's free to start out and see if you like it. I'm sure you'll get plenty of hours of fun out of Warframe.

The game for me, was really fun the first 500 hours. It was a new experience with cool grafics and so on.. HOWEVER: The game really only consists of farming. If you want to build a new weapon; farm for the parts so you can craft it. Want a new warframe?; Better find the ingredients for it first...  After you finished crafting the weapon/warframe, gongratulations you now have a new weapon.. Btw. The only way to lvl up in this game is to first level up your warframe/weapon. And for that you will once again have to farm so that you can craft a new weapon..  Warframe consists of endless farming, which can get really boring after a while as Warframe never really gets anything new to the gameplay (except warframes and weapons.)  Currently I only login in once in a while to check out if something new happens, then log out as usual nothing new is there.  Save your time and play something else, as you will only regret it later.

For a game like Warframe, I wish there was a 'kind of recommend' button. Don't get me wrong, it can be fun, but this is a good example of how you can take the pay-to-play model and ruin a game. If you really want to be successful, you have to join a clan, but in order to join a clan, you have to have really good gear, but in order to get really good gear, you have to invest tons of play time OR outright buy the stuff with real-world money. I might change this review at any point if any update makes me wanna throw my computer out of the window. My old review:    Let's keep this short and simple. Controls are nice, graphics are flashy, the soundtrack is appropriate and let's face it, you're a space-ninja. Buuuuuut, that doesn't mean bugframe doesn't have cons. With every update you have to wait for a couple of hotfixes, cause of certain bugs that keep reappearing, it's a tough start for a new player (but it's like that for any MMO), the RNG is terrible, some changes that come with updates, the so-called nerfs, are usually uncalled for.  Still it's F2P and if you play well enough (or if RNGesus blesses you with multiples of rare stuff), there's a trading system, so you can sell the rare stuff you don't need to lazy players with platinum ($€-bought in-game money) for that said platinum. All-in-all it's a game you need to play a bit to figure out if you like it or not.   My new review:     I stopped playing the game. Not because of any gamebraking factor, or any major change. It's because everything feels the same. Sure the quests are a nice change of pace from regular missions,  BUT  EVERY NEW WARFRAME, EVERY NEW WEAPON (well not every weapon since most of them are craftable through market), EVERY NEW WHATEVER PIECE OF EQUIPMENT YOU NEED, YOU GOTTA FARM IT FROM BASIC MISSIONS OR a bit different version OF THE SAME BASIC MISSIONS, for which you ALWAYS EQUIP THE SAME SETS and JUST MOSTLY CAMP OR DO A SPEEDRUN OF THE MISSION TO GET WHAT YOU NEED AND THEN YOU RINSE AND REPEAT UNTIL YOU GET WHAT YOU WANT!!! And while we're on the topic of new stuff... They have a tendency to nerf every single thing in the game... Except enemies, which get a buff every once in a while... The community is still decent, well it is getting a bit cancerous, but that comes with every big F2P game. Also one more thing that is with most if not all F2P M.M.O. games, the EULA contains them being able to ban you for whatever reason they want to. I don't mind that part, I mind when they ban people who just comment on what wasn't fixed and what should be fixed with updates cause something is broken in-game.

This game will get you hooked. The amount of unique weapons and mods will keep you grinding for hours but it never feels like a chore because of how awesome you feel flipping and wall-running and spraying bullets as you progress toward you next piece of loot. The armors are called Warframes and are more like classes than actual armor. Each one is a little different and most are quite good. But amazingly enough, every single feature you can get by paying is also obtainable through just playing the game. I don't think there's a single-pay-for-only feature. Now playing without speding a dime is going to take you more time but that's it. Nothing more. As a wondeful little bonus, the game looks amazing and incredibly unique. It might not look as cool to everyone else but to me, this sets the game apart as something very, very special among other loot based shooters like Destiny and the Division.. Don't play Destiny. Don't play the Division. Play Warframe. This game is for: Players who enjoy feeling like a ninja, players who enjoy loot based shooters but either can't afford of have grown tired of Destiny and the Division This game is not for: Players who do not enjoy any type of grinding

(I know i do not have much time on this game but this is merely my opinion from my experience so far)  I mostly recommend this game if you have a bit of spare money that you are willing to spend on a game. Because if you do have a bit of spare cash, this game will be incredibly fun in some ways, since almost everything can be bought with platinum, which is this games currency from micro-transactions. The amount of cool things i've seen from people who have spents lots of money on this game, is unrealistic. It makes me feel like a less cool space ninja guy, but meh, i'd rather spend my money elsewhere.  If you are like me and dont want to or have any money to spend on a game, this game can still be somewhat addictive to some extent. I first heard about this game when it came close to being one of the top mmo's where you need to farm like crazy, and boy was that list right. I spent a whole 24 hours just farming for neurodes, which is a crafting component for many weapons. I only got about 4-6 within that time. Whereas a friend of mine got around 50 within a couple of hours. So i just guess that my RNG is bad.   I kept on saying to myself whilst farming 'Why am i still doing this? How can i do this for so long?' The thing that made me stick, is the variety of 'tactics' you could use. Now i quoted that because many people would disagree and say this game isnt tactical at all. And i also somewhat agree, as i've seen people stand still as trinity and any other warframe, and just spam abilities. And that doesn't look fun at all, nor tactical.  In conclusion:  If you have some spare money in your steam or paypal then you will more than likely enjoy this game and play it for hours on end.  If you want to play this game and not put any money into it, you will need alot of spare time and patience to get to the point where you will enjoy it the same as those who have put money into this.  I'd give this game a 8.5/10 if i were to give it a legitimate rating. This game could be perfect, but my personal RNG is whats making me not enjoy this game at all, and the fact that people who put money into this can have a much more overpowered things in a much smaller time frame, but heck, i guess thats how micro-transactions work.

Warframe is one of the best Free to Play games on the market and certainly one of the best if not the best 3rd Person PVE based shooters out there. A Very healthy community with many players who's endgame is just to help out newcomers.  That being said it really is a sandbox endgame. For some, its grinding the void to get all the prime weapons and frames. Others want to set records and see how far they can go in a survival or defense mission. And of course Fashionframe is the true endgame.   Every frame and weapons truly feels unique and you will have countless hours of fun trying out new builds to fit your playstyle.   On the topic of the in game market. PLatinum is the premium paid for currency used to buy weapons and frames from the market. However, everything except cosmetic items can be obtained without spending any real cash. Some games have this model as well but with an absolute ridiculous odds and actually being able to collect everything you want unless you pay for it. You will never feel that way in warframe. With relative ease and alot of fun doing it will collect blueprints and parts and build different frames and weapons in your foundry. The best part about it all? If you grind out the rare prime parts from the void, other players will be willing to buy them from you for platinum which in turn can be used to buy things from the market. If anything, Warframe is pay to speed up and most certainly NOT pay to win.   The Developers (DE) give constant updates and balances, and are in frequent contact with us. Between Dev Streams and ingame messages about hotfixes, I can easily say that DE are probably the best developers at listening to their fanbase and responding to them.   Give warframe a try, its free and a ton of fun.

I feel that at the 600 hour mark, its time to write a review for this game. This was the first game that i downloaded to my computer almost 2 years ago when I got into PC gaming. Needless to say, the game has DRASTICALLY changed since then. However, it's still amazingly fun.  People usually describe warframe as a grind (which it is). It's a different kind of grind though. All the weapons and warframes have a purpose (with like maybe 2 exceptions), and are just fun to use. Thats it. This is just a fun game that i literally am stuck playing because it's jsut freaking fun to fly around like a ninja chopping enemies in half and sending them ragdolling into oblivion with a grenade launcher.  Get it, try it out, it's free afterall. If you dont like it, oh well, you didnt loose any money.  EDIT:  GG DE, ya got me with the 2, 75% off of platinum purchases in a row. Guess who has 8k plat sitting around, and nothing to spend it on.  Thats the problem that ive run into after an almost 300 additional hours since i wrote the first review, is that im starting to run out of shinnies, and the new shinnies arent really that interesting to me. The newest weapons like the stradavar and dark split thingies are trash and a waste of time. The devs need to spend less time making copycat 'trap' weapons that suck, and make more interesting unique weapons that could serve a purpose. I need something to use that can take out the lvl 120 enemies i face on a regular basis BESIDES the tonkor or synoid simulor or vaykor hek.  Recent reworks to warframes like Saryn and Mag (Volt is excluded, his was good) have blow a huge load. Thats all i have to say. Still would reccommend this game despite the gripes.

So, I've come back to Warframe and so much has changed. I can finally say I love this game in it's current state. Yes, there's a hell of a lot of stuff that requires some pocket money but there's also a lot of stuff that you can earn yourself and I feel like you won't be hampered too much unless you find cosmetic looks insulting to your character. This game has fantastic fluidity in it's movement and combat systems (with the right movement combo you can genuinely go 0-100mph real quick). The game is graphically awesome and is well optimised in various areas, all of these options are changeable to your own spec ofcourse.   Warframe is a very nice switch up from the regular fast paced action MMOShooter and I truly believe and stand by the fact that if you played this game before the huge update it has had and stopped playing since, give it another go now. Honestly, I'm thoroughly impressed with the direction this game is taking. Do not be turned away by the microtransactions as like I said, a lot of these items are available through Mastery Rank and using blueprints to collect the resources you need to make them.  Pros: - Great storyline so far - Character design and background is very interesting - Feel like a total badass whilst wrecking everything in your path - Large choice of weaponry and armour (anything to tailor your destructive needs) - Online servers are very, very good. Hardly ever any drop in connection etc.  Cons: - Lengthy wait on the foundry for a lot of weapons and items (patience is required for better gear but not complaining) - There are A LOT of micro DLC options (again not complaining but they're everywhere in game) - Sometimes struggle to find a team to match up with (not all the time)  That's really it. Like I said if you haven't already, pick this game back up, it has its own launcher/patcher now as an external output from Steam once you've downloaded it from the store to your library but yeah, truly loving this game at the moment and cannot wait to reach endgame content!  - Ryzun

So, this is an awesome game, except they made some changes that depends on good team work playing. They now have these 'fissures' that pop up though-out the mission and you need to collect these relics from the fissures as you kill things in order to get very rare items.  The Problem: You need to complete a misson WHILE doing this, and some missions need to be done first, before worrying about gathering these relics which pop up through the entire time that you are doing the mission and even after as long as you don't exit. In one such case there is a capture mission where you need to run after a guy and shoot him down and 'capture' him. The problem is, not everyone is a team player and happily collect their relics as you run off to catch the bad guy. Then, once the capture is done and the OTHER people who didn't help collect all their relics, go off to exit. You MUST get all your relics in order to get your rare item (You need 10), so since you were single handedly chasing this guy down because others cannot be bothered, you could risk losing your chance on getting the rare item if the people close the mission out on you.  The void fissure method, I do like it, but there are some styles of missions it should NOT be on. To top it off, they now also have a guy that will appear in missions who are very strong and can appear in these fissure missions. My boyfriend and I were running off to get the capture target, while the other 2 decided to do their own thing, then this guy also came and was kicking our asses, while we are also trying to take down the capture target and eventually they came to help, but refused to revive anyone who fallen, then since they had all their fissures they were about to go close the mission. Luckily they didn't but my bf used up the last of his self-revive while trying to get the fissures, and he lost out on the entire mission.. fun right?   This game has brought out a lot more d*cks, and my ignore list of blocking these players is going to get very full very fast.

Warframe, my dear dear used to be favourite game...  Don't get me wrong, I love this game.  I put quite some time and money into it..  So let me just summarize some Pros and Cons.  PROS: - The game has AMAZING graphics, for it requiring such a low performance - The gameplay is very fluently and addicting - The Community is truly great, I did not encounter one toxic player so far. - You Do not nead any other players to complete any missions, everything is soloable (except Raids) - You can change every Weapon, character or companion to your personal play style. - there are scheduled Dev streams where the dev will interact with the community  CONS: - The game is hard to learn, I started playing with a good friend of mine, and we had trouble learning all the details about mods, crafting and everything... If you do not have any contacts in the game, visit the forums or any other place to get Information about the game - The game requires a lot of time, meaning that the characters (Warframes) you can farm are seperated in different drops, (Helmet,Chasis Systems, Blueprint etc) which all drop from different sources.(And are Rng based) - You need a lot of platinum (ingame currency) to equip your account   MICROTRANSACTIONS  Yes, the game is free, yes there are microtransactions... so how do I start this... with the ingame currency (platinum) you can buy cosmetics,ships and the newest update stuff (weapons,warframes,ships etc)  You Can however trade the stuff you farmed on the market with other players against platinum or other items.  Also, there is this thing called slots.. For weapons and Warframes... You need platinum to be able to own more weapons and Warframes, which is quite exepnsive should you plan on getting all warframes...   What made me stop playing:  The simple reason I stopped playing was that there is no actual skill improvement. After I got everything you could have gotten in that time I started realizing that all I am doing is getting the new released items, stop playing, waiting for an update and get the new released items again.  There is NO actualy skill improvement compared to many other games  (I will just use csgo,chess or smth like this as an example)   END WORDS   This is a truly great game, I can just recomment playing it, it has amazing graphics,story and gameplay supported by a great community. But prepare to have a lot of struggles learning the basics  On my last note I can leave the hint that the Game has a lot of little 'features' I did not adress here simply to not spoil the game.

But......the premium currency is kind of easily obtained through gameplay. You get these parts to powerful weapons/warframes, and you can trade other players for them. So for example, lets say you got a 1, but you needed a 2, you could trade a player your 1 for a 2. 5/5 stars handsdown.   -Just don't get addicted

My Opinion of Warframe is good so long as you don't have an opinion (insta-ban for speaking against the Devs)                  + Warframe always has something new every time I come back to it + There's Warframe diversity + 200+ weapons to collect + You can modify these weapons to your style + It's free to play, and everything that would cost money to get can be bought by trading. + It's a grindfest + You never run out of things to do + Sometimes rewards exploration + End-content is challenging  - There's a lot of bugs/glitches - A lot of warframes prove ineffective - You can't keep all 200 weapons and/or warframes you've earned unless you're willing to spend money - There's a usual preset you use for weapon modifications - Feels repetitive after a while, even when aiming for different things after every mission. - Trading can be tedious and you're not able to trade resources (to help friends/be helped).

Most reviews of this gem of a F2P seem biased towards two very prominet sides: Those with over 1200 hours ingame complaining about a lack of stuff to do at that stage; and those who have played for less than 400 hours, spent all that time grinding and are now bored. I felt it necessary to adress this game from a midpoint perspective: I don't have an insane playtime count ingame, but nor am I new to this genre.  So, if you can run Warframe, and haven't yet: what on Earth are you doing? Even if you aren't one for farming or mindless slaughter, give this game a college try. It's fun, varied and quite unique in its styling and storytelling. I personally didn't expect much from a freebie, but **** was I wrong. The random generation of maps, the simple fact that RNG won't constantly **** with you (unless you want Equinox :P) and resource hunting is enjoyable.  On the other hand, nothing in life is perfect (except the deity of your belief, of course). This game has bugs and its assortment of issues. Enemy's armour scales to the point where only cheesing the game does anything; some frames are stupidly better than others; and of course random bugs and glitches. You'd expect the devs to pay more attention to these key issues rather than shoving content down the launcher and nerfs up the frame's backsides, but thats the reality.   So, with all that said and done, is Warframe worth your time? Absolutely! Despite its issues, the game stands out as a shining beacon in its genre of a looter-shooter, only really outshadowed by Borderlands 1 & 2 (Destiny? Don't get me started >:| ), which is saying alot for a freebie. The devs have been a bit careless recently and some recent changes were stupid if not unecessary, but the game lives on. People complaining about the endless grind: They are immature. Why sign up for a game that OPENLY admits it's a grinder, and then complain about it? People claiming a lack of content? Name ONE game that has endless content, and enough content to live over 2000 hours? None? Thats what I thought.... (Multiplayer only games 'content' is different in the fact that they don't effect total playtime, because they don't dramatically change playstyles like PvE items do)   So, to end this review: Is it a good time to jump into Warframe as a rookie? Definitely. Are you a veteran wanting to try come back to your old stomping grounds? Maybe not yet.... DE are still implimenting changes for late-end game content. But, alas, I return to the long wait for the War Within.  Thanks for reading this review. Go back to playing games..... Go......

To tell you the truth, this game does get on my nerves sometimes. Since its release, I've developed a habit of putting 20-50 hours on it, then uninstalling it for a year or so. When I get the itch to play it again, I reinstall it, and then spend a considerable amount of time glued to wikis and walkthrough videos, trying to make heads or tails of the changes that have happened since I was gone. It's easy to get lost in the ever-changing landscape of this game, and you best not get too attached to any one aspect of it, as it could be gone with the next update.  Now, at the time of my yearly rage quits, I might be inclined to not recommend this game, but that is ultimately unfair. Despite the long hours of grinding, or constantly having to rely on the internet to tell me how to complete certain tasks, or the sudden jumps in difficulty without warning, this still remains the best free-to-play game I've encountered, hands down. For me, the enjoyment outweighs the frustration. (And of all the games that require a lot of grinding, I definitely have the most fun doing it in this one.)  What you get in the end is a third-person action game with extremely satisfying controls (most of the time), gorgeous (if repetitive) environments, and a lot of fun crafting and management elements, all with a price tag of zero. My advice to you is to heed the warnings of the negative reviews, and then give it a shot anyway.

For someone with two jobs, a girlfriend, and a 2 month-old puppy, committing to the grind of Warframe just isn't realistic for me. However, much like Destiny, I think that the core moment-to-moment gameplay is strong and impactful enough to keep me engaged for short spurts of time. I just do wish that the long-term gameplay loop wasn't centered around endlessly grinding for new weapons and frames, and more about something a bit more meaningful. Then again, the sense of worth and meaning one derives from a game is completely subjective, so take from this what you will. Certainly recommended for those who have the time.

WARNING: Do not count on this game's tutorials and in-game info to guide you through it. You will NEED either someone to teach you or a good third party guide.  That said, this is probably the best F2P out there. Fantastic mobility and control, satisfying as all hell in terms of high level weaponry, this game's core gameplay loop is fun as all hell.  Which is good, because this game is also a bit of a grindfest, especially earlier on when you're stuck to the lower difficulty planets which yield less rewards. Stick with it past that hump and you'll be rewarded plenty.  Also, be aware that while you can buy everything in the game with the cash shop currency, Platinum, not everything in the cash shop is worth buying at ALL. In fact only a few things are. Don't buy without a guide!   The good news is, Platinum can be traded between players, so if you're willing to do the farming that others don't want to, there is nothing in this game that you can't get for free.  This game is a bit 'mysterious', the lore and other stuff about it isn't obvious. If you're willing to dig into it a bit, and figure things out for yourself, it's awesome. If you want to be guided, this isn't for you.

This game has changed tremendously over the last year and for the better. When I first started playing back in June '13, it was a cool little game to just collect stuff in, level up items, and fool around a bit. The game underwent a major overhaul for its PS4 release and is now expanding in all categories including lore, map variety, mods, weapons, and warframes. I updated this review pre-update 14, and the additional quest/lore system, upcoming mass-UI, and player ships are HUGE improvements to look forward which will further solidify the game as a serious and unqiue title.   The mechanics are very attractive, mixing fast movement with gunplay/melee combat and the special powers of each warframe. The mod system can change up combat as you see fit, and any gun/melee/warframe is viable with enough love put into it. The graphics are bright and shiny, and the game is pretty well-optimized for older systems. Tile sets for maps are finally taking the game off of ships and onto planets. Sounds for enemies and environments continue to be updated for the better. Dojos offer players a way to create clans and design/decorate their own 'house' of sorts. Warframes and weapons can have customized color, attachements, armor, skins, and syndanas (scarves).   Best of all, the game boasts a dedicated developer team who usually respond quickly and respectfully to the thoughts and wishes of the community. They even run live streams which are fun to watch and offer a kind of interaction that a lot of games miss. One of the biggest improvements I've seen due to this dev-player interaction is through events, which were once extremely annoying due to their setup but are now engaging and fair to both the occassional player and the diehard clan alike.   The cash shop for this game is also rather extreme but this is F2P and to be expected. The game lacks dedicated servers, but several changes put into the grouping system have made joining a terrible host much less common. The pve/psueo-pvp Dark Sector system was arguably released too early and right now doesn't offer players/alliances much benefit. However, with DE's track record, it's suitable to have faith the Dark Sectors will continue to be improved upon. There is an actual pvp system in the game, but having never bothered with it, I can't offer any opinion.   RNG is perhaps the one big drawback of this game. Much of the game's content relies on RNG, which after a while gets very tiresome. To date, not much has been done to allow players to have some influence over RNG (except outright buying said items through store or prime access) and there are many tweaks that could be made to make things less grindy..  Yet, there's a lot of good in the game and all the reason to trust that improvements will continue. If the game had some kind of membership system, I'd definitely buy into it without a second thought. It's plenty obvious this game is growing and growing quickly under focused guidance. It's good to see a team that's not afraid to remain in the beta phase and still get stuff done. High hopes for this one!

Its a fun game with a deep lore and plenty of stuff to do Pro - it has a variety of missions and modes to play - can play with/ interact with other players - the movement or the parkour is really well done and smooth - the combat can be played as a murder crazed psycho or a stealthy snek - a variety of 'warframes' you can play with  Con -it does get repetitive -there are a few game modes where it would be more efficent if you had a group -A ♥♥♥♥ LOAD OF GRINDING to get some of the simplist stuff -based on a 'platinum' currency (real world money)  -platinum is not availibe to come by in regular gameplay (have to pay real money) -warframes require platinum in order to get the full 'frame' -Basicly: platinum is every where in this game  Up to you -quick combat -neverending stuff to do  -you can get 'blueprints' for weapons and warframes but require a lot of grinding (not a ♥♥♥♥ ton but quite a bit) -there is an trading system where you can trade stuff (but only 'prime' items it seems like and 'mods) -the bosses need some form of skill in order to kill (but somewhat tanky)  In the end my biggest complaint is that platinum is needed buy items and stuff from the shop (not everything only uses platinum) but bluepprint can be bought with the in-game currency. It is still a fun game and the platinum thing doesnt take away from the gameplay, just that it later in the game it becomes anoying.   TL;DR  Fun game, great gamplay, always have stuff to do, platinum is real world money and is practiclly every where, quick combat, other player interaction, and a good deal of custumization

During the last years, Warframe slowly crept it's way up the Steam-Charts, silently creating a sizeable playerbase all around the World. Given that War Within, the next big 'Story'-Update is emerging soon, i found it more than appropriate to post my review of this at second glance really abrasive looking game.  To an outsider looking in Warframe may look like absolute sensory overload, a good looking Free-to-Play Game with high-octane action throughout any mission. At second Glance however, a steep learning curve, lack of explanation on the Game's part and huge Grindwall may turn any newcomer off, if there isn't persistence in that Gamers mind. Lastly at third Glance, the Game's depth and true potential may be finally seen, as the Gamer reads up on all the little hidden mechanics, gets in touch with the mechanics and learns how to overcome his own lack of persistence. The only thing remaining is the Grind, but if it's fun, is that a bad thing? :P    Pros:
Old: Pretty good.

TL;DR: A game cant be all bad if it takes 1,800-ish hours of my life over 3 years. One of the best F2P 3P shooter games out there with depth in mechanics, movement, and lore that'll satisfy the space ninja in you.

830+ hours (downloaded outside of steam). I would rate Warframe 4 out of 5 stars.  Pro: - Truly free game. I've used the trade chat and farming to make enough money to get almost anything I've ever wanted in this game. And if I couldn't afford it, there was enough other options to get by with that I didn't care.  - Great action combat between every weapon type imaginable. Shotguns/ assault rifles/ great swords/ lasers/ katanas/ ninja stars/ scythes/ cannons/ grenade lauchers/ etc.  - HUGE variety in weapons, classes-(frames), and mods-(builds) that allows a broad selection of play styles. The builds can be changed at any time for free.  - Super active community full of helpful people. The region chat is always active, no matter what time I log on.  Cons: - Not enough content. I was bored very early in this game, but I found goals to keep me playing. Mostly farming for a weapon I thought was interesting, or a frame, trying different builds for weapons and frames, etc.  - Very fast paced and antisocial in most public games with strangers. Not enough time to communicate because players rather compete for the most kills or the highest damage, then rush to the extraction and never see them again. It's better with clan members though.  - I can see it slowly transitioning into the endless RNG grind that mmorpgs are notorious for. They've recently added Riven mods (extremely strong mods), which cost kuva, kuva takes a long time to farm. You use kuva to reroll the stats on a riven mod. Also, riven mods are for random weapons. You don't get to choose which weapon it will be for. As you reroll the random stats, it begins to cost more kuuva each time, forcing you to go grind more kuva, searching for those perfect stats.  They said Riven mods were to encourage players to use older, weaker weapons, but they also gave riven mods to the META, the best weapons... That's not going to encourage us to play older/weaker weapons. It's going to force us to buy or grind for Riven mods for the BEST weapons if we want to keep up. And since players are selling these Riven mods for THOUSANDS of platinum, the grind is becoming ridiculous.

That being mentioned, it's kinda boring to grind sometimes ;pp. Up to you whether you like it or not pce.

If you are looking for a long term game to play, like high mobility third person games, and dont mind grinding things, Warframe is the game for you. If you can I would recomend finding someone to help guide you along as the tutorials have a hard time keeping up with the game as things change.

This is the perfect kind of game in which you can play without worrying too much about being the 'best'. With a slew of weapons and warframes to choose from you can customize how you play pretty heavily. The action is fast, the control feels good, the camera is completely terrible like many games like Warframe.   The main issues I would say about this game come into play whether or not you want to spend IRL money. You do not ever NEED to spend IRL money for this game. It isn't as much pay to win as much pay to rush. You pay to get things you don't feel like waiting for. In this regard I feel the biggest downside of the game is how much effort you will put into getting something that you won't use. A lot of weapons aren't as effecient, despite having really cool designs and it feels bad spending the time to upgrade a weapon just to have it underperform.   If there is a specific warframe that you want. I would recommend buying them if you're going to spend and IRL money. I wound up quiting the game for a long time because I didn't like the starter frame I chose. Not because they were bad but because the didn't feel good for me to play. However, coming back buying the one I thought looked coolest at the time hooked me on this game for a consecutive 3 months. It has it's issues sure overall this is a great game. That said look at the positive and negative reviews.

The only problems i can think of are the new player experience(which they are currently rehashing), a but of grinding in the beginning and some abbundant bugs and glitches, but none too annoying, more funny than anything else. If you need a time sink between releases, or a good 1/2 hour-hour of gameplay a day, this game is for you! Even after 3 years of playing this game, i have never gotten bored, and my hours should help speak for me.

This is one of the best free games in the world right now, if not THE best. It's simple, elegant and the combat is amazing. I've seen many people complain about repetitiveness, which yes, is an issue, but the fun part is playing online with different people, collaborating to find the best way to do a mission, and there IS actually quite a wide variety of missions. Survival, defense, exterminate, void runs, dark sectors, pvp, quests, even a relay for you to just chill and talk some crap with others. The community of players is great; they're very patient with newbies. I've been very happy with how the players, especially high-levelled ones, patiently deal with the new guys and even people who still kind of suck like me. Melee combat is really fun especially if you have stance mods on, and combat overall flows very smoothly. One moment you could be wallrunning, then the next hanging on the wall and picking those neat headshots, then rolling on the ground and slicing someone in half... You get the idea. Many newbies also complain about the apparent pay2win factor of warframe, but in reality, this is one of the few games left that you don't NEED to spend money on to actually get good. This is currently my favourite game, and as far as I'm concerned, this stands proud among some of the huge paid games around.
